reviewText:
Though I haven't finished the game yet, I've been pretty entertained thus far. It blends a little of Neverwinter Nights and a little Dargon Age to create game that isn't strictly either, and at least for me it proves an enjoyable blend. The combat mechanics don't try to direclty simulate DnD rules in its entirity, wich in my mind is a good thing as DnD rules were never meant for direct translation into a computer game. In Sword Coast Legends your characters all gain various abilities you purchase with points gained by leveling up, and most abilities are on a cooldown timer, or otherwise grant some passive bonus. Battles are largely about timing those abilities and knowing how they synergize with each other, combined with prioritizing your targets. Some fights can become challenging if you don't make the best use of your abilities, and if things feel to easy you can raise the difficulty and also select options that reduce some of the game's more friendly combat features like the ability to stablize dying companions in combat. Overall I found fights just challening enough to be stimulating, kind of like Dragon Age: Origins, if not quite as intense.

The story is alright so far. I haven't finished the single player campaign yet so I can't judge all of its components, but the main plot is serviceable if a tad basic. I found its strength so far to mostly be the party members who journey with the character I've made, as each has a fairly distinct personality and background that I've enjoyed learning through chats at the camp and doing their side-quests, and they have entertaining banter as we adventure around. Heck, they've been more memorable than most the characters in the first Neverwinter Nights, none of which I can remember except for the kobold bard Deekin.

Both graphics and audio get the job done without really having anything that stands out. The music neither inspires nor grates, the graphics show me what needs to be shown without wowing me, and the voice acting is... actually rather decent, overall. So no offense here.

If I level any major complaints towards the game its the lack of overall roleplaying options in a roleplaying game set in what is arguably DnD's mot well known setting. Yes you got dialouge options, and can sometimes use your stats to persuade or intimidate an NPC, I never got the feeling I was able to define my character beyond basic responses. The dialouge options available to your character are just kind of limited and dry, and more than that there's little in the NPC dialouge that makes you feel like they're talking to your distinct character. For example, I rolled up a drow fighter, because its Forgotten Realms and if I'm not going to make a Drizzt clone then what's the point of Faerun even existing? Joking aside, I was disapointed there was zero dialouge or respone to my drow character actually being a drow. In fact *spoiler tag for main storyline* one of the characters your encounter and work with eventually reveals himself to be a drow, which your party treats like a big betrayal of trust, accusing him of lying and basically calling him a dirty drow... all the while I'm standing there, drow as a demonic spider orgy, and none of them had responded to that fact once the entire story.

So, yes, the story could've used some expansion to include more roleplaying options, but other than that, I've had fun.

7/10, will keep adventuring as a dirty drow that apparently has the world's most clever disguise of wearing a helmet.

reviewText:
I was really looking forward to this game.  I had a good time playing it at first, until I got to Luskan and the story felt like it got derailed by a ton of distractions.

Things I liked about the game:
- It has a good character creation system.  It includes a lot of options, facial customization, subrace, background story, as well as stat modifiers based on most of those choices.
- The look of the game is all right.  It's better than it's predecessors.
- The music is decent, I liked it.
- It conveys the feel of a D&D game well.
- Despite distractions, the story is neat.  I like the idea of it and it compels me to continue playing in spite of all my other complaints.

Things I didn't like about the game:
- It has some pretty severe optimization issues for a lot of people, myself included.  I can't run the game at anything higher than the lowest settings due to the game overheating my card.  My card normally runs at around 55-60C with any other game, but somehow this game has managed to push my card to temperatures exceeding 80C.  I'm hoping this gets   fixed in the future.
- There is no easy way to get details about creatures you are fighting.  No right-click -> Examine functionality.  The closest you can get to this functionality is to use the journal and try to locate the enemy in the bestiary, and some creatures are missing from this screen.
- The camera won't zoom in enough for you to be able to see the facial customizations you made at creation.
- The camera often locks you into very awkward angles preventing seeing things on the ground.  There are many times where the camera hard-locks me into a top-down view without letting me zoom to see smaller items on the ground.
- There is no setting to increase the rotation speed of the camera, making that a bit of a chore as well — the camera just needs a lot of love.
- Interacting with any NPC zooms and locks in your camera as though it were an important story aspect.
- Dragging abilities to the power bar has an unexpected delay– you have to hold the mouse down for a second in order to move anything around, which doesn't really make sense when you are in the skill menus; I could understand such functionality while in combat, but this is a 100% of the time deal.

Overall, it's an all right game with lots of issues which will hopefully eventually be resolved.  I think my biggest problem with it is that I can't stop myself from comparing it to the original Neverwinter Nights series, which was excellent in so many ways.  It leaves me wishing that the original engine could just be modernized and expanded.

I'm still going to play it to completion because the story is interesting.  However, I would not currently recommend this game to anyone I know.  Maybe eventually, but not currently.

reviewText:
Why the Mixed reviews?

I'll tell you why, it's not mainstreamed. They tried something new and some things work and some things don't, BUT... They are working at fixing some of it. One of the biggest flaws i've heard people complain about is the lack of customization with DM mode when it first came out. Another was it's not HARDCORE to the PnP rule set. I guess people like myself and the many friends I play it with just are able to look passed those things as with the first 2 Community Patches they have added SO MUCH conent to the dm crafting and there is more beeing added consistantly. They already have ALLOWED MODDING, so the Modding community will change the things these whinners are complaining about. As far as rulesets go, this is one of the more enjoyable d&d experiences I've had.

I'm Going to focus on the Negatives for a moment as to what I beleive are the worst. I had a hard time getting passed level 5 as I felt it was going slow. I hate the current single player AI, they are just plain stupid. They could really add in the old BG AI system or Dragon Age AI system with spells and health and such.

I waited till the free weekend to try it out and I am very happy i gave it a shot. I read soooooooooooooooooooooo many bad reviews and watdched a bunch of gameplay footage on youtube and I was like... where are these bad reviews coming from. So trying it myself and leaving the reviews where they belong(in the trash) I started my journey in the Sword Coast Legends. First thing I did was played for about 18 hours. Then I some how convinced my brother and friend to give it a shot. Within 2 hours we were having a Blast. I've now 200 hours invested in the game and I wanted to write a review as I would say about 70% of the bad reviews come from people with Locked profiles or only 2 hours max in game, lots even 5 mins....... (Thats saying a lot about the review you are getting)

The DUngeon Master Module building is jsut awesome. I've invested over 65 hours into 1 module of my series. I didn't realize how much fun it would be to build a story how I want to tell it. And the excitement to play it is just awesome sharing it with friends. Adding in my own mobs, names and humor that my friends will enjoy as well as other.
Sure it needs work, needs more options, need more features in dialog and commands, but those things are coming. New tiefling race already coming and a class to go with it, so they are bringing more and more content out.

Just do me a favor and if you don't buy it now, if and when there is another free weekend, Definatly Give It A Go and I know you will or atleast most of you who keep questioning it Will Love It.

I give it a 8.5 outta 10 atm, but as more content and features are added my rating will only go up.  IF you would like anymore info you can usually catch me on http://www.twitch.tv/jaizek As i have been streaming the building of my module and explaining things to others. Its a Great supposrtive community.
Hope to see you in game.

Cheers

reviewText: I don't understand the immense amount of hate this game has recieved. I just got this the other day and I've found this game to be highly entertaining. reviewText: I like this game. It can be fun. I feel like I should start off with that, cause it's important to note I don't hate this game. But it's still very clunky and frustrating at times, both as a player and DM. It got some things right in ways I find great, like having a DM and having killed enemies drop items the DM can use in a session. But at the same time, there are way more things it did wrong, like not giving the DM any control whatsoever on what loot can be offered where and when. The closest interaction a DM can have with loot is to place treasure chests down, and even then you can't decide what's in it. Just that it's there, and only a certain amount of chests can be placed in a session across multiple maps. Not being able to make your own companions for DM sessions with friends is frustraing, and I don't see the option as dropping friendly characters as being the same thing. Honestly this feels like a very cool in-beta game versus a finished one, and the idea this could ever be priced at $40 blows my mind. I could maybe talk myself into paying $20, but the fact there's supposedly already DLC for it and it's in this state makes that hard to do. In all honesty, I don't see myself playing this much once the free weekend ends. Sorry. I want to love this game, but I just can't get past some of the restrictive, clunky, cheap-feeling flaws and glithces.

reviewText:
As someone who could care less how closely it follows the latest D&D rules, I find the game to be fun.  The only nitpicks I have thus far are some game-breaking bugs (quest triggers not triggering, quests disappearing entirely after loading a save), and the fact that the art style of the weapons, armor, and clothing can't be taken seriously, i.e. it isn't based on real world examples, and also seems a bit haphazard even for a fantasy game, as if it lacks an overall cohesive theme/direction, but these are personal preferences.

Otherwise, the gameplay is entertaining and has some features that other games in this genre simply don't have.  It's worth the base price of $40, but the Deluxe ed. definitely feels like a bit of a rip-off and is geared towards those who simply must have everything available to them as the Dungeon Master.

So long as the developers keep improving the game and expanding the content, it will have a place in my library until something that can do all of the same things better comes along.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I played this for a few hours and have to say I don't really recomend this.

The whole time I was playing this I was mentally comparing it to Neverwinter Nights 2, Dragon Age: Origins, Avernum: Escape From the Pit and Divinity: Original Sin. It feels a lot like each of these games in ways but the execution is poor with the game mechanics and user interface choices. Also, the game is based off the 5th edition of D&D rules. I like 3rd edition best not this newer stuff. I like needing spell components and having to only have X number of pre-slotted spells a day not this MMO cooldown style.

The story was okay from the bit I played but nothing that was overly intresting from the beginning. I dunno, I just was not very happy with the product. Having to micromanage 5 character's inventories was the last straw for me... let me explain this. So you pick up a potion of regeneration, right? This now goes into your character's quickslot automatically. I don't want it in there because I want to save it! Then I have to remove it, no biggie right? Well it also goes into EVERY other character's quickslot bar too! So I have to remove that for everyone as well. Kind of a pain. It does not stop there! Later on if I loot that same potion of regneration it will go BACK into the quickslot bar! The few hours I played it was a constant tug of war to remove items like this and keep them out. Just ugh!

You cannot zoom down far at all. The game ran poorly for me on my system. The skill tree system looked cool at first but to me it was a design flaw. Just to hard to see things. Maybe the player made modules are better... the ones where you play a single character. But as for the long campaigns? No.

The combat system was not overly impressive either. Not for me. These are my thoughts: if ou want to play a fun action D&D game that actually follows the rules well try Dungeons and Dragons Online. There are some paywalls but its enjoyable and has a lot of free content. See my other review about that. Or you could buy Neverwinter Nights 1 or 2 from GOG.com if you wanted to play on a RP server. See my profile for links to that. The next best thing I can compare this to is Dragon Age: Origins. I loved that combat and it had a good story. Very fun game :) Sword Coast legends feels like DA:O  in some ways but seriously DA:O is way better.

If you like MMO-ish CD quickslot style combat and want a top down isometric RPG (like this is YOUR THING) this might be a decent one for you to try if its on sale. I will warn you about the UI once again though. They designed it poorly. The story seemed alright. It did make me laugh and smile a bit. Good voice acting and the writing was alright. It was not enough to sway me to keep it.

The mixed reviews were accurate. I'll give this one a 3/5

NOTE: The game was given to me by a friend. I am going to stop at 4 hours of gameplay and have them request a refund.  If they won't let him refund it I may just delete it from my account.

reviewText:
During the hype, I was expecting a Neverwinter Nights game. But because it wasn't, I stopped after the headstart access. Hoping perhaps after some big updates, there might be some improvements.

After months of waiting, I decided to give it a second chance.
Got a couple of my buddies and started playing the campaign mode.

One of us started talking to an NPC.
Everyone stops what they are doing and is brought over to listen to this conversation.

The moment the conversation ends, a friend wants to sell his items and talks to the Goods Merchant.
Everyone stops what they are doing and is brought over to listen to this conversation.

The moment the conversation ends, a friend accidentally clicks an NPC.
Everyone stops what they are doing and is brought over to listen to this conversation.

At this point, we decided, let's just go fight some stuff, maybe it'll be more exciting.
We entered combat against some bandits, steamrolled through without any need for positioning or strats.

Then we saw a random NPC, and a friend clicks him during combat.
Everyone stops what they are doing and is brought over to listen to this conversation.

We all quitted the game.

reviewText:
I am absolutely loving this game. I spent 82 hours in head start building modules, playing with new people, playing with friends, and just having an all around great time.

If you're looking for an RPG maker, you're going to be disappointed. If you're looking for a tool that allows you to tell live stories with your friends and shape them on the fly as you go, you are going to have a good time. I highly recommend checking out some of the streams / videos of the game where people are live DMing.

I will say that I have not played through the entire campaign, but what I have seen has been quite good. It isn't the best game I've ever played but it certainly is worth the $40 I paid.

The biggest down side is that the creation tools are very limited. It is hard to create content that doesn't require a DM to facilitate the game and I understand that a lot of people want this (myself included). However, the tools that are provided are intuitive and easy to use. I hope that they will eventually add in an advanced builder" mode that adds more depth to the creators tools so those of us who want to spend 100+ hours learning them and creating can do so. Until then

reviewText:
Overall, the game is filled with possibilities but fails to deliver. I had hopes for a Bulder's Gate/Pillars of Eternity style game, which I think that the advertising suggested. Instead, it plays like an ISO port. It feels like a low-budget touch screen game brought over to Steam with no effort at making it more PC friendly, which is a shame because if they had then the game could have been drastically improved.

What I played the most is the single player campaign. The writing is ok and the story line about what one might expect from a Sword Coast focused game. The tactical game, though, is painful. You control one character at a time with the AI controlling the rest. The AI uses abilities and there is no way to control when they do so, as one could in Dragon Age: Origins. Abilities that needed to be used at just the right time could easily be used at the wrong time by the AI. Another problem is that there is no way to set party formation, as one can in BG and PoE. Instead, everyone just charges in or, if the wait function is on, you have to micro manage each character, at all times. While the ability animations may be nice, combat quickly falls into ability spam fests and gets tiresome.

I would recommend BG I and II, PoE, Divinity, Icewind Dale I and II, or even Wasteland 2 or Fallout I or II before this game. for single player. It is a shame that this game was not of the quiality that DnD deserves and that it comes off as a cheap money grab.

reviewText:
I played during the free weekend, the game has been on my wishlist a little before it officially came out. I wasn't able to buy it at first because I didn't have the money. Glad that this was the case as this game did not meet my expectations.

Now I know you've heard it all before on failing to meet expectations but I knew this before I began the free weekend. I really had the feeling as if I was playing Diablo except that every enemy I met was a bullet sponge. I played a couple of D&D based games before like BG and NWN and I absolutely enjoyed them. I also have played games like Diablo, Torchlight and PoE and I've also enjoyed those games. This game feels like it's trying to be both.

In any case there were a few things mechanically I personally did -not- like. Perhaps these are because of the 5e edition DnD but regardless I didn't like them. Since the fact they didn't completely follow the guidebook perhaps they should've reconsidered the following things:

-Skill tree(s) : It's one thing to have feats/skills that have a requirement it's whole different story when spells get into the mix. Also the tiered skills and spells could definatly have been replaced by more passives or abilities.

-Stealth : I played a Thief/Rogue at lvl 10. Maximized the stealth skills and had extra stealth on my items, still got spotted by every single thing in every single room. There was 0 chance on avoiding a fight, this makes me very sad.

-Cooldowns : Previous games had abilities, spells and skills that you could only do like 1/day or something like that. Which was fine as you would just camp somewhere before engaging in a next fight. Now you have cooldowns, on which some skills can take AGES. Arrow of Slaying, 200 second cooldown. I compared the damage with my bow rogue when I came out of stealth (on the rare occasion I wasn't spotted) with maxed out sneak attack. And the damage is the same, except stealth you can spam every 5 seconds for that 1 attack. Also sneak attack is the ONLY reason to even be rogue.

-Overall Simplicity : No more weapon specifics like damage and hit. Doesn't even tell you the save rolls you make right off the bat. Overall there's too many details missing to actually know what you're doing. Lots and lots of junk items. No action queueing.


TL;DR

It's not that the game is bad, it just wasn't really enjoyable for me. It might be for you, but personally I can't recommend it. It raised expectations, failed to meet them. Came out over-simplified. Seemingly tried to take the best out of 2 worlds but didn't quite make it. Need to waste some time?, this is a fine game. Want to play a good/memorable game?, look somewhere else.

reviewText:
I am so disappointed in this game!

The biggest reason for this disappointment is that I've been looking forward to a game that captures the fun in playing D&D and was very excited for the release of this game.  Being immersed in the story and history of the Forgotten Realms sword coast should have rocked!  The idea of being able to create a dungeon and lead a group of friends through as DM sounded awesome!

Unfortunately the developers of this game didn't deliver a game that hit any of these expectations.

THIS ISN'T D&D!!!!!

That can't be understated.  It doesn't feel like D&D.  This game doesn't have the mechanics in combat of D&D.  It doesn't have the spells (cleric, or mage) of D&D.  It doesn't have a full compliment of D&D races or classes.  Nor do any of the included classes advance as they should in D&D.  There are ZERO out of combat skills/feats/spells.

Basically.... It isn't fun like D&D.

The MAC version of the game runs SO bad its unplayable.  Tried on my Macbook Pro, Mac Mini, and Macbook Pro Retina.  With the graphics setting all the way down, I was never seeing frame rates above 30fps.  Normally around 15-20 when its not crashing.  The PC version, boot-camped on the same hardware, runs MUCH better performance wise.  Its clear that they don't have a clue on how to bring a quality gaming title to the Mac OSX platform.  Other developers can do it, why can't they?



PLEASE DON'T BUY THIS GAME!

Don't get suckered into giving up your money for a D&D game that isn't D&D.

reviewText: A license of Wizard of the Coast, the Forgotten Realms and specifically the Sword Coast! for god sake! and after all these years since the last game of D&D, this is what we get? Nein. No, thanks. Overall disappointment. This does not do justice to the great ones, not even to the most mediocres of those times. The game, if we forget the part where it is definitely not a D&D game, it's not that bad, ok but... but there are plenty of non D&D games much better (I rather Dungeon Siege instead this one). First of all, the game requires and force you to create an account before allow you to see a menu or do whatever, so... WTF. Its story is too typical, dull, not remarkable. So much missed potential here, the world is easily forgotten. Character creation is simplistic, the combat system it's ok, but like others standard dungeon crawler. The graphics are meeh, animations, scenarios... Neverwinter Nights 2 (released in 2006) looks almost identical (and of course is a masterpiece, and a real D&D game) so... what's the point to buy this game? The Sword Coast was the scenario of some of the best games ever made (Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale), you cannot call your game like that and not make a work of art, you cannot work in Dragon Age Origins and do this... No. This is not the game we deserved and is not the game we expected. If you want a truly D&D game or just a great role-playing, just revisit the classics, the holy trinity (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale & Planescape Torment), Neverwinter Night 1 & 2 (Mask of the Betrayer, yes, please), The Temple of Elemental Evil or the new masterpieces Pillars of Eternity or Divinity Original Sin. But this one, no, I cannot recommend it (especially if you like all those previous games which I named). If you do not want any of that, you only want a simple, unremarkable, superficial and a bit enjoyable role-playing game, you can give it a try.

reviewText:
I really never review games, but seeing some of the negative reviews for SCL, I felt compelled to give my 2 cents.

Looking at this game objectively, it is easy to see that the majority of negative reviews stem from individualist expectations of what players perceive the game SHOULD have been.  The nomenclature Dungeons and Dragons" is not to be thrown around lightly when fans are as passionate about the subject matter and gameplay style as DnD fans have proven to be.  Few negative reviews have pointed out anything beyond the fact that the game is not NWN 3.  I do not believe that this was the intention of the developers as much as it was the HOPE of the gaming community.

The old Infinity Engine and NWN games are among my favorite PC games of all time

reviewText:
I don't understand all the negatives people are posting. To me - and I played a lot of Baldur's Gate and NWN this is an excellent modernization of that ongoing franchise.

Party make up is quite flexible - and with four members you can switch between leaders on-the-fly, and also choose whether to control all party members in every action they take or simply play the one you want and let the rest act as AI controlled henchmen.

I've found battles to be both interesting and challending, the graphics are really nice (particularly if you zoom in to see things up close, althought that can be problematic during combat when you want a good field of vision.

I haven't played pen & paper D&D v5 so can't comment on the accuracy of SCL vs that, but the ability selections are quite varied and rewarding letting you customize your team as you wish (and yes, you also control the leveling up of your henchment/party members).

The quests for the most part are pretty good, puzzles take some thought, the game doesn't lead you by the nose like some do - your brain is a valuable accessory; you should want to use it from time to time.

I've also played player created modules and found them a lot of fun. First time I did that I didn't realize I'd started a public game until two voices came out of the speakers saying Hi
date: Krystyn" but we all went along together and had a great time.\n\nCamera control is 360 degrees which is great
recommended: allowing you to view the battle from any/every angle.  I admit to playing a mostly tactical game
hoursPlayed: pausing fairly often in combat to give specific party members commands - but in the multiplayer no one paused and we just played fully in real time. Both were fun.  :-)\n\nIn summary

reviewText:
Two words.... Neverwinter Nights. Okay maybe not as epic as the Neverwinter Nights 2 was for me, with all the extra scenes with your companions, I'm nearing the end of Act III and it is alot of fun, at times it can be hard to kill certain foes as well as to get better gear, but over and doe it is fun and runs like the Original Neverwinter Nights did. If you liked that game you are sure to like this one, it won't match up to some things of Neverwinter Nights 2, but most games can't in any case. Now I know that not all people will like this, there are issues, but I can tell you as part of the Headstart access, they development team did listen to us on glitches and problems. No game is perfect, but if you want a story that will engage you companions that are funny as well as serious and NPCs that you can really hate or love, then I would suggest that you play this game.

The background I would have to give around 9/10

The characters I would have to give around 8/10

Your Companions I would rate at 9.5/10

Side Quest I would have to give about 7.5/10

Main Story, Narration and plot I would give 10/10 (Yeah, I liked it alot so far, will change it though once I complete it)

Overall 9/10

But this is just my review and what I think of the game, make your own judgement on it when you play

reviewText:
I got suckered into pre-ordering this game.  My time spent trying to get the DM tools to do what I was hoping they might, and finding out they never would, was enough to ensure I couldn't get a refund for this title.

So, basically, I'm giving this game my lowest mark.  It was a community rip-off and WoTC should be ashamed they ever got the hopes up of so many veteran D&D players, especially old time DMs like myself, who believed the hype and actually thought this game would be the equivalent of NWN 3, with real tools that actually would allow custom campaigns.

I've learned my lesson after this and after a similar crapshoot with a game called Dungeons:  I will never pre-order a game again.

The funniest part about this review is that I had to play the release version for 3 extra minutes (5 total) in order to post it, yet I can't get a refund.  Yeah, hilarious.

reviewText:
Rolled a Dice for refund! Got it!

Why? Well i expected a D&D game from a game that has a D&D stamp on it. Based on the gameplay this has absolutely nothing to do with the classic D&D games like BG, IWD und NWN. What really matters in any RPG game to me is the combat and this system just feels like most games these days. Washed out and simplyfied for a larger audience that doesn't want to be bothered with thinking about builds and choices in character creation and development.
Honestly i didn't play it much but a already know that this game is nothing i'd spend 59,99€ on.
I'll might buy it as soon as it's on sale for ~30€ with all upcoming fanbase-milking dlcs.
The story sounds ok but i didn't want to risk playing more than 2 hours for the sake of refunds.

If you want... something... playing in the D&D universe and have at least one person to play it coop, pick it up as soon as it's on a big sale. Otherwise just buy BG:EE, BG2:EE, IWD:EE. If you already have those... well... i feel your pain.

3/10 Because there are no Dragons you can use in the editor... in a Dungeons and DRAGONS game.

reviewText:
Purchased this game during the recent half off sale and can honestly say it's only worth the $20 if you highly value a one time story playthrough.

Pros
+Decent overall graphics
+Brings back memories of the oldies in the genre
+Randomized dungeons for quick online games

Cons
-Hair graphics are from 1995
-Starting power in the game is basically zero. You'll get wrecked by goblins 1 on 1.
-Abilities are absolutely useless compared to auto attacks
-Items are completely out of control. Zero cooldowns and 75%+ action speed increases later on.
-All of the broken items can be put into a chest for your other characters to use. So lvl 1 with the best gear possible.
-DM mode is weak.
-Mod building is even weaker. It's 90% random even though you build it"

The one real plus this game has going for it is a decent story mode. But really
date: it's just decent though the playthrough might be worth your $20. Other than that though it's pretty much a train wreck. As stated before the abilities are useless compared to auto attacks for all classes. Later on in the game (character levels) you'll get a plethora of items that give you "cooldown reduction %" so that your ability cooldowns are no longer 20 seconds to 6 minutes (yes 6 minutes for a couple abilities that are bad). In fact you can get 100% cooldown reduction so that you don't have any! Sounds great but the only abilities you'll use are the ones that bolster your auto attacks. For reference I have a lvl 20 fighter that uses a super pimp longbow
hoursPlayed: has zero cooldown on abilties (so infinite +50% action speed)
voteText: +75% action speed from items
helpfulPercent:
and crits on something like 6-20. So that's basically 11 attacks per round that almost always crit. And you can do this with any class. Quite literally nothing can stand in front of you for more than about 2 seconds.

But why can't anything stand up to that? A sly mod builder could certainly build to counter your uber character right?

No. The mod building system is supremely gimped. Nearly everything is randomized and you can't even control what kind of equipment/ability scores the monsters/npc's will have. Mod builders are basically forced to make vanilla characters. This lack of authority stretches to other areas of mod building as well; can't put specific items anywhere. It's all random.

tl;dr - You start off pathetically weak and end up godly within less than 30 hours with absolutely no reason to continue playing."

reviewText:
I held off buying this game because of all the negative reviews, but caved when I saw the sale price.  I'm an old school PnP gamer that has also played the gold box series, EoB series, and most of the rest of the D&D games since.  I can see where some of the negative reviews are coming from, your character building is more similar to WoW than D&D, but I haven't found that detract from the adventure or my ability to build the characters I want how I want them.

Many of the older games that tried to faithfully recreate the PnP D&D systems have been hit and miss.  Often they just bogged the game down in stats.  I would like to see this game perhaps expanded a bit towards the stat side of the spectrum, but I don't feel it is so far to the arcade" side that it won't be fun to D&D enthusiasts (myself included).

I'm having a blast at 4 hours into the story."

reviewText:
Now I understand the devs went bankrupt, so there's not a lot they can do, but I've noticed the game could use some polishing up. For one thing, your character's race, alignment, religion, and background have virtually no impact on the story at all. One of your companions who greatly distrusts and hates the Drow apparently has no reaction towards your character being a Drow. Yet when you encounter another drow companion, she goes into full on paranoia like she's expecting them to stab the whole party in their sleep!

There is also no way to double check your character's flavor build after you leave character creation, short of writing it into your bio. Once you finish character creation, there's no way to check what your alignment or your deity is. But the worst part is that this also extends to the Ranger's racial enemy as well!

One of your companions, is a Ranger. But I can't tell what they're supposed to be good at killing, because it doesn't list it anywhere for them. Not even so much as giving a hint in their character bio!


The story is played on a railway system with the only significant choices appearing to be whether or not you kill people / recruit them to join you. Even if you're playing an evil character who wants to slaughter the world, there's no evil ending" that lets you side with the main villain
date:
or at the very least usurp their power. You have to be the hero!


Even the module creation needs some working on. From what I can tell
recommended: the equipment you have available in DM mode is dependent on what gear you have come across during your adventures. The first time I tried to make a module
hoursPlayed: the list of equipment I could give to NPC's was extremely limited. But after I found a bunch of loot on my own play throughs
voteText: I found the available selections had opened up. What this basically means is that you need to grind as a PC before you can make a good module as a DM!\n\nYou also can not pick the reward that quests give you when creating a module. You can decide whether or not it gives you gold
helpfulPercent: but you have to pick "Random" on whatever kind of weapon / armor / trinket that it gives you. You also can not custom design weapons / armor / trinkets. Which I can kind of understand
votesHelpful:
but it's still disappointing.


Those who are accustomed to D&D games and the crap load of spells and abilities they have to offer
votesTotal: may be off put by the skill tree system
votesFunny: but it's actually not so bad once you get accustomed to it. The downside is that some of your companions will have access to trees that are exclusive to them
commentsCount: even if you're playing as the same class.  For example
column16: the Deception tree is part of the Wizard class
column17:
but one of your companions can learn it. This comes across as being unfair and detracts from the idea of building the character you want to play.


If you're looking for a hack and slash dungeon crawler
column18: then Legends of the Sword Coast is fun to check out. But if you're hoping for a role playing experience
column19: you're going to be disappointed."

reviewText:
Just finished a few days of SCL, about half way through the main quest.  Sadly, it's not a great game, but it is fun for those who like the Forgotten Realms setting and Lore.  The story is a little vanilla, the characters lack that sparkle from previous games and the number of classes and races are very limited.  However, it has that Forgotten Realms vibe, along with some cheeky and knowing humour which reminds me of BG2.  Additionally, for once, the wizard and cleric character and ability trees are really interesting, perhaps even a little over powered.  You do get to chuck a lot of spells about as your fighter just sits around sucking up the heat.

The two biggest problems to date are loadng times between places and very uninteresting loot.  These can be easily fixed.

Not a DM, so can't really comment on that stuff.

If you like a bit of single player rpg action, this isn't a bad bet to while away 40 hours in a familiar way.  It just isn't the game everyone was hoping for - Neverwinter Nights 3.

reviewText:
A decent game for fans of D&D who enjoy a dungeon crawl with friends. The game mechanics are similar to Baldur's Gate/Icewind Dale.

I recommend that you play a char with healing ability like a cleric, you wil be able to solo some of the content without having to rely on potions all the time.

The addition of fan-made modules means that there are hours of content left to explore

But the game does crash from time to time, and it can get a bit confusing if you don't know where to go to complete some quests, many of which are very similar.

Most of the complaints come from pen & paper fans who are angry that this game is not a direct translation of their beloved ruleset.

TL;DR: Decent game if you have friends willing to play it with you.

reviewText:
This is a game I'd really like to recommend; but having put in several hours I no longer want to play it and will not be finishing it. It boils down to a combination of incredibly clunky interface, and lack of flavor in the setting. The game itself is fine, but pales in comparison to older titles (Arcanum, Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, Planescape Torment, or Dragon Age: Origins) both in terms of enthralling combat and engaging story.

Gameplay:
- Interface is clunky (especially equipment/shopping)
- Camera controls aren't that great; can only click to move
- Combat is so fast that the AI is in control of most characters most of the time, and the AI isn't particularly good
- Spell variety is limited
- Load times feel like a big wait
- Quests are simultaneously too simple (go get an X) and too vague (where do you get an X? wander around the area until you wind up in the right place)

Storyline:
- Backstory for characters & places is *extremely* limited
- Exposition generally lacking flavor
- NPC dialogue is lacking, not full-fleshed characters

reviewText:
If you don't have up high expectation to a D&D this game may be fine for you, but it's skill system and playability have been dumped down, very limited choices on how to solve the quests.

That aside, the game is broken beyond playability. Each time they add a fix, you have to download 2 GB patch. Each patch breaks more than it fixes. 30 hours into the game, a patch completely broke my NPC followers with a forced skill reset and after the reset, they granted Skillpoints equalling a level 3 character, but they were level 5 already.

Playing that game on hard, the right skills at the early levels are essential to continue playing, with this game breaking bug it becomes impossible to continue with characters that are effectively 5 levels lower than the enemies (+2 for hard mode and +2 for lacking skill points, +1 cause they are 1 level lower than the main character).

So don't bother with this game, before they fix all the issues and it becomes playable. If they ever fix it. It's been 2 months since the bug broke my save game, and there is still not fix for it.

reviewText:
Sword Coast Legends (SCL) received a mixed bag of reviews upon its release; many with fair points of criticism.  In the months since, however, the devs have listened well to the community and have really tackled a lot of the complaints that were raised at the time.  This is not to say the game has been perfected, but it’s come a fair way since October and definitely deserves a positive rating now.  Bear that in mind when looking at reviews of this game here on Steam.

As a long time fan of D&D, I want to love this game.  That is not to say that I have walked blindly into this and determined to see only the positives, but I’m glad to say that I really do like what's been created here and it has got a lot of positives about it and a HELLUVA lot of potential.  If the devs remain committed to it throughout 2016 and maybe even beyond, perhaps keeping it up to date with the story seasons of D&D itself and expanding the DM mode, there is perhaps a classic in the making here.  With Pillars of Eternity bringing the cRPG genre back to the fore and Beamdog about to release Baldur’s Gate 1.5, SCL has arrived at a period of resurgence in this genre and, being a D&D product, has a lot to live up to with BG, NWN and ID all as brilliant forebears to this iteration.  Overall, it’s probably on a par with some of the weaker of this group (which is a great achievement in such esteemed company!) but perhaps falling short of the scope and depth of the strongest and not on a par with PoE, but again, this is a great game in its own right.

Visually, SCL is a beautiful game with a lovely blend of the artistic style of D&D and a richly detailed fantasy world.  It’s no Skyrim in this regard, but such a comparison is pointless as they are two very different games.  For a cRPG, it is beautiful to play within.  The one annoyance I have is not quite having complete control of the camera and to do so would only enable players to more fully enjoy the amazing world of Faerun as presented here in SCL.  The soundscape is nicely attuned to a variety of settings and ranges from relaxing ambient noise to chilling effects that really enhance the overall atmosphere.  Magic is particularly great, not only to watch but to listen to through an intense battle.  The ferocity and intense action is all the more pervasive with the carnage of battle ringing in your ears!  The music by Inon Zur (BG2, ID2, Dragon Age, Fallout, LOTR: War in the North, need we go on?!?) is brilliant adding yet another layer of atmosphere to a game that is already soaked in it.    Finally, the voice acting is very strong with confident writing shining through the performances which balance the best bits of D&D’s slightly tongue in cheek style with enough dramatic punch to not leave you cringing.

The gameplay is quick and simple to pick up with a great variety of personalisation options available to each of your characters and a good deal of skill trees to pick a whole range of useful abilities from.  All of this really nicely echoes the flavour of classic D&D and really enhances the feeling you are playing a digital version of the tabletop game, more so than its predecessors with its more transparent mechanics and intuitive UI.  The party mechanics are simple yet effective and allow you to play as either the whole group or as an individual with your companions following you at the press of the button.  Inventory is shared between the whole party which is a nice little time saver if perhaps a little too over simplified for some.  Now admittedly, whilst SCL is overall  very much simpler than the likes of BG or PoE, it’s not so dumbed down to the point of being overly limiting.  They have struck a good balance here which will probably still annoy the players that want absolute control, but you can never please everyone and what they have achieved is arguably an almost optimal balance that will hopefully please the greatest proportion of players.

What I think is the greatest achievement of the game is the feeling of playing D&D 5th edition.  In previous iterations such as BG, ID and NWN, the mechanics were there but felt overwhelming at times and hidden behind a fair bit of maths that would only be truly understood by putting the hours into the games or by a D&D player already familiar with the rules and mechanics.  In SCL, the mechanincs are clearly there but are simple to see, understand and grasp.  This is both a result of the great work by WoTC making 5th edition rules possibly the best yet but also the devs of SCL who adopted and adapted them really well to a video game with subtle changes made where necessary.  It really feels like a digital version of the tabletop RPG at times which, for me at least, is really exciting and satisfying!

Finally, DM mode is an exciting return to the module creators of NWN 1 and 2.  Although technically a lot simpler and consequently less powerful, there is an interesting twist with players actually able to DM a game in that they play with and against the players in a spirit not too distant from its tabletop counterpart.  Whilst fun, it is incredibly difficult to create an experience that is anywhere near as deep as the traditional D&D DMing experience.  In my opinion, this is also where the game is the weakest and yet also has the greatest potential.  The limitations upon creating modules are so severe in places that it is truly claustrophobic for creative storytelling and I have found myself working harder to create a story within the confines of the mechanics of DM mode than creating the actual story or events themselves.  The devs, however, have been making efforts to improve and expand the mode with Community Packs, of which 2 have been released to date with a third promised and extra content for the Rage of Demons storyline.  Whether this will truly bring the potential of the module creator to the fore remains to be seen but if it does, it will be incredible.  The strong, cult community that still exists around the NWN module creator to this day is testament to the potential power of that and the deep desire for a quality product in the D&D and cRPG communities.

reviewText:
My friend and I almost fell asleep playing this...
There's basically one strong point that this game has going for it:
Players can act as a Dungeon Master for their own Procedurally Generated dungeon content.  Meaning 4 players act as the adventure party while a 5th person serves as the dungeon master.  This makes for a pretty cool multiplayer experience and is a great idea.  I imagine most of the people still committed to this game are here for this experience.
The problem is that the game's weakest feature is the combat system which is a shame because tremendous portions of a gameplay session are spent fighting monsters.

The combat system, animations and class mechanics are extremely dull.

Animations and sound effects related to combat lack any visceral feel to them and ultimately this makes every encounter feel lackluster.

I'm not sure if it's the 5th edition ruleset holding these aspects of the game back or if the designers' interpretation of them is just uninspired.

Wizards of the Coast needs to consider a bigger investment in a more modern and more complete Dungeons and Dragons experience for the PC.  Even n-Space would probably be able to deliver something much better with more resources at their disposal.

The solution would be to consider a new, more visceral combat system and probably a fresh interpretation on all of the D&D character classes and how they can contribute to adventuring both in and out of combat.

Props to n-Space though for continuing to make aggressive changes to the game to try and improve the experience for people who want to keep playing,  I wish them good luck.

Some Feedback on the Postives Environment art looks fantastic
There are lots of multiplayer and cooperative opportunities available to the player.

reviewText:
A wonderfully build game.  The feel and look are very similar to Neverwinter Nights. (Currently fewer class options).  I have played through the main story once and loved it.  Most of the time the treasue was disapointing (but that is consistent with 5th edition rules, which scalled back the power of magic items for game balance).

I also like the storage chest shared between my characteres.

I have also spent quite a bit of time running dungeon crawls, both solo and with other players and found them are great ways to hack and slash with out needing to worry about quests or time constraints.  Being able to specify what tile set the dungeon uses as well as what monsters and bosses you face are a nice touch.

The module builder is severly limited. **Note: I have been a DM for about 3 years and am currently running a 5th Edition DnD campaign.  I have also put many hours into both of the Neverwinter Nights Tool Sets.
Compairing the two, it like saying Sword Coast Legends' Tool Set is Elementary School and Neverwinter Nights Tool Set is College.

I understand that the reason for the limitations is to retain game balance, but feel that the limitations go too far.  I cannot use an object as a transition point. (Tried using a well to transition into a cave dungeon)  A dm cannot even give specific quest rewards, only a random weapon, armor, or other. ( I wanted to give a specific cloak I saw in the game that gave some fire resistance as an initial quest reward)

All in all, it has replay value.  I first played through as a Halfling Rogue and look forward to playing the other classes and races.

reviewText:
Not for me.
By reading some reviews, I actually thought this was a more streamlined, arcade oriented version of D&D. Which was a criticism from users. Instead what I got feels too much like Baldur's Gate and all those games, which frankly I never enjoyed and by now I've outgrown.

The game has good graphics, though nothing spectacular or special. It does pay attention to detail, and I think it could make an ok multiplayer experience, but it's outside my current tastes. I'd prefer a more hack & slash variant, closer to the Gauntlet remake, but with the customization detail of D&D.

So yeah, this is not a bad game and it could be enjoyable if you like the pace and the depth that's in between Baldur's Gate type things and more streamlined things like NWN. Not for me, pace is too slow and detail is a b it too much, I don't feel like investing time right now.

I might come back to the game if it's dead cheap in a sale, because I like D&D a lot and there's not a lot of games, buyt currently it's too expensive. So I returned it, a bit sad about it.

reviewText:
Vibrant characters and a world chock full of exploration make this a great successor to games like Baldur's Gate. While not on par with past games like Neverwinter Nights, this D&D game has enough charm to keep you occupied for many hours.

A large number of negative reviews state that people were expecting certain things, and because of that, they gave the game a bad review. This game holds up on its own but, because of those reviews, the game has a FAR worse score than it deserves and it is a shame.

It uses the D&D 5th edition rule set loosely and by loosely I mean it adheres to the base rules in regards of stats and character creation. part from that, your abilities are on cooldowns (something I've seen a lot of complaints over) and enemies are HP sponges; taking a ton of damage before they are defeated. Even your most powerful abilities will only appear to dent their HP and that is one of my lone complaints. Low level enemies can just swarm you and, due to their numbers and large HP pool, beat you down which might put some people off.

It is worth a look if you're a fan of the genre.

reviewText:
This review is not based on the DM side of things, only the player dungeon crawl & story campaign as MULTIPLAYER.

SCL is meant to recreate sitting around the table with friends, discussing strategies, sharing story experience of the a dungeons and dragons module.  Battles would take  an hour to resolve as each player gets their turn, initiatives rolled, damaged dealt and received, laughs shared and omg we are going to die moments.  This is a at the heart of the feel I am looking for and why I looked into this game.

If you are looking for a game to play single player wise, it plays like a Baldur's Gate style game where battles can be paused to issue commands if you wish or go all out real time for quick instant gratification if you are so inclined.  It works fine for that style of play but you can easily get tired of it if you are on easy mode or frustrated if you are getting killed to quickly on harder difficulties.  This is fine to explore while you are waiting for your friends to come online to join in some adventures along the Sword Coast together.

Sword Coast Legends offers an all-new way to enjoy the time-tested magic of playing Dungeons & Dragons as a SHARED storytelling experience."

So does SCL deliver this experience? This is the big question.  The short amswer
date: almost but not quite yet.  If you came to this game to play with friends it works but without a pause or a timed pause feature it is very hard to recreate the table top feel.  The pausing has been disable in multiplayer because some players can be jerks and deliberately try to "ruin the experience" for others by pausing (and unpausing) too much. I can see multiplayer with pausing enable can increase the risk of ruing the game experience with abuse especially with strangers. But they really should have a system in place where the host of the game can pause
hoursPlayed: allow people on friends list only the ability to pause or a vote in game system to disable/enable pause permissions.  This would go along way to bring the table top feel to SCL.  Without the multiplayer pausing it takes away from that fundamental design element in the game
voteText: to bring the table top  feeling back where battles are discussed
helpfulPercent: strategies formed
votesHelpful: excution is modified and the taste of victory shared by all (even the DM).\n\nIn essence
votesTotal: without pausing (timed or otherwise)
votesFunny: multiplayer combat does not unfold in the same slower pace of a table top experience.  That seems to be the missing element(s).  If they do develop a system to modify the "pace" of the game (ie fast paced for those who like more of a hack & slash feel and slower for those who want a table top pace) this would make the game much closer to spot on where it needs to be.  Even a means to scale or adjust the level of combat speed in the game would be best versus the 2 extremes of with pauses or without.\n\nI will be watching this game for multiplayer improvements like pausing in the future.  I will happily purchase the game when this has been achieved substantially enough to make this aspect the game robust.  Until then I will hold back on the final purchase and keep an eye on the development of this game because I like the direction it seems to be going."

reviewText:
Oh Sword Coast Legends, people sure love to hate it. No, this is not Baulders Gate 3 or Neverwinter Nights 3, no this is not a 100% direct translation of the 5th edition Dungeons and Dragons ruleset.  But is this a failed attempt at creating a quality dungeons and dragons experience? No.  In what other game can I control a story while my friends play through it? Where can I have a deep mystery experience one night, a comedy adventure another night and a hack & slash fight fest the next? Sword Coast Legends is all these things as long as you put some effort into it and as long as you can arrange to play with others. This, in essence, is its problem. It needs other people  who are willing to invest into the experience. So if you have the will to join one of the Steam/online groups and are willing to put some imagination into the experience this game is a real gem. If you want to jump in and play by yourself, you may find your experience limited.

Some have complained that the toolset is limited, and I have to be honest it does have some limitations. The developers however have shown that they are very willing to listen to the community and are working hard to make this into the game its players wanted. Personally I'm enjoying my time in this game, and I'm excited by where the developer and the modding community are taking it. For me nothing that has come out in recent years comes as close to the feeling of DnD than this game does.  The feeling where anything could happen, where I am creating my own story and where I'm doing that parallel to others creating their own story as well.  On sale this is a steal, full price its still worth its investment. Please buy it so I can see what you bring to the table as a DM and lets create a story together.

*This is my first review with hundreds of games in my library. I feel this strongly about this game
*I also have 50+ hours during the headstart weekends, so I've been here since the begining

reviewText:
The notion that this game is not like Diablo, not a new NWN 2 with DM mode or any other classic CRPG seems to be quite clear now.

So, to cut that ****, lets just highlight the pros and cons IMO.

Pros:

A new way to tackle multiplayer cooperation with the DM threat meter
Cons:
I would have wanted more serious" graphics

reviewText:
Long time D&D player and really enjoying playing through the campaign as a 2 player co-op.

Sure, its a liberal interpretation of the 5th edition ruleset with some odd decisions like skill trees etc. but it still FEELS like d&d and thats whats important in my opinion. Its also a little rough round the edges right now, but with a few patches I'm confident this will improve.

Here are some of the things I like so far:

>NPC spoken dialogue is really really good and frequently very funny and endearing.
>A really good search system which is made good use of by frequent traps and secret doors.
>Lots of interesting little items that feel straight out of the players handbook: thunderstones, flasks of oil, glue, acid etc. All of which can be used in combat e.g. throwing a flask of oil makes any target it hits vulnerable to your fire spells.
>Proper CRPG combat with pausing (both manual and highly customisable auto pausing) and, at least on hard mode, the requirement for frequent tactical decision making.

Here are some of the things I would like to see improved:

>Playing 2 player coop as the host, there is no way to give control of one of my npcs to the other player.
>The wizard skill tree is missing a few essential spells like flaming sphere and burning hands, and doesnt properly reflect  the schools of magic.
>When you talk to some npcs in coop, its shared with the whole group, but other npcs conversations are not shared - this is confusing and I'd rather all conversations were shared with the other players, or to be able to configure this via the options menu.

reviewText: I'm not sure why people have thrown so much hate at this game. Maybe they impulse bought and regret their decision based on flawed expectations. This is not D&D Simulator 9000. reviewText:
I played it now for a couple of hours during the free weekend.
Lets split this up:

What it does good:

+ it keeps me in the game, the story and character dialoges are very good and I want to explore more of the story
+ Linux Version (big pro for me)
+ Graphics not to shaby, yet it runs smooth on my old Q6600
+ Sound and voice is flawless, I LOVE THE MUSIC (if you speak english fine, there are only german subtiles for examples no voices)
+ Well its cheaper, so I guess for RPG fans I would recomend it so far, full price I would wait for another Sale again
(I recorded some Gameplay and will upload a Video to youtube soon)
+ Multiplayer

Whats not so good:

- D&D just on the surface very shallow (and I am really not an expert, but even I notice it)
- fighting system really is somewhat weird, a mix of MMO and Dragon Age
- kind of a deja vu effect often. Didn't I see that in  Dragon Age 1 already? (camps, conversations there with the party)
- it feels like it was published to soon somewhat, had some crashes on Windows, Linux was fine so far, what reallly surprised me.
- some areas like Luskan, very laggy outside the city (might be my weak CPU)

What i can't rate is the DM Mode, and the random Dungeons, not tried it yet.

so for the price on sale right now, I would go for it and give it try. I will buy it, just because I want follow the story, wich really sucked me in.

reviewText:
To discripe this game in one word:
Limetations.

The story is avarge.
The multiplayer is full of rooms with one person in it that never speaks.
The classes are similer.
There are no skills to master.
No diplomacy, intimidation or lore.
The race selection is elves, dwarves, humans, half elves, and halfings.
No gnome's, yunati, planetouched, etc.
Druid arent in the game.
There arent any area of effect spells worth mentioning.
In fact the entire games feels like you just killing your way through whatever gets in your way.

To d&d fans:
If you are looking for a dungeons and dragons game this isnt it.
I am not a dungeons and dragons fan and even to me it feels like a bad hack and slash with a d&d skin.

If you want to buy it because it looks like d&d: dont it isnt d&d
If you want to buy a rpg: this is a hack and slash, no rpg to be found.
If you are bored, rich and got nothing to do: Go to the steam store and buy something better.
If this hasnt conviced you not to buy this game: sigh, go ahead and buy it.
You have already desided that you would.

reviewText: This game is awesome. I have 80+ hours into the game and I haven't even finished the story campaign. I can firmly recommend the game to any RPG player. It has a fun and engaging storyline campaign where you can choose to play single player or with up to 4 players in coop mode. It also has a dungeon crawl mode where you can play with up to 4 players in a party AND a Dungeon Master who controls things in the dungeon from a top down view. They can create monsters, buff monsters and add roleplay and story driven aspects as well as control them and the boss. The closest thing to being able to DM a video game to date that I have seen. Not only does it have these modes but it also has a campaign/module creation mode. In this mode you can completely customize a campaign from start to finish that up to 4 players can play and someone can DM. A lot of people give this game flak because it's not exactly dungeons and dragons. In my oppinion making a video game exactly dungeons and dragons is not only almost impossible. But, it just wouldn't be that fun. For the price point you get all of these features and they will be adding more detail to the module creation in the future. As it is the game is very well put together and provides more than enough bang for it's buck. If you like RPG and turn based RPG DnD type games I recommend this game.

reviewText: Another game by Wizard of the Coasts that attempts to revive older systems and mechanics in a new form. Sword Coast Legends plays like Neverwinter Nights, Baldur's Gate, Diablo or any other isometric RPG. However in this particular case, it has a active pause battle system with very MMO like ability system - all skills has short cooldowns. Nothing much from standard D&D casts per day. You can pause game and issue orders or just use tactics - Companions AI is not bad, however it sometimes fail to notice combat begins and just stands still until you won't issue attack order again. Character development is based on ability trees. Personally seen only Wizard ones: Starts from one skill, then next levels unlocks another branches and spells. Not much from D&D spellbook: Most common offensive spells like Magic Arrow, Melf's Acid Arrow and Disintegration. No utility spells and only couple buffs like Mage's Armour or Magic Weapon. Inventory is very similar to Neverwinter Nights 2. Unfotunately books, scolls, notes and any lore items with descriptions also uses this system, so you won't experience something like Skyrim's books to read. Shame.\nStory from prologue does not sounds bad, however the form in which is presented to the Player is just bland. Good thing there is voice acting during cutscenes, which are dull and without any emotion. It's the first time I played RPG and was doozing off when story was unfold. This is probably most grave and repulsive flaw of this title. For 20 euro I can get Pillars of Eternity, which will give me many hours of gameplay. There I get (according to developers) 30 hours of singleplayer scenario and then ability to create own games with other Players. Unfortunately, it is not enough of promise to make me invest my money in this title. It has potential, but feels too meek in comparision with other RPG of this type available to choose Sword Coast Legends.\n

reviewText:
I've been used to the heavyly luck-based battles in Baldur's Gate and the likes (BG II, PlaneScape: Torment, Fallout 1&2) but there the loading was quick... Here, there's up to 30 seconds to try again and the quicksave does not save buffs so you also have to redo the whole preparation.
I won't search if there's any mod to fix that, because it's a basic and it's a shame to make the solo experience (mostly based on trial and error/badluck) that awful and frustrating just because of the damn long loading time and broken save system.

By the way, random maps, random loot (even from chests). Luck-based rogue-like... In other words: they killed solo-mode and so they killed my curiosity for DM+party mode.


Maybe the game is enjoyable on DM+party mode, if the DM can balance the enemies and choose the loot. Maybe it's a good tool for pnp" nights. But there's many free tools on the internet."

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of the Neverwinter, Icewind Dale, and BG series games. When I saw this I was excited and decided to give it a try despite the bad ratings since it has a free weekend going.  Unfortunately I was disappointed and here's why:

The game creators skipped a whole lot of relevant information for helping players determine the rulesets.  During character creation it is very difficult to find out what bonuses the different races, subraces, and origins give. I had to use a wiki to even figure out what bonuses were given for the origin choices.  The racials don't give any indication on what they give and the only way to figure it out is to pop back and forth between the different screens to try and figure out what has changed, or to try and find a resource online that shows the values, unfortunately the online wiki doesn't even have this information.  Overall there's a complete lack of contextual information during character creation that can drastically affect how your character performs.  This information has always been present in past games.  Sword Coast Legends does a terrible job at letting you know the rules it will be playing by which is unforgivable for a DnD video game adaptation.

Now about the story: I played through the prologue, and the story elements are fine, but the story seems a bit forced.  You're a member of a cursed guild that no one thinks is legitimate etc etc. It is a bit frustrating however, that the story basically drops you in, jarringly, and you have no clue what's going on.  I think I would have received it a lot better if there was more backstory involved. As it is, the story tries to force you to care about characters very early in the game, but there has been no time to create a connection.

The combat system is fine, it works for this type of game although it does seem a little bit more sped up from previous titles. One of my gripes though is that spells and queued tasks aren't handled as intuitively as other titles.  It also doesn't seem to bear much relation to actual DnD with the skill tree system, and way it handles leveling.

Overall I think this game could be a lot better it just needs to provide more contextual information about the actual ruleset to the user. If it can fix these problems (which shouldn't be very hard at all). It would be a lot better. Unfortunately it seems like this is more of a game type that is dumped out for the community to just deal with and not get direct support. We'll see.

reviewText:
The only way I can recommend this game is if you have never played Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape: Torment, Pillars of Eternity, et al.  Or if you have played those games and did not enjoy them.

What I mean to say is, this game, while trying to be a spiritual successor to the aforementioned titles, is nothing like them at all.  That is the most egregious error that it makes.  It does not flow smoothly.  The in-game UI is terribly unintuitive and needlessly departs from the successful UI that most all of the above games utilized.

That isn't to say that it doesn't make any other errors.  This game is bad enough that it doesn't warrant a real game review.  So, without going too in-depth, here are some of the more annoying problems I found:
Based on playing through a brief part of the game, the dialogue sessions cannot be skipped or sped up in any way, nor can you re-read the dilogue by scrolling up, nor can you access the main menu or even leave the game when in a dialogue session.  This means that you MUST act out a full dialogue whenever it comes up.  And the voice acting is poorly directed, feeling forced or just unnatural.  So it gets old.  Fast.
The game world is rendered in 3D, so as to allow you to rotate the camera whenever you want, zoom in, and zoom out.  This is a neat idea, but foolish.  A rotating camera is completely extraneous in an isometric RPG, which is what this game is trying to be.  And because the game world is rendered in 3D, you lose out on those wonderfully painted landscapes that the Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale games offered.  In their place we have polygons that look like parti-colored clay.  In short - the game world is ugly.
The camera follows your main character around in a fashion very similar to Diablo.  This means that, for the purposes of an isometric RPG, the camera is too close to allow for a good view of the battle, and just doesn't behave very well.  This makes it difficult to maneuver party members, try to place spells or other area-of-effect skills, or to simply get a good view of things going on.
The UI is unintuitive and feels a bit sloppy, and possibly unfinished.  Perhaps an executive came in and arbitrarily ordered a developer to take away all those extra buttons! They clutter things up too much!"  There's no simple way to manipulate the party formation
date: nor adjust party AI on the fly.\nI would go into it a bit more
recommended: but frankly this game isn't worth the time spent typing
hoursPlayed: nor the time spent reading.  Don't waste your money
voteText: not even if you see it on sale."

reviewText:
I very rarely write reviews. I was very much looking forward to this game as I spent hundreds of hours with Neverwinter Nights and its editor and what it offered concerning player-made modules, persistant worlds etc.
I love the Sword Coast setting, I like Dungeons and Dragons and I love computer RPGs.
But ... I have stopped preordering most games a long time ago, so I waited until release and what I heard and read simply was not good enough to make me buy SCL.
So the free weekend was a good opportunity to form an opinion of my own.
It was not a good start: a game on steam offering a free weekend and still requiring an extra account besides Steam? Not good. Made me leave the game alone for a couple of hours until curiosity won over ... What might I be missing?
So I created an account and went to character creation.

- Really? You're calling this a D&D game and I can only create ONE character for the party, the rest is forced on you? And the choices in creation are extremely limited.

On into the game. Graphics ... well ... they are not that important to me (after all, I'm still playing Baldur's Gate 2 from time to time ... or Planescape Torment), but they certainly are not great.

- Combat is atrocious in my opinion. Not enough strategy, not enough skills, party members with full health bar are dead a fraction of a second later.

- Quests / story: While others say it's not too bad or even good, I did not find it particularly engaging. The first steps in the story, the first quests are so cliché I thought they were left behind in the last century.

Taking a look at the editor ... that's a joke, right? Not really enough options, not really enough freedom to create ...

All in all: Definitely not enough there to make me spend even $20.

reviewText:
Do not be dissuaded by the negative reviews provided for this game. I'm coming up to the 10 hour play mark with the current release, and 20+ on pre-release, and can very safely say, this is a fantastic representation of what digital D&D can become, and they haven't even added any additional content yet!

Single player includes an exciting story line with more voiced dialogue than you can shake a stick at. That being said, online mode is where the real fantastic things happen.

So far I've played 8 online campaigns with dungeon masters, and they are so fantastic. DM's voice the entire story and provide background dialogue, challenges are intense, and it all can be scripted from scratch! Sometimes players get into it and roleplay too (Shout out to my main man Ser Balder of Waterdeep, we'll get you that coal mine, buddy). The way that this game has allowed people to let their imaginations run wild is truly number 1.

Now to the nitty-gritty. The mechanics are much more advanced AD&D. Not only can your character focus on stats, but employ element attributes to stack as well. Not only that, but the spells are dazzling, and the combat tickers keep you planning. Well done, wizards.

Lastly, the content. The Sword Coast Legends team is developing constantly. They painstakingly took feedback for two months in pre-release, to bring something well done and fun to play. Imagine what's coming next from them. Longevity people, there will be more to come!

If you managed to get through all of that, and are now at the bottom of this review, know that this game isn't going anywhere, and the player community will thrive off of it if we let them. I really do believe this is a powerful successor to Baldurs Gate that will keep us coming back for more.

reviewText:
I have been in all the Head Starts and have been building campaigns and playing campaigns only (no story mode yet). At this point I really enjoy the game and the capability of creating and telling a story of your own creation. With the release I was very disappointed for two reasons. 1) I was expecting more outdoor areas. 2) I was expecting a ton more monsters.

Now, don’t get me wrong! There are a ton to choose from with monsters and objects. More than enough to create some really cool campaigns. Also, everyone needs to realize that N-Space has said that they will be patching in other items as well as providing some DLC to expand the library.

In all this is a fun game to play with friends and I would suggest grabbing a copy. In my opinion, the mixed reviews are a result of unmet expectations or ideas of how the game should be. When you let the community in and voice their opinion, which is what NS has done, you get a million opinions. That is a whole can of worms that I wouldn’t want to mess with. But, NS wants to continue refining the game to make it better and better. Shaping it into something the community desires.

I appreciate that.

reviewText: Have very much enjoyed this game.  Played in the Head Starts, worked for hours, even with limited DM options, to make fun adventures for my friends.  Single Player Campaign has been lots of fun too.  I like the pacing.  Played Pillars of Eternity, and Divinity: Original Sin, and I couldn't get very far in them; just took forever to get anything done as each battle was so slow (fun at first, fun for boss battles, but oh so boring grinding through battle after battle).  SCL speeds things up with real time combat (which can be paused and even set to pause after each round).  Inspired by DnD 5e, but not a copy of it may make some people upset, but table top DnD (which I have played for years) is a table top game, not a video game.  I like their interpretation of it.\nI'm sure more improvements are to come as they gather more data, and have more time to find out what works and what doesn't.  The game as is has been a lot of fun for me, and I'm enjoying DM mode in the creation, and in the playing aspect.
