reviewText:
Verdict: 7/10. Buy it now if you really want to play a D&D CRPG now. Otherwise, wait for a sale.

So I heard about this new game being developed called Sword Coast Legends, and it would be based on what was then called D&D Next (now known as D&D Fifth Edition, or D&D 5e). It would take place in the Sword Coast, a region of Faerun familiar to those who have played Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights. It was being made by some of the people who worked on the original Dragon Age: Origins, who I assumed were those who didn't sell their souls to Electronic Arts.

Oh, and they were asking for some rather silly prices for some of the pre-orders. Yes, they were offering pre-orders for a game that wasn't finished, based on an RPG that wasn't finished. Would it be a repeat of Neverwinter Online again? No thanks, but I'm keeping my money.

Over the past year, every few months, I would check up on Sword Coast Legends' development. I read about the companions, then the few plot hints that were teased, and then I watched videos of the game, as well as Twitch VODs. It wasn't until around September 11, 2015 that I actually pre-ordered the game. In comparison, my SwordCoast.com account was registered on February 26, 2015, and that was only so I could ask questions about the game on the forums.

Even then, I got it for $26.79 at a third-party site, which is close to what I might pay for it during a Steam Sale. Actually, I might've come out ahead, as I like the game, and I will be getting the Rage of Demons expansion for free.

Pros:

1. Well-written, well-acted companions. None of them are walking stereotypes, and they are all multidimensional characters with hidden depths. I particularly like how none of the wizard companions are in it for the sake of knowledge/science/magic/Mystra/whatever, and actually adventure for more practical purposes. Of the many companions, the two wizards the only ones who talk like real people. Hommet sounds like a real person and not a fictional fantasy character. Soronil talks in a more dramatic fashion compared to Hommet, but is the closest to how a real person talks (there's that hint of of tiredness and slight lack of seriousness in Soronil's voice that makes him seem more real).

2. A lot of the combat can be bypassed through stealth or diplomacy or money or even through previous gameplay choices. Surprisingly, combat takes up a shorter amount of time compared to exploration and social interaction in Story Mode. Then again, I tried to avoid combat as much as possible. It's refreshing to see thugs let you pass when you pay their toll instead of trying to rob you anyway.

3. No filler. Do you hate games where most of your time is spent fighting irrelevant monsters in a dungeon that never seems to end? In that case, SCL is for you. When an NPC told me that I would be teleporting to the final area, I expected a large megadungeon with multiple levels and countless monsters. Instead, I get teleported to the final boss and his minons immediately and then we fight after a rather short pre-fight trash talk.

4. No forced companions. While the Story Mode workaround for mandatory companions feels cheesy, the item does exist in D&D, specifically in the Eberron Campaign Setting. You can choose the party that you want without missing any mandatory dialogue.

5. Each ability score is used in dialogue. There is no god stat like Charisma because the other stats also come into play. In fact, Charisma sometimes gives a lesser reward compared to the Intelligence or the Wisdom option, as being persuasive doesn't always replace knowledge or experience in real life.

6. There are a lot of references to D&D lore, especiall Forgotten Realms lore. Lore buffs who can get past the game's arcade-like combat will love all the overt and subtle lore references.

Cons:

1. Lost all of my achievements during the Headstart. I had all of the companion achievements as well as numerous campaign achievements. The only ones I didn't get (other than the Dungeon Crawl and Dungeon Master achievements) were the one where you maxed out in one class, maxed out in all classes, and finished the game with every race and class.

2. Performance is choppy in many areas. Also, for some reason, Shadowplay's FPS counter doesn't show up in Sword Coast Legends. I can feel how low my FPS is, but I can't tell because the FPS counter doesn't show up. I might have to use the Steam FPS counter, though.

3. There are several stability issues. During my first run through Story Mode, I crashed around 5 times. That's really not bad compared to some other games out there, but I'd prefer no crashes instead.

4. DM tools are extremely limited compared to whatever tools were made to create Story Mode. The DM tools and the DM client let you play Diablo-lite with a DM. There is no dialogue editor in the DM tools, and you are limited to We accept!" and "Not right now." This is quite jarring after having played Story Mode since it gives you so much more freedom and so much more dialogue options.

5. This is a D&D game

reviewText:
A really nice game if you like Dungeons & Dragons  based games.

I have played some of them:

- PlaneScape Torment
- Icewind Dale : Enhanced Edition.
- Icewind Dale 2 : Complete Edtition.
- Baldur's Gate : Enhanced Edition.
- Baldur's Gate 2 : Enhanced Edition.
- Neverwinter Nights : Diamond Edition.
- Neverwinter Nights 2 : Complete Edition.

And i loved them all in their particular ways.
And now i can add this game to the list.

About this game.
This game has no exceptions, i loved every detail in it's own way.

- The story is complete and well executed within the game.
- The characters are each balanced and interesting in their way.
- The combat system could be a tad better with more options.
- The enemies are balanced for each difficulty setting, i like that a lot.

The only thing i see that they were missing is that the game are way to short.
But i guess that's because they want to release DLC:s over time for players to buy,
their way of earning some money, right?

Anyway, the game is a catch, just reel in and you are in for a feast!
Buy it and have some fun.

reviewText:
Lets start with something very simple and clear: THIS IS NOT BALDUR'S GATE 3!
With that off the board, I'll start by saying that, while this is not a perfect digital version of 5e, it is a very good D&D game by itself.

Combat is top down real time, just as in, well, Baldur's Gate; you can even pause it.
There is a story mode for those who dared buy the game alone (aka Those who went against the tide of people, sometimes friends, saying this game is crap)
There's an online mode, for adventuring with random ppl
And there's a DM mode, where anyone can publish a self made adventure with a quite big array of tools (except for quest objectives, but the three default available ones quite suffice)

Did they add the 5e rules?
Yes and No

During character creation, you get to choose some of the book's races and classes (the most basic ones, like humans and paladins, while the most complex ones, like Draconates and Warlocks were left out, probably for the time being)
Those races have the racial variants
Feats were not employed, since, as of 5e, they're optional
Skills were reduced to 2 (Lockpick and Spot, which are the most important ones for this kind of game; Survival, Knowledges and the sorts are flavorful, but compared to those two, they're optional at best, both in the digital and the PnP versions)

Now
All the hatred apparently gravitates towards one thing about the game, and spreads to everything else due to blind rage

The Ability Tree

So, instead of the by-level system of unlocking new class features that is present in the PnP version, they opted into a more customizable way of class advancement: an Ability Tree, which also encompasses weapon and armor proficiencies, as well as the level of your character's Lockpick and Spot skills.

Different? Yes, but its a virtual game, based on a very loose system intended to be less restrictive

Also, there is no mention to dice rolls whatsoever, which may be considered offgame" to some; and I havent seen "save rolls" so far (but those must be hidden
date: like the supposed dice rolls)\n\nI am yet to try the coop gameplay
recommended: as I am one of the "against the tide" people

which may come with a surprisingly new quest for you.

tl;dr
Game is good

reviewText:
Its Not Baldur's Gate, Its not Neverwinter Nights, its not Icewind Dale. Those were absolute classics, based on D&D rulesets but not exact transpositions of P&P D&D. So is this game.

Single Player:
I know many will disagree with me but this game's atmosphere, music and combat is actually very D&D like, not really too much like a Diablo style ARPG. The story reminded me much about Neverwinter Nights with its locations and factions, the combat is very Icewind Dale like in which it is based on perfectly gearing and building your party up to the point its an unstoppable killing machine, the characters (party companions and NPCs) resemble a bit of Baldur's Gate in which they voice opinions, give quests and personality (some of your party members may dislike other party members for example, and they do make it very apparent, although they never leave the party like in BG).

Multiplayer:
I love Dungeon Crawl, the loot, the fights, the progression, the exploration inducing quests. Its fun alone or with a party of friends, but it really shines when you get a DM, its like your own undiscovered adventure and playing with someone you cant predict is the most fun and challenging any D&D videogame has ever been for me.
Cant say I have played a great deal of Modules, but the ones I did play (were recommended to me) are fantastic. This is the place where this game was meant to shine. From well written (player and D&D fan written) stories, to complex battles which can spike in difficulty when playing with a DM, Modules offer something for everyone and Im even considering building some myself (if I find the time, jobs take a lot of it).

Negative:
People complain about the lack of features, and they have to, there is still a lot missing. There is also the problem of stacking item effects, wich can make even a pathetically built character a single player powerhouse.
That being said, the game is still being updated and will recieve DLCs later on, which (like in Neverwinter Nights expansions) will open up the game much more and introduce more options to all players (adventurers and DM).

All in all:
This game is definetly worth its price, if N-Space solves the stacking issue it will even shine among other great D&D videogames of the past. I wholeheartedly recommend this.

reviewText:
This is difficult to review. First of all, i am a bit biased, since i crave Roleplaying games of all kinds and generally view them favorably just for being RPG.

Also, i am a seasoned Pen and Paper RPG Veteran with more than 35 years of experience as Player and DM.

My oppinion of this game is mixed, and here is why:

First of all, it is a decent, wellmade RPG, with slightly dated graphics, a simplified module editor and a 'random dungeon generator' that allows nearly endless replayability.

It has a well thought out multiplayer component that is fun to play and very enjoyable.

The campaign is very well written as far as i played it, and it reminds me a lot of classic NWN1 and NWN2 campaigns.

If my review would end here the game would recieve a very high score, somewhere between 8/9 out of 10.

BUT, and here is what many people criticize, and what also makes my rating go down quite a bit:
The game is not what it says it would be. It is not, as it says, and not even CLOSE to being a 5E adaptation. It is indeed a game that plays in the Forgotten Realms and uses the well known Attribute scores, races (not all of them) and classes (not all of them) we all know and love from D&D. This is already where it ends. It has no advanced and/or prestige classes, no skill system whatsoever, it does not at all use the magic system and instead is based upon a skilltree. There is no resting in any form, and no crafting.

Another point going against it is the very limited editor. While it works great in creating random dungeons, that is also its greatest flaw. It is not an editor per se, it only generates random dungeons which you then can modify. No building dungeons or maps step by step.


Conclusion:
SCL is a very enjoyable game with a great campaign.

It is NOT in any way shape or form, a 5E D&D adaptation.

Still, if you forget what this game is supposed to be, and take it for what it is, you will enjoy it.

On a base of 1 to 10 i give this game a 7.

reviewText:
This game is a good game solo fun with friends ad even better with a good DM. This game can feel like D&D with a good DM and the right module. The game play is more polished than the HS and shows promise for what the devs are doing in the future. The game is ment to be played with five people, 1DM and 5 players.

The DM aspect makes this game shine, alowing for multiple different outcomes in questlines. You want to kill the family that you just found food for?.... ok. The DM tools are limited with a limited mind, it takes some tweaking but anything is possible with the right imagination.

Most of the complaints that people have will be patched in the future. The devs hear what we have to say and want to the game more enjoable for us. Custom dungeon maps, more races/classes, more quest options, more DM tools and so on. They have already fix most of it anyways. Remeber its a video game not pnp, you will never get the true D&D feel in a video game.

Great game with great replay value. You just need friends.

reviewText:
First off I got this game without crazy expectations, it looked good and did remind me of games like Baldur's Gate or any other D&D game that came out some years ago. Now I see tons of reviews from people complaining that it isn't what was promised and doesn't meet their expectations, honestly I'm not sure what they were expecting because in my case I liked what I received.

Sword Coast Legends isn't a pure D&D game sticking to the rules of the table game, it's more arcadish and has a character building system that works with skill trees like you would find in Hack and Slash games like Diablo.

The Graphics are not stellar but do look good and offer a good camera control all around, zoom in-out and full 3d rotation with free cam that can be set on the character or just wandering around the map. There are a few glitches that I could notice like capes going thru the character models but other than that it's pretty well done and has nice Eye Candy effects for things like Flaming Swords and Spells. The Fighting system is pretty simple, you choose who or what to attack and select skills as you go and the rest of the party does the same on it's own with a decent AI. It's also possible to control every party character actions and pause to select each action but I personally went with the Hack and Slash style of playing.

The Story is great, I'm not that far into the game but I'm intrigued to know more and discover how the whole scenario develops. Side quests are easy to keep track on since they show on the side of the screen and update on the fly with each step you take on them.

As for Audio I like the Music and the Voice-Acting is pretty well done, it doesn't offer that many different voice options for your own characters but it ain't that bad. One thing that can be annoying is your character replying to every move command you give to it, not sure that was necessary.

I think the end result could be better, but as it just came out I have hope that the Devs will keep working on it and make it better with time. They say more classes and races will be brought into the game but what is not said is if those will be directly included in the game or if we'll have to purchase DLCs for them. One thing is certain this game will have some content DLCs coming our way later on, it needs them to stay alive.

I didn't use the Dungeon Master part of the game, I mainly played it as a single-player so far, but I like the idea that I could play it with friends and a DM controlling the action. I'm not gonna say much more about that since I didn't really experience it but one thing is.. I would have liked the game to have some SteamWorks integration so that Adventures created by other users could be shared easily thru it.

The game could be better but it does offer plenty of nice Questing hours for the price tag it's offered under. I would describe it as a Baldur's Gate" meets "Diablo" kind of game. Hopefully it will only get better in time
date: but as of now I already consider it's worth the price asked for it and is an easy grab if it ever hits a 50%+ sale.\n\nOverall I would give the game a 7/10 for now."

reviewText: So I've spent a bit of time playing this game in single player mode.  I came up in PC games playing Baldurs Gate and have to say that this is the type of game I enjoy.  Is it as good as Baldur's Gate? No, but it is close.  If you like a bread and butter cRPG, without the necessity of playing online like WoW, or having to spend real money to get good gear like Neverwinter, then this is the game for you.   There are a few options I haven't explored, DM, Co-Op, etc., but those really aren't my thing anyways. Graphically, it is pretty decent.  The story and NPC companions depth is kind of lacking, which is really where it lacks compared to Baldur's Gate and why I say it's not as good.  All in all, it's fun and I've enjoyed playing it.

reviewText:
21 hours but I'm guessing I've only seen, at most, one fifth of this game.

Just wanted to get a word in here right now that my time spent so far has been really enjoyable.

I saw mention from a Gamespot review claiming the combat was too simple but they must've patched since then because I've had to stay on top of the pause button.

In some ways this reminds of the MMO Neverwinter but everything is more compact both game-world wise and aesthetically.

Maybe not as sophisticated as Dragon Age; I would say that Sword Coast is a highly polished and meaty Confrontation" featuring the TSR world and lore.

What has sold me is that there is a lot here for those who like to explore for out of the way secrets and oddities which the game world is chock full of. There's also a keen attention to detail; every piece of new armour you find and every weapon reflects on your character in game when equipped. As example I've just flushed out the Graveyard section of the first (and maybe only?) town you enter and came out with a Jack-O-Latern mask which I fit on my short and plump dwarven fighter as well a skeleton mask for the necromancer.

If you're an attention deficit completionist who slaps on every wall in a video game looking for hidden rooms then Sword Coast will keep you content for a long while.

Currently no DLC and I believe that is because there are many free downloadable mini expansion campaigns made both by the developers and end users.

You can level up in these side campaigns and then run back to the main story with your new loot if  having difficulties.

I got SC for $25 from a recent sale. It's the fist time in a long while that I've spent this much money for one game and I found it well worth the price to boot."

reviewText:
its ok, It not what i was looking for from a D&D title. im a bit disapointed in it. I wouldnt spend more then $5-$10 on it if your looking to buy the game. I might enjoy it more if I paid less for it, ( i paid $20) but the game vs the cost just dont seem to be worth it.

others might like it,

It lacks alot of my favorite classes from D&D, and there is no utility to the classes.
the quests are linear. for example the quest to save or kill the dog at the beggining of the game. I didnt even have a chane to save the dog because my stats where not high enough to succeed the conversation. in D&D even if i have  ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stats, i could still roll high and succeed. this game has no rolls, just hard break points on your stats to determine success. that is lame to me. I decided to just leave the dog alive, then later i found out the caravan leader just came over and killed the dog anyway. I should have just been able to kill the halfling that was accusing the dog, and make up some lie obout how he was some evil hobit that had something against dogs.

I cant pickpocket the vendors if i want to. or i feel there should be the freedom to just kill the vendors and take their stuff. (obviously the vendors would fight back or be hard to kill but the option should be there.

the draw of D&D is to play the game the way you want to and face the consequences of your actions if you decide to play more evil ( or if your good get away with it). this just dosent exist in this game.

TLDR = No freedom of choice in the game = not D&D

reviewText:
If u looking for a normal ARPG with some D&D element, this game would be good for u.

But you will get disappointed when u are looking for a game like Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Night.

Yes, i only played for a short time. And these are what i have seen in a short game play:

Negativ Points:
- No Spell Book.
- Wizard can't learn new Spell from Scrolls.(No scribe scroll feature for Wizard)
- No Schools for magics.
- No Magical Feats.
- Lack of choice im Skills.
- Lack of choice im Feats.

Positive Points:
- Yeah! Every Magical Classes in this game are now able to cost unlimited spells every day! Warlock are going to be jobless xD
- Graphic is obsolutly better than NWN, BG and other D&D games.

At least, it is not a good game for me, as I am a fan of Wizard, and this game don't have the most features of wizard. The only thing is...yes, wizard can cast spells, nothing more.

reviewText: This is an agressively mediocre game. The voice acting is only partly acted and when it is, it is usually with a dreadful, annoying accent. Combat is fussy and half the time the abilities doesn't do what they say or just plain doesn't seem to work (Charge in particular was weird, randomly charging in a wrong direction). In multiplayer, the lack of pausing makes combat a big mess and a waste of your time.\nThe worst part though, is pretending to be a DnD game. Aside from the names of the classes,races and abilities it bears no similarities to the beloved Roleplaying Game and the engine behind (Much better) games such as Neverwinter Nights, Baldur's Gate or Planescape Torment. Pillars of Eternity is more of a DnD game than this one.\n2/10.

reviewText:
Unlike D&D 5th edition they have a point buy system at character creation. You are not allowed to roll for your stats. Also the character editor is lackluster. Body type, facial construction and other options are very lack luster. I've seen better character customizers in other games both single player and MMO.

Some quests in the game are broken like the one right outside of Luskan with the two quarreling people about becoming a pirate. You complete the quest and yet a quest marker still exists over the peoples head.

Skill trees for classes also are not great. In 5th edition for the rogue at certain levels you gain certain skills automatically. In this game you have to buy your way to them with skill points which makes it even harder to play that class.

I greatly prefer the actual 5th edition game.

If you are looking for something that is just a jump in and play this is for you. If you are looking for a real transference of game to video game this is not.

I only suggest buying this when it is on sale for like 5 dollars or less.

reviewText:
SCL is a great DnD 5e-based game. I would have liked however a bit more depth in the implementation of the rules. For example immersive concepts such as food, resting and exhaustion are missing. Also would have been nice to provide more transparency on the attack/ability check/saves dice rolls.

Anyway :) I enjoy this game a lot and I believe that saying SCL is >>not<< DnD is wrong. DnD can have many flavors - it can be anything from pure role playing to throwing a d20 for any possible interaction. I see DnD as an extensible framework - and SCL is just one of the things one can build upon this framework.

Awesome guys, keep up the good work. And let's hope we'll soon be enjoying SCL on consoles too.

reviewText:
At its current state, just cannot recommend it. The DM tools are not very powerful but the campaign is decent.Really hoping they can iron out these issues in patches.
3/5 if you are looking for a single player campaign its pretty good.

Campaign: it isn’t very good to play coop but other than that is pretty good, you can read up on that from other people
*Whoever hosts has the only save file, and control over every NPC party member- you cannot share it.
*Any dialogue that any character has will show up on everyones screen taking control from them- so if you want to enter a shop, each person has to steal control for maybe 15s each time just to bring up the shop for everyone(host has dialog control over any story dialogue).
*mouse4 is bound to moving your camera and you cant rebind it in any way.

Mechanics
*Each turn is one second roughly, you can autopause after every turn or 10 turns or 5 turns, whatever
*it plays fine, too fast for my tastes but I just have it auto pause every 5 turns-
*tons and tons of magic items drop all the time, and no real way around this

DM tools-this is the big letdown
*no custom loot drops(players can exploit for their own gear by having high level characters drop for them)
*no custom monster sets(you can get around this by manually making every creature as a “character” but it is tedious)
*no DM buff/debuff of characters
*no in game mechanics that don’t directly deal with combat(skill checks, jumping, puzzle solving)

There really isn’t anything you can do that isn’t combat- you can pause the game and call for skill checks and put in your little dudes accordingly, but it requires you to go out of the game and isn’t integrated into the DM tools. I can be playing with friends in call of duty and have a complex metagame that determines what weapons people use, doesn’t make CoD a roleplaying game.


DLC:
I have always known it would be reliant on DLC, and depending on how they do it, could be fine or could be ridiculous.

If they end up having it like Magma caves of C'thun Expansion" where the paid expansion has extra class/races/skill trees
date: etc-players get some content for free and extras like classes and skill trees(or the other way around
recommended: the monsters and tilesets) you need to buy-that is cool and I am all for that. Not everyone can play in magma lands
hoursPlayed: but hey its not like thats a core place for an adventure like "The woods" or "A City" is. Also depends on price."

reviewText:
If you want an entertaining 40-60 hour long story set in the beloved Forgotten Reams and you want to hack and slash your way through random generated dungeons with a few of your friends while manipulating the playing field through the DM client, then this game does a good job of that. It really does.

If you want to have the power to build an in depth story or recreate any of your favorite table top modules, it does not do a very good job of that. Not at all.

If you are looking for the next NWN tool set, this is not it.

Buy the game for the story, it's worth the initial price tag IMO, but I would wait if you want to build modules until they patch it up or release a few DLCs to give creators more tools to work with.

One last note: I logged 200 hours through the head start, most of which in the tool set trying to make it work like it wasn't intended. While you can create modules for others to play, the limitations of tiles, assets and monsters will make a lot of the modules look the same.

reviewText:
My biggest problem with this game is that it is bears the D&D name, while it has almost nothing to do with any kind of D&D ruleset.
Yes, it's set in Forgotten Realms.
Yes, it has spell/feat/monster/item names taken from D&D.
But that is all the resemblance.
Many things were um...borrowed from older cRPGs, like Baldur's Gate (like the blacksmith who can make you some magic items from its pieces if you found them), but many good cRPG elements were totally ignored.

Pro: - many minor items created (useless ones, but they give the game some seasoning)
- more or less smart character AI, when not user-controlled
- some ability score related tests in dialogs for faster/easier quest-solution
- cool snowy effects in Luskan :)
- Evermoors area is really great: you can get lost even with the help of the map  (ADDED: 10th Nov)

Contra: - cooldown system for abilities -> not D&D at all
- no multiclass (OK, I'm not yet familiar with D&D 5th ed, but come on...)
- endless sea of magic items, making mundane items useless junk
- level scaling enemies (9th level fighter has ~90HP, while a simple skeleton has like 300HP due to scaling)
- all abilities/spells are combat related only (persuasion/pickpocket/bluff/etc?)
- legendary D&D monsters made ridiculous (lich gets defeated by a 6th level party? Come on...)
- illogical item balancing (light armor gives huge bonus to DEX, while it has a huge limitation to max DEX bonus ... huh? )
- Single Player quests are created for kindergarteners
- not many side-quests in Single Player -> obviously the game was not developed for Single Player
- you can loot someone's personal chest in their home without consequences
- no item creation/customization
- Rogue class is totally unnecessary (anyone can learn disable device and search)
- Rogue can go in Sneaking even while in melee with enemies, and can even Sneak attack
- break barrels for looting -> this was such a stupid idea to implement into the game...old ARPG ♥♥♥♥
- illogical loot: kill a rat (not a giant one), get a whole suit of magical heavy armor
- no character interaction, every companion like the other one, no small-battles, etc.
- Invisibility spell is in Transmutation category?! :) :) (couldn't skip it...I'm a too rigid D&D player)
- oh, and one more minor thing: bugs bugs bugs bugs...2 weeks after release, and there have already been 3 patches (introducing new bugs too of course)

If it was a simple RPG without calling it D&D, I would not be so critical. But I wouldn't have preordered the game either then.

reviewText:
First i would like to add that i first played this at PAX. then seeing that it was free i figured i would give it a try again. I will buy it,

The game is great to play, it feels like a half Balur's Gate/Neverwinters Night and half Table top Dungeons and Dragons game. The solo story is good brings back memories of old DnD games. Below i will list some pros and cons:

Pros:
- Good Initial story to get you into the the gameplay.
- Great character customization system.
- Voice acting is about average for what you would expect other than a couple lines here and there.
- Very DnD feel with interacting with object in the main story such as bashing vines but not having enough strength.
- In depth DM tools, still need some work but great for creating fast campaigns for new players.

Cons
- Single player combat can be a bit janky due to the multiplayer focus the and the AI not being able to be tweaked to use some spells over others. (Considering my first experience with the game revolved around multiplayer this was not unexpected.)
- Setting up of your Skill bar is very clunky, it will auto-populate with everyting from scolls to potions and removing the objects from your bar will cause your character to use it instead of just removing it from the bar. (This could be easily fixed by adding a lock option..)
- Characters will run to an enemy over casting the spell causing you to have to issue a move command each time before casting if using a melee weapon.


Overall for being a new attempt at an idea I'd say its a solid 7.5/10 with some improvements the game could be fantastic i would recommend.

Some final notes I would suggest if you buy the game to play with a group to get the full expirience of the game and what it was mean't for i understand the negative reviews but after hearing the dev's talk at PAX i pretty much knew what to expect and i feel they nailed that pretty well.

reviewText:
A good game but far from perfect. Ideally this should be played with a friend as the idea of the game is to mimic the socialness of a D&D game, the module creator and DM mode being the prime examples.

Character creation is fun and although it feels there is a lack of classes, it is easy to make an interesting character with plenty of ability trees to pick from so you can specialise or pick and choose. Some complain about the abilities being on a cooldown, but I feel as though this lends itself to the game well as you still need to pick a good time to use them, not every encounter requires their use and, importantly, it keeps the flow of the game going. There are many interesting weapons and armour in the game which can suit many playstyles so whatever weapons you prefer there will always be some of those.

The story is nothing impressive as it follows a typical-ish D&D plot. There are plenty of quests to do, though some of which can be difficult to follow. The voice acting is good but no characters really make an impression but all companions have a fairly fleshed out backstory, each with their own quest to compliment it. The dungeons are well planned, with a few puzzles and plenty of secrets and traps. Overall, dungeon crawling is the strong point of the game and hacking and slashing through them is great with a friend.

reviewText: This game feels like something between dungeon siege and dragon age. If you play table top DnD, you will notice that this is not 5 edition, The hit dice, damage and thaco/profireci system is same, but Skill system is like in dragon age. So is this ♥♥♥♥? No, the system is waay weaker than that in Dungeons and dragon (for example neverwinter nights 2, BG 2 and so on), but it is waay better than what we see in Dragon age 2 and 3. As for story, its solid and game play is solid too. Havent tryed DM mode, but i like this game a lot so its up for me.\nJust dont believe the hype, this is not DnD simulator. Its Dungeon siege (Game play would be like original Neverwinter nights, but RPG system is streamlined so hard, i cant compare) like RPG, set in DnD world.\nIf you wana this, you will like this game. If you wana Old school RPG, go for pillars of ethernity.

reviewText:
This game is thoroughly enjoyable with a solid, friendly community base. The story mode is well written, reasonably voice acted and engaging.

However - this is not a D&D system game. It's got familiar looking mechanics and ability names, but the 'inspired' in their claim that the game is inpsired by 5th ed D&D is very much the operative word.

Once you get past that what you've got is a brawler that is fast-paced, easy to digest and with the option of cranking the difficulty right up. Pure win, if you ask me. The campaigns I've sampled seem pretty good and range from 'dungeon crawl plus' to 'book in game form,' so lots of variety.

The extra tileset in the deluxe content is pretty cool, but I'm not sure that it justifies the money. The extra gear is also nice but not essential.

TL;DR: get the norm version. Get over that it's not D&D and you'll have fun.

reviewText:
I went into this game looking for a D&D game.

This game does not follow the D&D ruleset.  This game has a very distant relationship with D&D mechanics.  This is not a D&D based game.

Once you get beyond this not being a D&D game then the game itself is.... messy.  All of the bits and pieces of the game (story, modules, multiplayer, game mastering, gameplay, setting, sound, etc) just do not mesh.  The game is lacking the element that would make it good and enjoyable.  As it is it is more clunky and mired in not knowing what it wants to do.

There is some enjoyment in building overpowered characters if you enjoy that so maybe the game is worth it at 90% off or so.

reviewText:
The game is...alright, it's a watered down NWN...and while I felt Neverwinter was watered down a tad much for me, I still enjoyed it overall.

UI could use work as well, numbers are too small when you deal/take damage so you don't really get a good sense of the battle and who's really winning outside of a sliding bar for HP...hell, everything is too small.

Story could try to be less predictable as well. Over half the time I was just going Let me guess..." and being correct so many times brought be right out of the experience. I suppose player made modules would help with this issue...but you kind of expect more from the developer in terms of story and world building.

Not to mention the game seems to hate NVidia. Don't know how or why you would do that...load times are HORRID! The game after a while just straight up stopped wanting to load
date:

reviewText:
Having played this game on Mac during a free weekend I can say with absolute certainty that I will not be buying it.

My wife and I both downloaded it, her on a Windows 10 PC and me on my iMac.  We intended to play the story mode together in co-op.

The user interface is poorly designed and buggy.  The entire process of starting the game & signing up was far too convoluted and when I actually did get to play the game I found I was unable to invite my wife to the game.

I later discovered through an obscure redit post that you have to complete the first mission" before you can invite others to your game.  Fair enough
date:
but would be nice if the game actually told you that rather than simply disabling the invite button!

Once my wife and I did get into game together we found the way that conversation had been done to be incredibly jarring.  Having recently been playing Divinity: Original Sin the notion of having my game stop me from acting while I'm forced to watch/listen to dialogue that my wife is engaged in is ludicrous.  In divinity it gives you the option to listen in if you want to but doesn't stop you from going about other business while one player talks to some NPC's.

Tactical pause not being available in co-op is a terrible omission... especially for players who would be on voice chat or in the same room while co-op'ing.

Overall I found the user interface/experience to be severely lacking and the story & game its self lackluster at best.  Feels more like an attampt to make some quick money than a serious attempt at a D&D game."

reviewText:
This game may not be an accurate representation of 5e, but it sure is a lot of fun.

As a fan of games like Baldur's Gate and Dragon Age: Origins, I found the single-player gameplay decent, though not fantastic--I'm big on micro-managing characters in party-based games, and this game doesn't really give any control to what your characters do when you're not actively controlling them, unlike the amazing tactics menu in Dragon Age: Origins. I haven't played enough of the story to truly comment on it, though it seems interesting enough from what I've seen.

Where this game shines is in multiplayer, especially if you can get a full party of four. You no longer have to worry about the AI doing stupid things (rather, you worry your friends will do stupid things hahaha!), and it's just a blast running around killing oozes and whatnot. One complaint would be that the dialogue system is a bit of a pain in multiplayer; whenever someone initiates a conversation, it interrupts everyone else and forces them to watch the convo. I'd prefer if it worked more like Divinity: Original Sin, where the dialogue would just be in a box on the side of the screen so you can read it but still do your own thing.

Other than that though, this game is really, really fun with friends, and I would recommend it to anyone who's looking to chill with their D&D party outside of actual D&D sessions.
voteText: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you do not go into this game expecting the second coming of Baldur's Gate then it is actually really decent.

Pros:

+ Fantastic classic fantasy D&D atmosphere
+ Very nice art direction and pleasing visuals
+ Great musical soundtrack
+ Character creation is a lot of fun
+ Motivating character development
+ Really nice special effects (spells etc.) which reflect character advancement
+ Feels like a nice epic journey from act 2 onwards
+ Nice choice of companions for different party compositions

Cons:

- So much wasted potential... I'm a single player guy and can only dream how awesome this game could have become if the focus would have been 100% on the SP
- A very slow start to the story. It gets better later on but it should have been more motivating in the early stages.
- Fairly boring side quests for the most part. Some good ones but the majority was mediocre.
- The game is way too easy on normal difficulty. There were only about a handful of encounters that required any kind of serious micromanagement.
- Very linear ... a little more freedom in where to go next or what to do next would have been nice
- In the same vein it would have been great to have more choices and alternatives in solving quests
- Backtracking sucked - There should have been more fast travel options especially near the end of dungeons
- Quest descriptions and map markers could have been more clearly and more consistent
- Poor pathfinding at times
- Some annoying bugs (nothing game-breaking but annoying nonetheless)
- Many more small issues that just made you painfully aware how great this game could have been with a little more attention to detail and more focus on the SP campaign.

All in all I would still recommend this game to any fan of classic D&D fantasy CRPGs. In spite of its shortcomings, this is an overall fun enough experience with addictive qualities during its better parts.

reviewText:
I’m not sure what all the fuss is about because I'm having a lot of fun with this game. I'm glad I was able to finally start playing it. I haven't gotten real far yet so my opinion is still subject to change.

I ran into one head scratching issue with commanding my chars in battle but nothing I would classify as problematic. It appears it was mostly due to my wanting to multi-stack commands and not understanding how that part works.

I have had no technical problems and no crashes on three separate machines and a VM that I used. The performance wasn’t great on the VM or the old laptop but that was to be expected. All still very playable once adjusted to fit the hardware specs.

I don’t recall any bugs but I really wasn’t looking.

From a good old gamer’s point of view – above average. I can easily recommend this game to players that enjoy the genre, have a little patience and don’t take the little things too seriously.

reviewText: Really enjoyed this game. Played solo and will look at multiplayer and DM in future. The style of this reminds me very much of Temple of Elemental Evil but with the new DnD ruleset. The story is very interesting. I was pleasantly surprised by the size of the adventure, thou it is by no means massive, it was certainly fair. I thought the graphics were good, not great. The combat was good for me but I admit to laziness in trying various pause settings which has caused me a little grief. Party control is reasonable but occassionally clunky. Overall I give this game an 8.5/10 and look forward to more adventures on the Sword Coast!

reviewText:
First off you may be confused by the low scores granted this game from other users.  I wonder if a majority have even played through Sword Coast Legends as I have.  What gripes most as you will read is that although this game is based off Dungeon and Dragons, the games rules system is not.  This game plays more like a Dragon Age/Diablo than say a Temple of Elemental Evil (3.5 rule set).  This is my major dislike as well as I have with this game.  To not recommend this game though is a bit on the spoiled gamer era we live in.  Not to give this game a chance is a shame.  Now to the listing of my Pro's and Cons.  Keep in mind this is from the original campaign,  I haven't tinkered with the DM client, or Multiplayer to comment on it.

Pros: The Graphics are beautiful to behold from a top down game.   The soundtrack reminded me of Neverwinter Nights 1 & 2.  The voice acting was surprisingly good all around.  All characters were well thought out with a believeable backstory.  *My favorite was a certain insane derro you stumble upon!*

The Bad:  The Save games, you only have one save game, with another option of  default" load which puts you at the beginning of a level(Possiblity of Hours of Lost Progress!).   Monster Difficulty
date: Don't be too despaired by the one save game option due to the fact that you rarely get the Total Party Kill in this game on normal difficulty or below. Rulesets. PLEASE!!!  If I wanted to play Dragon Age
recommended: or Diablo I would buy those games.  If I buy a Dungeon and Dragon game I want a Dungeon and Dragons RULE SET.\n\nFinal Thoughts:   Take the other negative reviews with a grain of salt
hoursPlayed: this game is not buggy and runs well.  Yes the rule set component of this game severely drags it down for me and others but not to the point where I would not recommend it.  Come for the Story

reviewText: My primary interest in this game was the ability to create adventures.  From my exploring it, here's the downside- the editor is feature limited.  It would be nice to be able to give specific/custom items and use them to drive quests, and also to be able to do some minor story branching based on actions/decisions of the players, but at this point you can't (at least I haven't figured out where/how).  But here's where I believe the editor really excells-  Once you learn how it works, it does an amazing job in my opinion of producing a basic stage upon which to write an adventure.  It automates things that can be very time consuming and tedius, to the point I fatigued/timed out in editors like Neverwinter's before I ever got very far.  Sword Coast Legends' editor automatically generates environments and sets encouters in them, including placing a boss in the last room of a dungeon if you so choose.  Putting together basic quests is also incredibly simple as it automates 90% of the work in a go kill this" "go collect these" or "kill the boss" quest.  And you can tweak things from there.  While the editor has only a fraction of the feautres of Neverwinters
date: it can (at least by my estimates) produce a basic game world in about 5% of the time.  And while D&D purists probably scorn it's simplicity- for the hardcore
recommended: a live dungeon master can do things an editor never could.\n\nBottom line- I'm happy to support these guys
hoursPlayed: and hope they continue to develope its capabilities.  I think the intelligence and automation they've built into the editor's basic assembly process is a significant leap forward in editor abilities
voteText: and I believe will set a new standard others will follow."

reviewText:
I really like this game and the potential it has.

I played the campaign and I enjoyed it but that's not what this is all about. I mostly got this game for co-op multiplayer fun. Players can create their own story/modules so others can play, be it as normal characters or as a DM.

You can just dungeon crawl but since all fun comes with the story I strongly suggest  that you pay attention to each module's story and even roleplay.

I agree this isn't another Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale game. Many things are different. Get this game if you really enjoy story based play. Gather your friends and have fun. It's all up to you.

Also, devs appear to listen and I have faith in them.

reviewText: I dont feel like I have scratched the surface yet, but I really enjoy this game so far. Usually this type of gameplay just isn't all that very fun to me. Sword Coast Legends has a great story to play if you are alone and want a nice world to explore. It get way more fun when a few friends jump on. Friends can join your story mode, or you can choose from many different random dungeons quickly in a dungeon crawl mode with many different options to choose from. There's always the user created modules, which have the ability to be as big or bigger than the games own story mode. While playing with friends (or randoms) you can choose to play with a Dungeon Master. This brings a whole bunch more into the game, as you have a live person controlling the AI and story in real time. This is by far my favorite LAN party game of 2015. My absolute favorite feature: awesome Linux support. This game runs better in Arch Linux than it does in windows for me on ALL of my machines. Looking forward to diving in deeper.

reviewText:
This game had one of the hardest jobs in modern video gaming.  I am convinced that no matter how good it was at release, it was destined to be panned by its audience.

If you are coming into this expecting Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights, you will probably be disappointed.  And that's a damn shame, because Sword Coast Legends is a great game -- it's just not in the same genre as those old classics.  It most strongly resembles Bioware's Dragon Age, only with a camera locked in isometric view and no programmable AI.

As someone who could never get into Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights (or Dragon Age, for that matter), Sword Coast Legends is a perfect fit for me.  Yes, it is a lot more casual.  Yes, the D&D rules are heavily abstracted.  But when I'm barreling through the procedurally generated Dungeon Crawl mode with friends, it feels good.  It feels like playing D&D, which is always my most important litmus test for the success of one of these games.  The rules don't matter to me.  What matters is the experience, and for my money the D&D experience of Sword Coast Legends is excellent.

The game is not perfect.  It is a ten-year-old experience at least.  The graphics are attractive but not cutting edge, and the UI is uninspired.  The Dungeon Master toolset is casual, like the player experience, and this renders it useless for anything but the most simple linear stories.  That said, the developers have pushed a number of free patches since release that have made great improvements.

The potential for monetization of this title through microtransactions is obvious, and it will live or die based on how smart the publisher is about when they begin to implement paid DLC.  But right now, as far as I am concerned, the co-op campaign and Dungeon Crawl mode alone are worth the price of admission, hands down.

If you are a fan of the old isometric pause-and-play D&D games, I encourage you to approach Sword Coast Legends with an open mind and try to enjoy it as its own animal.  It is very different than those classic titles, but it is not necessarily a less fun experience.

reviewText:
Update: Look at all the free goodies in store for the game here:
https://forums.swordcoast.com/index.php?/topic/8042-sword-coast-legends-state-of-the-game/?p=78919#entry78919

I've played this game over 40 hours so far on pre-release, and plan to (re)play many more.

First things first: If you want a clone of Neverwinter Nights, Pillars of Eternity, Bauldur's Gate, or other D&D games, you should pass or do more research. It is D&D but modified. As a Neverwinter Night and cRPG fan,I had low expectations (from past experience with other games) but really love the game.

Some people have strict D&D expectations, and don't like it. Some are warming up to it.

Entertainment Value - 5 Stars

NOTE: This covers the single-player campaign and not DM mode.

Here is a list of things I comprised: (Not in order of importance)

1. Dungeon crawls are fun. Combat is just the right amount for those whom
don't want constant or grueling combat.

2. Trap detection actually works. Rogue skills/abilities are useful.
3. The laughs. (see below)
4. Abilities are just about right, requiring some managing and planning but not micromanaging trash mobs.
5. Smooth performance - Some have had issues, I haven't had any.
6. The story, I'm liking a lot so far (half-way point now)
7. The quests are at least average or better.
8. Voice work is decent. (correction) very good.
9. Companion comments.
10. Companion AI (and ability to turn it off)
11. The sound effects. (except when the summoned creature disappears/'dies-- poor thing)
12. Graphics are fitting and nicely done
date: also fit the mood of the game.\n13. Combat is fun and not a chore
recommended:
but not so easy to let it run on auto-pilot.
14. 360 degree view -- newer games in this genre don't always have this.
15. The loot descriptions.
16. Hunting/exploring to meet some objectives.
17. Being Waylaid!
18. Music is very nice - subdued but fitting and top notch.
19. Challenging mini-boss fights that do require more pausing and tactics.

The laughs -- things like getting my 20 STR character charmed and killing off the rest of my party

reviewText:
As of the writing of this review I have played 4.3 hours of the game outside of the beta and somewhere around 85 hours in the beta.

The main reason that there are so many negative reviews for this game are that a large number of the people who played this game expected it to be very similar to pen and paper D&D like Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale. It is not at all like those games but that doesn't mean it isn't very fun. With a good DM this game can be loads of fun for a party of up to 5 people (including the DM) and while the module creator could use some work it allows a lot of creativity and most of my play time has probably been spent in that creating my Summer's Fall module.

They have recently announced a number of planned free updates that will really bring life into this game like mod support and more objects and abilities so expect it to get a lot better by the end of the year. Also if anyone claims that it sucks because they promised it would be like Neverwinter Nights with the dungeon master mode don't listen to them as nowhere did anyone promise that it would be like Neverwinter. In fact I'm actually glad that it isnt because this is far easier to use and therefore more inviting towards new players.

Best bet to really enjoy this game is to think of it not as a D&D game but merely as a fun game within D&D's forgotten realms setting.

reviewText: I am only playing the game in signal player mode and have played the game about 30 hours during the free weekend offer. I am glad of the free weekend and half price offer as it helped me pull the trigger to purchase the game. This game seemed to be made to bring in D&D board game players into PC game play and maybe they’re the players who have been disappointed with the game and hence the reason for the mixed review of this game, but this is only speculation on my part as I have no date to back that up. Bottom-line: In my opinion if you liked playing games like Neverwinter, Pillars of Eternity, Dragon Age Origins you most likely will enjoy playing this game as well. This game also seems to have a lot of potential beyond the single player mode that I am playing and hope one day to find a group of casual gamers to check out the multi-player feature with.

reviewText:
Okay so I guess you are one of those clever players who is here checking for traps before you purchase right? Good for you! There is a lot of hate aimed at this game. I have only one personal neg: the first five minutes were not enjoyable, that being the tutorial dream sequence of the campaign with silly blurry effects whilst I was trying to find my feet. But then that nightmare ended, and all became coherent. The campaign is a little trite, but then the campaign is not the strong point of this game.

One of the main complaints aimed at this product is that it isn't true to D&D, nor can it compare to the tilset power of NWN. The thing is, if you want to play a game faithful to D&D, rules and all, just go play D&D. We already have D&D. Five editions of it, seriously: use Roll 20 or invite your mates over and have a game at the table. That's as D&D faithful as you're going to get! Want NWN with better graphics, fine, this isn't it, but this isn't a cheese burger either, and all the cheese burger lovers aren't on the forums ranting like drunk harpies.

Having said that, let's move on to the positives. If you like D&D, and you enjoy the Forgotten Realms setting, and you like a good dungeon crawl or narrative with a distinct D&D flavour, you will likley enjoy this game for what it is: D&D tropes with some lightweight dungeon design tools.

The free weekend gave me a chance to try this game for myself after reviews disuaded me from purchase prior to now; I now own the game. I particularly enjoy the elegant dungeon crawl generator, where one may stack level after random level and drop their character into the gloom. Looking forward to more content for this game as I currently explore the Module design tools - lightweight but fun and accessable thus far like the previously mentioned random dungeon crawls. Sword Coast Legends is fun and accessable and worth a look. Going by the forums, you've got a 50% chance of being charmed and a 50% chance of turning into a drunk harpy. Roll it.

reviewText:
8/10

This is an early impressions review, based on the single player campaign, not on the DM mode etc which I have yet to try. I will write more when I finish the game.

I am VERY surprised to read the negative feedback the game has garnered on steam and online, because I am really, really enjoying this! Its not technically astounding, nor does it push the envelope of what one expects from a CRPG , but so far, for me, this is the closest a high fantasy game has come to Baldur's Gate 2 (The high water mark for CRPGs, IMHO), and I am enjoying SCL more than highly rated games such as Divinity or Dragon Age. It is also better than the first Baldur's gate, or the Neverwinter nights games.

reviewText:
Update: Look at all the free goodies in store for the game here:
https://forums.swordcoast.com/index.php?/topic/8042-sword-coast-legends-state-of-the-game/?p=78919#entry78919

I've played this game over 40 hours so far on pre-release, and plan to (re)play many more.

First things first: If you want a clone of Neverwinter Nights, Pillars of Eternity, Bauldur's Gate, or other D&D games, you should pass or do more research. It is D&D but modified. As a Neverwinter Night and cRPG fan,I had low expectations (from past experience with other games) but really love the game.

Some people have strict D&D expectations, and don't like it. Some are warming up to it.

Entertainment Value - 5 Stars

NOTE: This covers the single-player campaign and not DM mode.

Here is a list of things I comprised: (Not in order of importance)

don't want constant or grueling combat.

reviewText:
I'm going to jump on the bandwagon and not recommend this game until several iterations have passed.  The principal problem with SCL is that it isn't finished in a fashion that we expected it to be.  The game plays a bit like Diablo and other ARPGs, but lacks due to the combat rounds which don't allow the characters to spam abilities or allow turned-based combat, which it desperately wants to be.

Little things like the inability to trade items among party members are maddening.  Sure, the solution is to drop things on the ground and pick them up, but this is a lack of foresight on the part of the developer that is astounding.  There seems to be a random assignment of loot that we still haven't been able to figure out.  It took us aver two hours to realize that there were options to disallow the auto-add to task bar, mostly because options seemed broken - if fact you change options before even entering the lobby.

I wanted to create a custom campaign, complete with an urban hub right from the start.  Yeah, that won't happen for a while.  When our full party of four has a player drop due to a disconnect we are forced to temporarily adopt an NPC and then save and exit.  This is extremely clunky for a 2015 game.  Further, as the host I have had a few instances where we do this gyration only for the client to freeze, which needs a Task Manager purge of the client.  Others have complained about frame rates, clipping, tearing, etc.  I can accept slightly off graphics - our players are in three states and two different countries - for a slick multi-player interface and execution.  This game fails at both.

reviewText:
Sword Coast Legends is a game that is fairly difficult for me to review. There's a few reasons for this, but allow me to explain myself here: I'm not a D&D fan, but I don't have anything against it. That being said, the game still looked interesting, so I figured it would be worth a try. Sword Coast Legends isn't this god-awful atrocity that should be avoided altogether, but I couldn't bring myself to really enjoy this game, and I found it pretty boring for the most part.

I would've given this game a neutral option if Steam had that with their reviews, but the negatives outweigh the positives here, so I had to go with the former as my opinion.

Graphics
The visuals aren't actually all that bad in my opinion. The game looks pretty, and although I don't think it's on par with something like Divinity: Original Sin, it still looks pretty nice. It captures the mood, and that's really all I can say. This one of the few things about the game I can tolerate.

Gameplay
This is where my mixed opinion truly comes into play. On one hand, I am a fan of the character creator, and the game is simple enough to attract newcomers (like myself) to D&D, but the combat is so mind numbingly boring. I understand it's a CRPG, but at least Divinity: Original Sin, Pillars of Eternity, and all of those other games have combat that is actually somewhat entertaining. The ability cooldown is really long for everything, so the fights with some of the easiest enemies can drag out, and I've had trouble trying to stay up for the entire duration of a battle. To add on to this, the campaign is linear, and rather than having these interesting dialogue choices and quests, you're given what is basically a generic RPG that will lose your attention unless you're a huge fan of D&D. As said before, however, the character creator is pretty good, and that will probably satisfy fans. It's simple, as well, and this is also a mixed bag in its own right. Being that simple does attract the newbies like myself, and it might get you into D&D. On the other hand, it is too simple to satisfy the hardcore fans, this also affects the dungeon editor, which felt disappointing to someone like me, who loves trying to express my, ehm, creativity."

Story
There's not much to say here. If you're a D&D fan

reviewText:
As a fan of crpgs and past D & D games (Baldur's Gate, Temple of Elemental Evil, Neverwinter Nights) I was really looking forward for a return to Faerun. I greatly enjoy any rpg with character creation, so Sword Coast Legends initially felt like a natural fit. Unfortunately, upon playing it was the very opposite.

I'll start with the worst of the worst and that's the camera, map, and interface itself. The mini-map is rather unhelpful, with just a bunch of purple dots hinting at *something* but no names or locales come up. Combine this with a rather rigid version of edge-scrolling and the busier locales over-cluttered with abandoned buildings and it just makes exploration feel more like a chore than an adventure. It doesn't exactly help when you've scrolled too far and can't even center the camera back on your party. Arrive in Luskan and you'll know what I mean.

Any dialogue, from a minor NPC sentence to visiting a vendor, all stops the game into a 'cutscene'. The transition feels sloppy, especially in comparison with the likes of Baldur's Gate and Pillars of Eternity, where the transition was more fluid. It doesn't help that the game itself is very sluggish to begin with, making even minor sequences aggravating.

The combat, put bluntly, is boring. You basically find yourself mashing skills in hopes of the enemy finally dying. It doesn't help that there are no AI tactics to assign (defensive, healing, support, tank) and you either have to 'pause and play', hoping your party doesn't get wiped out by the time you make your next move, or watch as the AI spits out random skills that may or may not help. To be fair the AI DOES seem to pick up on your skillset, so if you have a Paladin with healing skills, sometimes the AI will use them when necessary. However, it's inconsistent.

On a more positive note, the music is excellent (as expected from Inon Zur). As is the character generation itself. The inclusion of subraces and details put into the models are pretty decent while backgrounds add more flavor. The concept of each class' trees and skillsets aren't too bad either. I would have liked to see your race/class matter, but most DnD PC/console games pay little to no attention to that, making it more for flavor (and stats) than anything else.

The party members and dialogue was actually pretty good. The party members really do have personality although their relationship to the main character does feel railroaded and a bit forced. I did like how they interacted with one another and actually acknowledged each other's existence, feeling more like a cohesive team. The storyline is pretty standard fare (you have nightmares, a big bad threatens all, etc...) so while it's nothing to really write home about it's not necessarily bad either. I did like how the party members felt relevant to the narrative rather than somehow being there for convenience. Sad;y, there is no party creation feature ala Temple of Elemental Evil and NWN2's Storm of Zehir expansion, which is kind of a standard for a good DnD game.

Overall though the game feels incomplete. Way too many bugs and poor handling to really enjoy even the main campaign. While I think it's excellent the Rage of Demons DLC and tiefling/warlock classes were added on for free, the game itself really feels like it could use an overhaul. Which is sad too because I really wanted to like this game. I'm still willing to give it another chance should the game get some more work done on it, but as is I honestly cannot recommend it.

reviewText:
Sword Coast Legends for me is a decent & solid RPG experience.  I am currenty still playing in the campaign on Act3 solo and have another character nearing Act2 thats been playing in co-op.
(46 hrs at time of posting + some time on headstart version)

As featured, you have 6 classes (these are Fighter, Cleric, Rogue, Wizard plus Paladin and Ranger) and 5 Races (Human, Halfling, Elf, Dwarf, Half Elf & some subraces of these) to choose from.  It's using 5e rules adapted for a video game which has led to a skill tree system consisting of multiple tree's dictated by your chosen class, which all contain numerous abilities, passives and spells you can learn related to that tree's 'theme'.

Instead of having uses and casts per rest period as in most previous d&d games for your abilities and spells (where you could pretty  much rest after each fight with little or no consequences) cooldowns have been added instead. These take a little getting used to, but if you spread your spending of skill points a little and/or take some cooldown reduction gear you can easily use a string of abilities in every encounter. I wouldn't say i prefer it this way, but it works well as an alternative method once you've adapted to it.

I have found the campaign's main story and many sidequests (although perhaps on occasion a bit cliche or generic) to generally be fun and/or amusing and true to the FR lore.  The NPC's you have in your party are voiced and all have an interesting backstory and their own questlines you can get from speaking with them at camp.

As well as this campaign you do also have dungeon crawls and a DM toolset included -  i havent touched these very much as of yet as i prefer being a player to a DM but its extra content and it looks pretty easy to use.

I have hosted one dungeon crawl as a DM for a friend of mine. I got to choose from some preset options for its overall layout and creation and then got to DM on the fly.  Modifying and adding, loot chests, obstacles, traps, encounters and even possess some creatures for direct control of them as she went through the dungeon.  For me, it was quite enjoyable and a decent 'bonus' on top of the campaign.

Based on a fairly lengthy campaign with the crawls and DM stuff as extra's i would recommend this product and rate it overall at around 8/10.

Although i have recommended this game it does seems to have recieved a lot of negativity from people because of what its not, which is a NWN3 with regards to the DM toolset provided.
If you have used the NWN toolset to design and create campaigns and adventures and are looking for that kind of detail and freedom in SCL and are more interested in that than the campaign experience as a player this perhaps isn't for you and you should read some of the negative reviews which detail it more.

reviewText:
This is a fun game for me with some caveats. I didn't come into it with preconceived ideas of what it was going to be; I just heard 'D&D game with random and DM options' and that was good enough for me. It's fun creating characters, rolling with friends or NPCs, trying out different build and strats, and being a murderous DM is a blast. The game is stable and runs smoothly.

That said, here come the caveats:
- Graphics are fine, just no wow factor
- Loot system is horrible with strangers. You only auto-split gold; everything else is a mad rush after combat to grab some loot before the front line grabs it all. I came from LOTRO and am used to a Need/Greed system of splitting loot.
- This is not hard-core D&D rules. All spells are like cantrips, in that you can cast a spell as many times as you want, just higher level spells have longer cooldowns. I get why they did that since in other games you effectively have that, you just force your players to 'rest' to get the spells back. In pen & paper, it works, but in video games where you can just load up the last save, forcing players to 'rest' is just silly.
- Game balancing needs tweaking. High-level spells should be clearing rooms and one-shotting mobs, but the paladin in the front is going to do more damage than the wizard in the back.
- Everything runs smoothly for me with about 15 second load times, but I have a new comp with all SSDs.
- Map and camera views take a bit of learning.

That said, what I'm mostly excited about is the potential of the game. I know, every game has 'potential' if devs changed things, but all the bones are here for a great creating adventures, just need more + tweaking: more traps, monsters, effects, environments, capabilities, etc. I finished the story, and  in looking at it with DM eyes and dreams of creating my own adventure, some of the things done in the story mode I was very excited about. 'Dream' sequences, puzzles, and  the intricate story lines based on prior actions were very cool. Now, where is my big, rolling, rock trap of death!

So far despite the much slurs spouting with a good portion of a skinny vitriol I've encountered on a Net for me I've found this game beautifully rendered and just totally compelling. So I simply decided to do not let nobody to convince me of a something flawing  in this game but rather to do trust with my own experience and must admit I haven't any doubts in the SWL. Thus it is just a great brand new sequel to the immortal Baldur's Gate / Neverwinter Nights franchise.
And what is essential even furthermore the game is really undemanding to computer resources thus I've found myself to run it at very decent FPS at the low graphics options of course but still on my pretty much humble GeForce 9600M GT helluva a mobile version!
As for the 'other titles' were mentioned around like the Pillars of... so I must admit I've experienced a something bitter times with it by dealing with the gross glitches and stalls in game then simply playing it.
Not to mention it lacks the most palatable multiplayer gaming experience presented in The Sword Coast Legends.

reviewText:
This is a fun game for me with some caveats. I didn't come into it with preconceived ideas of what it was going to be; I just heard 'D&D game with random and DM options' and that was good enough for me. It's fun creating characters, rolling with friends or NPCs, trying out different build and strats, and being a murderous DM is a blast. The game is stable and runs smoothly.

That said, here come the caveats:
- Graphics are fine, just no wow factor
- Loot system is horrible with strangers. You only auto-split gold; everything else is a mad rush after combat to grab some loot before the front line grabs it all. I came from LOTRO and am used to a Need/Greed system of splitting loot.
- This is not hard-core D&D rules. All spells are like cantrips, in that you can cast a spell as many times as you want, just higher level spells have longer cooldowns. I get why they did that since in other games you effectively have that, you just force your players to 'rest' to get the spells back. In pen & paper, it works, but in video games where you can just load up the last save, forcing players to 'rest' is just silly.
- Game balancing needs tweaking. High-level spells should be clearing rooms and one-shotting mobs, but the paladin in the front is going to do more damage than the wizard in the back.
- Everything runs smoothly for me with about 15 second load times, but I have a new comp with all SSDs.
- Map and camera views take a bit of learning.

That said, what I'm mostly excited about is the potential of the game. I know, every game has 'potential' if devs changed things, but all the bones are here for a great creating adventures, just need more + tweaking: more traps, monsters, effects, environments, capabilities, etc. I finished the story, and  in looking at it with DM eyes and dreams of creating my own adventure, some of the things done in the story mode I was very excited about. 'Dream' sequences, puzzles, and  the intricate story lines based on prior actions were very cool. Now, where is my big, rolling, rock trap of death!

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this. I've been playing CRPGs since I was a kid, and LOVED all the D&D ones (Baldur's Gates, Icewind Dales) and grabbed this thinking it was part of the new golden age in CRPGs. I was expecting something like Pillars of Eternity, except even more true-to-BG than PoE becase..hey, D&D. Half-Elves and Paladins and Sword Coast. Awesome, right?..except this game falls short of the mark, in so many different ways. If you were expecting the new greatest PC RPG in the line of The Witcher or PoE, THIS IS NOT IT.

To sum up, this game is simplified, clunky, without any charm, and lacks interesting characters or choices. This plays more like a simple ARPG (and if you wanted an ARPG, there's way better ones)

Specific complaints:

Unremarkable cast members - their voice acting is ATROCIOUS, and none of them seem interesting. For a party-based RPG, this is a must. and it doesn't have it.
Clunky UI -
Every time  you start and finish talking to an NPC, the screen takes about a second to fade to black. EVERY DIALOGUE. This gets extremely old, and serves no purpose because there's not even talking heads. It just zooms in a bit more - but there's no animated dialogue or models. It does this even for the voiceless NPCs. Completely unnecessary.
Pauses between conversation options - You'll selection an option, wait a moment, then hear the response..the pause is noticeable enough to be grating - not good for impatient gamers like myself. Simplified ARPG gameplay
Every skill is cooldown based. There is no rest mechanic in this game - there's no worry about conservation of your skills and resources in a dungeon. You just spam your skill when the cooldown is over. It almost feels like an MMO.
No heavy customization - each class has about 5-6 different skill trees, but there's no dabbling in multi class options which is one of the greatest things about D&D. A significant step back from Neverwinter nights and what D&D has to offer.
The classes feel bland and generic. In D&D your Wizards have the ability to summon monsters, polymorph enemies, shapeshift, pull out magical flaming swords...in this game, they pretty much just focus on blasting stuff (evocation school). Your Wizard feels like any other Ranged DPS. Graphics - The character models aren't great looking - I found it pretty damn hard to make an aesthetically pleasing character. But the environments look decent.
This game has no personality. It's generic, bland, uninteresting. I hate that I was so hyped up, and all I got was this.

I will be returning this for a refund. Do not drop $40 on this game. Go play Pillars or Path of Exile or Divinity.
