reviewText:
I like these kinds of games, though this genre is not among my favorites.  Sword Coast Legends (SCL) is very much like Baldur's Gate: a sort of mix between action RPG and turn-based strategy.  Also, SCL is the newest game in D&D and thus is based on the Version 5 ruleset.  So if you are into all those things regarding SCL, then you will like this game, as I did.

As far as graphics, sound (including voice acting), storyline, and user interface (UI), the game is great for this genre.  I have not played it in multiplayer, though.  I have imagined that it would be totally awesome to party with your friends in SCL, though I also have imagined that there is no *Pause* function, as everyone only controls one character and has to make due.  That would be super fun, of course.  But I think SCL has great voice acting and storyline - the cut scenes are very nice and dramatic and make you care about the game - and the graphics include all the 3D features and artwork that we have come to expect in today's games, especially in the (true) RPG genres.

To close, I only recommend Sword Coast Legends for either of the two following reasons:

1)  You are a diehard Dungeons & Dragons fan, want to see Ruleset 5 in action, and/or want to get a nostalgic feel a la Baldur's Gate et al.  For this group, I'd say that $20 is a fair price to pay for the base game.

2)  You are a diehard RPG fan, like the genres of action or turn-based, and/or want to play characters that you can care about.  For this group, I'd say that $7.49 is a fair price for the base game.

I would not recommend Sword Coast Legends to people who only like action games, only like turn-based games, and/or people who despise fantasy realm drama.

reviewText:
I am a huge AD&D fan. I started with Baldurs gate way back in the 90's and my love was cemented with NWN. Both of those games I have played though more times than I can count. So to hit the mark that seems to be the real issue:

This game is NOT AD&D but it is a bloody good adaption of it.

Nevermind the bad reviews from the P&P D&D fans that take issue with this fact. It's actually pretty cool and in the genereal style of BG and NWN.

Pros:
- AD&D adaption
- Forgotten Realms Wolrd
- Graphics are great for this type of game
- Reasonable storyline

Cons:
- Lack of clarity in stats/rolls/mechanics etc due to the adaption rather than pure AD&D nature
- Camera and controls can be clunky at times
- Some side quests are not easy to figure out and can only be completed further in the story

Overall it's a good game if you want an RPG in the style of BG and NWN. Don't go in expecting to see AD&D though because you'll be raging along with the other hardcore fans.

reviewText:
This game is secretly amazing. If you are looking for a full RPG experience with fully fleshed out campaigns and well thought out maps and encounters, look elsewhere. This game is best described as one of THE BEST dungeons and dragons tools out there to date. It is a mediocre game when not played this way. However, when played as a tool for D&D this thing is 11/10. It stomps on all others in its class.

If you are looking for a solid RPG experience look elsewhere. This is more of a dungeon crawling experience when it is not played as a tool for D&D.

I recommend this game for anyone who is into dungeons and dragons and is willing to spend the time to create content for their players or allow themselves to be immersed in others created content.

reviewText:
Played only the tutorial level of the game in the very short time I had been able to juggle time with my work schedule.

Played the level just fine with the low-end machine that I possess and was intrigued by the dream sequence.  I did not proceed any further than that due to, again, needing to juggle time between work and sleep.

all that aside, I played with the Rogue mechanics and understood the tutorial well enough, but I became utterly confused by one of the final tutorials talking about Cantrips.  What button does what where here?

Other than that little hiccup in the reading, I have to say that so far this game plays very much like Neverwinter Nights.  I sincerely hope that, whenever I do manage to pick the game up after this current Free Weekend is up, I do not end up becoming excessively bored with it due to the extreme repetitiveness found in similar games.

Until I see more of it, my recommendation is actually neither yes nor no.

reviewText:
Not sure why reviews are mixed, but here is mine.
I am a linux gamer, have this in mind.
Maxed out settings, on strong enough AMD CPU 32GB RAM + 780TI NVIDIA Binary driver on unsupported platform.
Game runs pretty well. Not exceptionally well, but not too bad.(can drop to 20 FPS in snowy area), otherwise on very playable 40-100 FPS. Windows players can probably expect better performance.

I am not Dungeons and Dragons fan. In fact never played any games in this universe. (may be one game, which I wont mention here)

Game is VERY FUN. I am sucked into story, characters are believable, every line so far is voice acted.(a few hours into game)
Graphics is great. It's not your AAA title when it come to graphics, but it is nice, allows camera rotation. For me, game graphics is good when there are a lot of textures. This game has it. Other effects are nice too.

I love complexity of skills/builds/chars.(for me, figuring out build at start of game - is half the fun)

For those solve in more than one way" junkies
date: game has it.\n\nI seriously reccomend it."

reviewText:
When the game first came out, it was a mess. From missed release dates, to pulling the game back because it was so terribly broken and bad. I uninstalled the game thinking that I had wasted my money.

Recently I got bored and I decided to give it another shot. I downloaded it and began playing a Ranger. The game is vastly improved over what it was in Beta and initial release! It reminds me of Neverwinter Nights, maybe less complex though. I guess a cross between Neverwinter Nights and Dragon Age would best describe it.

The storyline is pretty solid too. I am really enjoying this game. Pillars of Eternity was the last game of this type that I enjoyed.

reviewText:
Bought this game wanting to try an Old School CRPG.
Uninstalled it after an hour and a half of trying to figure out what the hell is going on with those sprites and having to deal with one monster of a migraine from looking at this game.
I don't mind lower quality graphics as long as they work, but when it gives you a four hour migraine and severe buyer's remorse, you start to mind.
I'll try it again here in a few months after some patches, but I'm not getting my hopes up.

reviewText:
Who doesn't enjoy a relaxed D&D-esque session with your closest buddies, right?
And who doesn't enjoy heading out on epic adventures with said closest buddies, right?
And, more so, who doesn't enjoy bountiful treasures at the end of a prevailed challenging journey of epic proportions, right?

You won't find it here.

What you will find, however, in aforementioned bountiful epic proportions is constant lost connection" issues.
That's almost just as good."

reviewText: As a game, Sword Coast Legends is dissappointing. Visuals are choppy, the art style is unappealing--almost cartooney--and the voice acting is cringe-worthy. As far as gameplay, it's stable enough, but that's it. Stable *enough*. Throughout the free weekend, I found myself saying repeatedly that it wasn't that bad" or that some part of it "was okay". In truth
date: I've realized that as a D&D player and as someone invested in Forgotten Realms
recommended: I really wanted this game to be great. But even my rose-tinted Faerunian goggles couldn't make this game better than it really is. It's an underwhelming retro-style almost-isometric RPG that would be a great follow-up to Neverwinter Nights if it hadn't already been done a thousand times better by other companies who make a living beating Wizards at their own game--literally.  Perhaps if Sword Coast Legends came out in 2007
hoursPlayed: I'd be much more impressed. That's about the year in which this game belongs.\n\nNow

reviewText:
This is my first review.

TLDR: Its a poor game, there are moments when you think this should be better than it is. Modding could fix this, unfortunately the game's DM tools are completely lack luster and modding is all but impossible at the moment. It feels like the developers and their lackies made a game that they want to control, so you only have limited tools, while they get the entire toy box.

It has all be said by others, but it boils down to this for me, and quite likely for you as well.

1.	As a DnD game, this is pathetic. The pacing is way too fast, there is no balance (not once have I felt at all threatened by the enemies in the campaign) and the dialogue is halting and clunky at best. It lacks key races from any fantasy genera (notably Orcs and Dragons).

2.	As a hack and slash, the game is ok. It mainly consists of clicking on the enemies until they are dead, with almost no skill use except the occasional pause to counter a spell or heal a teammate. The UI is terrible, clicking on anything is clunky and often you misclick and stand there doing nothing while being hit.

3.	The Engine is clunky and ugly. Clicking on anything starts feeling like a chore in the first area, dialogue is invasive taking control of your camera and anyone else playing with you regardless of location. The color pallet consists of greens and browns.

4.	Multiplayer is even more clunky. As every time you talk to someone all players are interrupted to see the dialogue (instead of just posting it in the message box on the lower left, like NWN). You cannot leave an area without all party members, meaning if you have a retentive friend or player that likes to micromanage their inventory, you have to wait for them. It also means every time you click to leave, a dialogue box pops up that will kick them out of their inventory, hilarious once, annoying afterward.

5.	Lastly we come to the one thing that could have redeemed this game, the Toolset. As long as your modding tools are comprehensive enough with a DnD style game, someone will make it work when you utterly fail to do so. Unfortunately here the game again falls flat on its face. In an effort to simplify the tools so that the developer’s young children could use it, they stripped the toolset of every possible usable functionality.

a. You cannot craft dialogue trees without getting creative and making your game endlessly clunky. Every quest or quest action you can write a single sentence or two before you hit character limits then the PC only has the option of a yes/no response. To make a dialogue tree, you have to make a separate quest action for every single sentence, requiring the players to click multiple times to continue a conversation. Yet the engine is clearly capable of supporting dialogue trees, as they are present in the main game.

b. Quest rewards are randomized; you cannot pick a specific reward for players.

c. DM character creator is limited, you do not have full control over stats, equipment or even colors when it comes to monsters. This is great if your used to bad DM’s that overpower all their characters because ‘mine’ but terrible if you’re a good DM and just want the freedom to tweak until your happy.

d. Quests can only be bound to objects or characters, you cannot place a trigger just on the ground to be stepped on. Quests also can only be triggered by clicking the object.

e. Exterior Maps are ‘random’ but they are not. Maps are pre built, with between 2-5 variations many of them just small areas, like a glade in the woods. This makes for tiresome tweaking to try and make each outdoor area feel different, while using the same map(s) over and over again.

f. Dungeons are random (yay) but the templates for them are just boring, brown and ugly. Still suffering from the same problems as the rest of the game.

In the end, I cannot recommend this game, my brother and I purchased it to play a good old DnD CRPG and it got boring in the first half hour, we plugged on for another two before agreeing to return our copies. Modding will not fix it unless the developer can/wants to open up hood and give the users the full toolbox.

reviewText:
Game isn't Baldur's Gate or a completely faithful recreation of actual tabletop D&D 0/10 would not play.


But yeah, I'm baffled by the level of complaining about the game.  It's a solid game for the price.  It's not mind blowing, but the gameplay is fun, and I've been having a blast crafting a campaign from the minute details of the plot to creating little personal flourishes, like a rat that is also an armed explosion trap ready to blow up anybody who touches said rat without first disaming it.

Oh, you wanted a faithful recreation of D&D that you can play online, with friends?  There's no video game on earth which currently exists that can replicate tabletop gaming.  Go sign up for roll20 if that's what you want.

Sword Coast Legends is a good game with gameplay that hovers somewhere between Diablo and Baldur's Gate II.

The only complaint I have is the absolute randomization of dungeon layouts and loot (You can absolutely fill a dungeon however you want to, but have no say over what players get for completing a quest - i.e. they can be rewarded Random Weapon
recommended: or Random Trinket.")  but even then
hoursPlayed: it still works for what it is.\n\nIn the end
voteText: almost all of the issues with the game feel like minor complaints when you're crafting a serious questline about a fallen paladin's quest to get revenge on the order that spurned him to share with friends and strangers (and dropping booby-trapped rats into some inconspicuous corners along the way.)"

reviewText:
Release Review
Well so far I have put about 45 hours into the game IN THE HEADSTARTS. This is what I have found so far. The campaign is fun, a good D & D style romp. Good quests, nice story and good voice acting.

Over all a solid 8 out of 10 for me for single player.

Now for the multi-player. Love the DM mode just wish we had more control over what the players were doing and bringing in, like being able to look at the character sheets and inventory to see if they are cheaters. Need more control over loot for sure, Ninja Looting abounds in pickup groups.

They told us that they were holding alot back from the multiplayer side to avoid spoiling the campaign, turns out the community was either being unrealistic on their expectations for what was coming or we were mislead by developers. There was not much more released from the head starts. NO NEW MONSTERS even some that are in the campaign are missing (DRAGONS anyone). NO NEW ITEMS again even tho there are tons more in the campaign. None of the additions that people were asking for on the forums were added, that I can see.

Looking at about a 6 out of 10 for multiplayer as a module builder. 8 out of 10 as a DM or Player going thru a Module.

BUT IT COULD BE SO MUCH MORE! The base is there just need the additions and polish.

Really hoping the developers continue to support the game and make it great not just grab their money and run..........................

reviewText: Never played D&D card game but I loved the Neverwinter Nights series (minus Sword of Zehir which was a bomb).  This reminds me of those games and I liked it.  I played Single Player and battles were just challenging enough to keep me interested.   Story is kind of blah and too much unnecessary dialog but that kind of goes with the Neverwinter genre and its like.   Needs more instruction on how to use mechanics - even after playing these type of games for years it took me awhile to get the hang of it again.  Would prefer holding to left mouse down to move not point and click.  I would recommend it but not at full price.  I'm buying it at half off.

reviewText:
Played for the free weekend and in my opinion this game is pretty fun. If you enjoyed classic crpgs of the past like Baldur's Gate/IWD/NWN series then you should give this a try. It apparently goes for the 5e D&D ruleset (which I know practically nothing about) but it does takes some liberites from what I can tell. I'll start with the pros then cons.

Pros:
-Single player campaign is pretty interesting as far as I got, I think I might actually complete it, unlike NWN OC which I got bored of by the end of chapter 2 lol (Modules was where that game shined). The story is interesting, and the npcs who join you along the way are humorous as well.
-I like the combat, sure it doesn't feel that close to pnp what with ability cool-downs and such. But it works well imo. I have no idea how 5e plays so maybe it works that way, all i know is you dont have to rest after every couple combats to reset your spell books.
-Player made modules can be downloaded from within the game. And there are already hundreds of them to choose from. Downloading player made content has never been easier (I cant stand steam workshop because every time a game updates mods break your game until they are updated)
-For something different you can play randomly generated dungeon crawls where you have quite a bit of control on what it will consist of but not limited to: your objectives, and enemy types, the tile set used, how many floors and if there will be a boss. Really simple to figure out.
-I never tried DM mode or creating a module but from some youtube videos I looked at it appears to be pretty intuitive. I think I could even manage it and I have never created custom content for a game. But at the cost of that, it may limit what you can do if you are very experienced at such things (dont go in expecting nwn tooleditor at least not yet anyways). Devs keep adding features to this as time goes by.
-You get a persistant camp with a stash that you can visit during your adventures. The chest is really nice because you can swap items between characters with it.


Cons:
-This may not effect most people but I cant seem to keep a solid 60fps, I meet and excede the recommended specs but occasionally the frames drop. mostly in large areas or areas that have particle effects like snow falling etc. It is still totally playable for me, just breaks immersion a bit. Not sure if its an issue on my end or if its unity engine related.
-Many of the down votes are due to the fact that you have to sign up for a 3rd party account. Really not a big deal, it takes you 3 minutes tops, and bang your playing the game. You can at least opt out of the email updates if you want.
-Character creation is kind of limited in comparison to older D&D based games. You get the main races like Human (theres actually 2 sub race selections for this) elf, half-elf, dwarf, and halfling. Each with at least a couple sub races except for half elf. So no gnomes or tieflings yet but possibly in an update. They did just add drows apparently so you can get your Drizzt on if thats your thing. Also the classes are lacking, you get your basics but theres so much more I think we all want to see, like Warlocks, Monks, Bards, Druids, and Barbarians to name a few.
-Skill trees... yea instead of your usual feat/skill progression like in previous dnd games you get skill trees for each class. Think Dragon Age Inquisition basically. That is not necessarily a bad thing but it could really be improved upon.
-All in all this game is pretty streamlined, anyone could pick this game up with no knowledge of D&D or rulesets. A con no doubt for D&D vets but probably good news for people new to it.

Unfortinately I cant say anything about MP because I only played single player so far, but what I know is you can have 4 players with or without a 5th as a DM. You can play the campaign with friends or try other modules or do some random dungeon diving. thats about all I know about it.

Anyways this was my first review, I felt that this game deserves a some more possitive reviews. Thats what I think anyways. I played for the free weekend and then bought it, I think this game is worth a buy if you enjoy these types of games. Thats my 2 cents, have a good one!

reviewText:
Bought this game on a recommendation from a friend and was not disappointed. I tend to jump from game to game quite a bit, and this is one that I actually played all the way through. Enjoyed the single player campaign and was also fun playing co-op through dungeon crawls. One complaint that I had while playing co-op was that the loot drops were not independent, so if your not playing with friends, loot can be ninja'd from you.

Pros-
-Interesting campaign although still a little easy IMO
-Classes were neat
-Developers actually seem to care about game feedback and is introducing new things already (free) (so-far)

Cons-
-Loot drops if not playing solo
-Not having more class choices (5 currently)
-Little easy
-There's no stash currently (But it's supposed to be added pretty soon)
-Items are a bit underwhelming to be perfectly honest although to be fair its not supposed to be a gear grinding type game anyways.

Overall I would recommend this game pretty strongly especially if the developers keep up the hard work

reviewText:
Most of the negative reviews here and elsewhere were from before the new content.

First off, it's 2016. Games aren't on cartridges or CD's and are no longer fully featured. The landscape has changed, get over it. After these last two community packs, most of the reviewers have stated that they like it now but still refuse to recommend it because the devs have to earn their trust. So, listening to the community and publishing packs to answer their feedback DOESN'T earn your trust? Get over yourself.

Secondly, this is a video game, not a pen and paper game. I too am a long fan of pen and paper games and am a GM. You know what else wasn't like its pen and paper cousin? Neverwinter Nights 1&2. Nor was Baldur's Gate, or The Temple of Elemental Evil because video games will never be able to fully emulate our imaginations.

Thirdly, for a dungeon crawler that evokes the feel of a pen and paper game (but isn't fully one), this game is fun. It isn't perfect, nor is any other game, but I found the DM controls easy to use and don't require a PHD in game design in order to have fun. The gameplay feels pretty much like any other dungeon crawler, which is a win to me, because if something isn't broken, it doesn't need to be fixed.

All in all, I recommend this game, as a gamer of 23 years and a tabletop gamer of 14 years. It's not perfect, but hey, $20 is nothing compared to some of the garbage for which you pay $60. If you like dungeon crawlers and want it to be skinned as D&D, buy it. :)

reviewText:
So SCL is an isometric (zoomable :-D) perspective RPG set in the Forgotten Realms D&D campaign setting, using a (highly) modified 5th edition ruleset.

I will keep this rather brief.

The GOOD:

Excellent character creation in terms of making your character look how to want them to look.
There are lots of race and class choices, as well as background

Really nice feel to the campaign. It just has it. This is a really big + in my opinion as a few D&D games of late have fallen by the way side in terms of single-player campaign.
The way party members are dealt with is cool and refreshing (in a vintage way, if that's possible), and characterisation is very good so far (with really nice voice-acting).

The combat system works well after getting used to it. Although it may have taken me a while (1-2 hours) to get used to it because of the sheer amount of time I've spent playing games like Baldur's Gate and Pillars of Eternity.

The graphics are pretty (see the BAD for more details though...)

Music is constantly playing throughout the game, giving it a Classic dungeon crawl" feel.

I haven't done too much multiplayer yet (I did do some in the headstarts though) but it works well from my preliminary experiences with it. The 4+1 multiplayer dungeon crawling is good fun
date: especially as the dungeon master can alter monsters
hoursPlayed: traps etc. in real-time.\n\nDM tools are quite nice
voteText: but I'd like more freedom and a free-form tile editor would be good
helpfulPercent:
as well as the ability to make branching dialogue when making NPCs.


THE BAD:

The graphics are nice
votesHelpful: but not nice enough to lower the frame rate of my highly powered rig to about 15 fps at max settings. I get ~35 fps on The Phantom Pain on maximum settings
votesTotal: to put it in perspective.\n\nThe combat is just very slightly clunky. I'm not really sure how to describe it! Baldur's Gate is so smooth with how it deals with abilities
votesFunny: and I feel when I play this that I am expecting it to be a little more responsive
commentsCount: but that could just be my subliminal preference.\n\nTree system is a bit weird and maybe gives each character class too many choices
column16:
but this decision may have been made because there is no multi-classing.

The prologue is not good.... It is alright. Okay. Fine..... But that's it. If I wasn't confident I'd really like the game from previously playing Sword Coast legends I may be writing an entirely different review. It is far too linear and a little bland.



My problem with other reviews is that most of the very harsh reviews are from reviewers that have played 1-2 hours. This is not enough time to really appreciate the game and I imagine most haven't even finished the prologue yet.


As a die-hard D&D fan and player 9/10
column17: as an average gamer 8/10."

reviewText:
The campaign is really fun. As a long time D&D player from NWN DA:O and Baldurs Gate, this game has a bit of everything. Personally I'm enjoying how they handled the skill trees and adapted the ruleset to this PC Game. It might offend some DnD purists but so far it's enjoyable.

The party combat AI could use improving. The level editor needs a tileset editor.

Buying just to play the game, I'd give this a 7/10. Buying and seeing the game evolve and all the missing features like orcs, kobolds, better level editor, tileset editor, and some patches to the core gameplay and tools to build worlds for DnD adventures like NWN1 - this game could be a grand successor.

I myself enjoy the graphics and atmosphere, it's well done and suits the genre. Sounds are good, as is the UI.

Need to be able to remove or minimize the quest window. Screen edge mouse scrolling is a really missing feature.

reviewText:
I'll be honest what got me really excited was the whole Idea of a DM and players creating amazing modules. Though so far all I've heard was that the tools that DM has to create with is very limited. I also find myself wishing for more classes and spells as so me classes feel completely the same (paladin and cleric).

Though this is very dissapointing, I would like to believe that these problems will be updated by the company via DLC/Expansions/update.

I find the Story Mode excellent and enjoyable and with that I see the possibilities of Users creating equally epic works.

I feel that the issues plaguing this game is definitely something that the company will be working on, (especially since everyone made such a big deal about the DM limitations) and that the problems with the limitations on spells and classes is something that future DLC can fix. I think that the game's features is overhyped from what it actually is but I don't think its a horrible game either. I think that the game will definitely live up to its promises after a couple fixes and expansions/updates.

I think its worth it to purchase this game so far. Now if they start making us pay like $10 for a single new class or for a few monsters to create on the DM, I will quickly change my stance just like my experiences with evolve, it was a great game but once it got really microtransactiony I just totally left the game. I'm totally open to purchasing expansion packs and dlc's (though slightly wary of dlc's) which will expand the original game and by buying this game its kind of my way to show support to the company. Just hoping they don't F us in the future.

reviewText:
If your first priority is experiencing Forgotten Realms lore in a cRPG, this is a good buy.
If it's dungeon crawling, bad guy killing and loot collecting, this is an enjoyable game.
If it's faithfully translating your table top RPG experience to a computer game, this is a very poor fit.
If it's recapturing the magic of Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale, this is unlikely to satisfy.
If it's finding a mod engine on a par with Neverwinter Nights, it may get there someday but not yet.
If it's the multiplayer experience, you'll have some fun but probably be able to think of at least a few titles that do it a lot better.

I got enough enjoyment out of playing the game to feel like I got my money's worth.

reviewText:
Is it 100% true to D&D? no...
Is it ground breaking? There are some unique features, but no...
Is it a unique kind of game? nope.

Is it good? Absolutely.

Sure this game has flaws and isn't perfect but it is fun. The bugs will get fixed (All games these days have bugs at launch)

I have played for almost 18 hours (at the time of this review) and that isn't even scratching the surface. I still need to start a game in story mode, do dungeon crawls with other players, and be a live dm. The 18 hours are just the time I have spent creating just one of my campaigns.

Bottom line: it's a fun game. If you are unsure then either wait for a sale or buy it and request a refund before you play it too much.

reviewText: I have played through some of the story line and several dungeon crawls and a friend's DM-led campaign.  Most of all I have to say that I really enjoy this game and it is a ton of fun!  We were able to do an old-fashioned table game even though our group is spread across the country.  And I really have to say amazing congratulations to the Sword Coast team for some of the best writing and story line dialogue of any game I've played in years!!  The voice actors are great, and really give the feel of different people with different perspectives on life (and larceny).  Some other reviewers will always find things to nitpick, but the devs continue to improve the game, and they put serious effort behind what really makes this game stand out - the dialogue and story writing that sucks you in and makes you laugh when you least expect it.  I absolutely recommend this game.

reviewText:
TLDR Version: A pathetic offering given the competition, and only vaguely D&D. Plays like a dumbed-down Diablo 3. If you want the experience you EXPECT, play Pillars of Eternity, Shadowrun: Dragonfall, or (if you want multiplayer) Divinity: Original Sin.

EDIT: Please note that I have spent MANY more hours than are shown in the game - during the Head Start, I spent a great deal of time playing, creating, and trying to DM scenarios and dungeon crawls. I withheld judgment until the proper release.

Sword Coast Legends wants desperately to be a modern Baldur's Gate, or perhaps a reinvention of Neverwinter Nights, or some combination. It fails at both.

The game's entire feel is not that of a D&D session, but more like a squad RTS like one of the Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War series, except that it is tactically banal. The story dialogue and quests are highly simplistic, and often even embarrassingly bad. The NPCs give fetch quests with no context and a backstory that feels like it was improvised and unedited. The characters are one-dimensional, and the world is boring. Gameplay feels like an MMO or (*gag*) even a MOBA, with a hotbar of abilities that cool down in real time.  The skill trees are entirely inventions of the game developers, and have nothing to do with D&D.

Worst of all, the multiplayer story experience is awful. The host controls 3 characters while the guest controls 1, leaving the guest constantly waiting for the host. Loading screens can last for several minutes, and gameplay is more like Diablo than D&D.

Maybe it's unfair that I've recently played Pillars of Eternity, and have trouble avoiding a comparison, but that's the reality of the situation - SCL was released in an environment where the bar was set high, and they are well below it.

reviewText:
This game is not perfect...Not the best opening line to a game review when it has been recommended i know! But wait: I have only played about 13 hours but so far i am loving it. I can see that perhaps due to its relatively linear approach there wont be much interest in playing through it again. But as my Wizard hit level 6 i can safely say it is a good game. At least for someone who loves DnD and Forgotten realms in particular.

Pros for me.
Magic system lets me have and use some of the most iconic DnD spells. Magic missile, Melf's acid arrow, and fireball being my most useful.
The AI is generally spot on when you leave them to control themselves. (Aside from the Cleric who thinks bless should be cast near the end of a fight lol)
The voice acting is pretty amusing. The Rogue and the Necromancer have both cracked me up on a couple of occasions and even the Fighter pipes up with some funny stuff.
It is based in forgotten realms ++++
A beggar tried to convince me to buy his button that he claimed Drizzt had given him for saving his life. I did not buy it but amused me nonetheless.
I pick pocketed a dwarf for 250 gold whilst he slept. He had a note from his wife claiming it was the last of their savings please don't lose it. I sneakily put it back and went on my way. :)

Cons
There have not been too many opportunities for me to go into a kind of good or bad scenario as Neverwinter nights 2 offered. And i have not seen much downside (as yet) for helping theives or Tiefling warlocks with nefarious designs. Perhaps it is simply too early or perhaps there is no downside.
AI is never gonna be at a level of fellow players.
Loading screen times can be very long (but my system is a bit old)
Need more toolbars! Soooo many potions and food items that give temp boosts it gets a bit ridiculous really lol.

In summary so far i am enjoying running around in Forgotten realms. I am thinking of it more as a book quest since you can't stray too far from the script. But who cares i am fireballing things. That being said i may change my review in the future as i progress further into the game.

reviewText:
I recommend this game with a glaring BUT...!" tagged onto it. 100+ hours into Pre-Release for credibility.

Quick and dirty:

Pros: Light-hearted

reviewText: I liked it.  I think the biggest hurdle is the weight of expectations.  It isn't Baldurs Gate 2 or the like, it isn't Dragon Age: Origins, it isn't (from what others have said) like Neverwinter Nights custom modules.  It also isn't Diablo.  It does have elements of each though, while not being as great as any of them in their strongest points.  I played the custom DM modules before official release and they were fun enough, but I mainly got it for the campaign.  I'm honestly not sure how the game is supposed to be played.  My main strat, which worked well for my preferred party/characters/actors, was to have buffs so I had a fighter with AC and HP party buff, a Paladin with Bless (and Aid- +damage resistance, and HP buff), a rogue with Revellry(?) giving the same buff as Aid-  +damage resistance, and HP buff.  Without these and other HP buffs, early on, it was near impossible.  I was playing on Hard (which had to be selected each time I played) so that may have been it.  However with all those buffs fights rarely needed micromanagement.  Later I got more buffs like the wizard with magic weapon and haste.  The result is that by the end boss, which I read was supposed to have two stages- after their health gets to half, my fighter in particular with 4 attacks each round, critical range through the roof, strength obscenely high, haste, magic weapon, crusaders mantle(+ radiant damage per hit) I watched the final Boss' health drop so fast all I could do was exclaim Holy ****! Get Rekt!" (very untypical of me and was an exclamation of true amazement and excitement) and he was dead before he could trigger his halfway health stage.  Even if the guide online was erroneous
date: the point is that I got what I wanted.  I got a game with DnD races and loot
hoursPlayed: and became a complete bad ♥♥♥.  Ie. I just wanted to equip my guy with better loot and have fun with story and side quests and I did.\n\nThat isn't to say the whole game was a breeze.  I didn't micromanage per se

Anyway discounting idling and whatnot I got over 50 hours and completed everything.  While I sometimes wished that the buffs didn't have to be reactivated every 60-100 seconds

reviewText:
Oh boy, where to begin *rubs eyes*.
Cinematics are hilariously broken, and wont even run on a fairly decent 2yr old gaming laptop. This is the only game I've literally had 'freeze' on a loading screen....can't you even make loading screens guys? My computer offers to 'end unresponsive program' after a second or two of loading, instantly hating on the game xD

Whenever it does load, it's a buggy mess at best, and a boring endless smash 'n grab grind, at worst. Even with a good DM you'll end up with someone coming in and stealing all the loot, or being FAR higher leveled than you, smash 'n grabbing everything (stealing all the loot, -and- not even letting you kill anything).

A half dozen games in we had a boss that just plain didn't spawn...after rolling the last consecutive 6 dungeons, the boss was too scared to even show up. 10/10 would scare away dungeon bosses again.

Don't even get me started with bad DM's xD the ones who will spam mages behind doors?
You've been hit with lagbolt for 7fps damage! You've been hit with lagbolt for 5fps damage! You've been hit with lagbolt for 12fps damage! You've been hit with lagbolt for 9fps damage! You've been hit with lagbolt for 7fps damage! You've been hit with lagbolt for 5fps damage!"

You are now at 0fps! GG...

reviewText:
EDIT: Edited to reflect more time spent on this game, and further impressions and opinions on what I've experienced.

I played this during Head Start and I've now started working on the campaign. The dungeon crawls were fun, and I'm finding the campaign to be entriguing.

That said, I'm going based off what I've already experienced, which isn't the full campaign storyline.

I find this to be a lot of fun - and one of the better D&D Forgotten Realms titles in recent years. Is it as good as Baldur's Gate or Icewind Dale? No, but it is a faithful return to that kind of story telling. I'm personally not a fan of 5e, so the lack of 5e character class builds is kinda nice for me - my only complaint is a lack of true multi-classing, but you get something similar with the mix and match class tree system. The combat isn't too complicated in the beginning, and abilities can be on long CD's - which can be a bit tedious at times.

Graphically, it needs a little polishing; it's not the most beautiful of games, with a few annoying bugs, but it's better than I expected.

DM mode needs some  tweaking (dungeons are not fully customizable - you can only add in monsters and the like), and I'd like to see Druid and Bard classes added in.

Characters are well written and I'm enjoying what I've experienced of their storylines, as well as dialogue being a lot of fun. There's been a few laugh out loud moments for me.

It's obviously drawing influence from the more classic Forgotten Realms titles, as well as a little bit of Diablo, but you can only rehash the isometric rpg game play style so many times before it starts to look like x, y, and z games. If you're expecting something like Neverwinter Nights - sorry, you'll be disappointed, and don't bother pulling out your wallet. If you're looking for a return to the Forgotten Realms and isometric rpg style gaming, this will be worth your time and money - at least much more than certain MMOs out there.

reviewText:
I went into Sword Coast Legends expecting some interesting party based combat, hopefully with some clever dialogue and an engaging story. I ended up with higher blood pressure, throbbing rage-veins, and a strong sense of raw, untargeted hate.

The game drops you into a tutorial dream sequence set in a flaming building. The smoke and flames make the graphics blurry, so it's hard to see your surroundings while you figure out the controls, including a non-intuitve manual screen rotation to look around walls and such.

The purpose of the fire is to give the tutorial a sense of urgency, but the opening dialogue kills that immediately. It starts fine-- someone wakes you up to let you know the building is on fire and beset by enemies. The natural response, oh ♥♥♥♥ I should fight my way out of this burning building

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that I was a little disappointed in the game when I participated in Early Access.  I felt that if there wasn't a good single-player campaign, I probably would hardly play the game.  I missed, what I considered was, the tactical combat of earlier D&D games like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale.  This combat just seemed like point and click.

Well the game officially launched, I've played through the campaign, and I must say that I was wrong.  There is a lot of tactical decisions during combate...especially during bosses.  I found myself pausing the game to give each character a specific set of commands for their next action.  It got to the point where I really enjoyed the combat and the AI.

The biggest achievement for this game, though, is the story.  It's a well written D&D adventure, full of action, heroism, horror, and some laughs; and the voice cast does an amazing job at bringing these characters to life.  By the end of the campaign, I was emotionally invested in the NPCs.

I recommmend this game for anyone looking for a little D&D fun as a solo experience.  Right now, I find the dungeon crawls and DM experience a little lacking.  I'm hoping this is a foundation on which the developers will keep adding stuff.  I see a lot of potential with the player-created content if we're given all the tools that we ask for.

reviewText:
I played quite a bit of the early access after I preordered.  The game isn't totally what I wanted but I also think you can get 40 hours of game play out of it.  40 hours for 40 dollars is acceptable for price.  A buck an hour is usually what I look for in pricing.  I think the storyline looks good so far in what i've seen and how its done.

I think the real issue is the new D and D ruleset is not as good as 3.5 or prior.  It doesn't feel like D and D at all.  And the DM stuff doesn't feel like Neverwinter (nor did anyone claim it would be, but I still hoped).  So you will be kind of left hanging, but if you can deal with that I think the game is fun.

Just a note...I find some characters completely unenjoyable to play in this ruleset so it may be worth taking a few stabs at the game with different characters.

This is a good start for something to build on too...add in more customization for DM's and please find a way to make persistent worlds in the future.

reviewText:
Warning: I have over 100 Headstart hours and finished the campaign on release but had A LOT of progress from the final headstart before release (headstart 5)
Now for the review:

TL;DR: Campaign is awesome, tools are excellent for live DMing

The game expands itself in the FR universe of D&D and keeps a solid job on keeping you interested on the main campaign for hours on end, and the modules that some people of the community have done are full of detail and amazing original creations that also give a ton of extra hours. The newly added Rage of Demons expansion, brings new DM content, new class, new playable race and a cohesive short campaign featuring a lot of lore and albeit short, it's very fun and well built with 3 different factions that offer replayability.

Has it stands right now the Module creation tools are quite limited, but not without reason. The DM tools are meant so that ANYONE can make a quick module and just LIVE RP with friends. It isn't the Aurora toolset and some people do miss that possibility the NWN toolset had, but it's easy to roleplay with a live DM just as you would do on the tabletop (which is the actual intent of the DM tools in this game). I repeat: These are not Dev tools like the aurora toolset but DM tools so understand that you are meant to use them as you'd use your modules on the tabletop! You can pause the game to give lengthy explanations, add your own NPCs both friendly to fight by your side, or neutral to stick around idle and just give you quests or even hostile with spawning hordes of enemies to have your friends fight them! As for playing modules without a DM buddy, they are really well made, playable and full of detail, but need work and expanding the tools will in fact make it an even better experience!

N-Space had promised many times on the forums to expand the content of the game and the tools available, and although they closed shop, as of right now, the game stands perfectly on their own!


As for the original campaign, I have to say it's a really solid cohesive experience that lasts about 40-60 hours depending on how much time you spend doing all the puzzles and side-quests (it has great RPG puzzles!). I played the campaign on hard and had a blast just playing through it. Some people prefer some NPCs to others and that's a good thing! The companions are so detailed that you immediatly make favourites out of them! It lacks some secondary quests, which I wouldn't mind having, being as that would expand the main campaign even further in longevity, but as it stands it's SUPER solid and excellent for cooping with friends (yeah, you can coop booth campaigns with up to 3 more friends!)

I absolutely love cRPGs and this game is definetly between the BIG ones!

9.5/10

reviewText:
If you're a fan of Neverwinter, Baldur's Gate, and the like then there are no surprises here.    You build a character, add additional members to your party, beat up kobolds at the behest of farmers, take their lunch money, save the world, rinse and repeat.

In terms of the single player mode, its standard issue adventure that took me about 30 hours to complete with about 90-95% of the quests and items uncovered.   The writing is not breaking any ground, the characters are pleasantly quirky in very predictable ways, the decisions you're asked to make are fairly black & white, you've seen this before.   While the gameplay was enjoyable the story wasn't terribly compelling.  It feels like they wrote standard-issue fantasy tropes on a bunch of sticky notes, plasted them all on a wall, and had someone throw darts while blindfolded.

Gameplay is fairly good and while there's a few interface elements that were confusing at first (they expect you to use the keyboard to control the camera) it works out fairly well.   There are a number of bugs and it felt like it was missing a number of usability features that I would have expected for a game that is not breaking any new ground in terms of interface.

I have not tried the multi-player segment with a dungeon master and there's a possibility that the community will provide far more compelling stories than the single player game through mods.   While I don't recommend it right now it might be worth it in six months when they make some updates and the modder community gets an opportunity to write some content (or port games over from old Neverwinter mods).

reviewText:
What a game and what a shame, that it is getting such bad reviews!

Sadly this is what happens when you hype up a feature of the game, in this case the Campaign building and DM mode, which dont really live up to the hype at the moment. It is still a really solid and easy to use system. I can understand that people are dissapointed in the lack of control over the maps, however who really enjoyed having to build everything manually in Neverwinter Nights? It took such a long time to make anything worthwhile.

The DM mode with Dungeon Crawl is still solid, it is fun and something you can just jump into and enjoy, it is however just a bonus. What really matters in this game is the Story mode and this is where this game shines. It shines like a buffed up baldspot in the setting sun. It is the first game, in its genre,  since Baldur´s Gate 2 to really drag me in and keep me intrigued. The Story, Mechanics and Flow of the Story Campaign is just excellent. Herein also lies the issue, very little marketing was aimed at  the Storymode, to the degree that I almost feel like alot of players might not even have given it a try before reviewing.

tldr; DM mode is not great yet, but it is still under development. Story mode is excellent and a worthy descendant of Baldur´s Gate. Overall this game is a solid buy, that promises many hours of spellbound joy.

reviewText:
Wow the amount of hatred this game gets for NOT BEING another game!
SCL is not Diablo
SCL is not Neverwinter
SCL is SCL.

What you get with this game is a D&D 5th edition based gameplay, with roleplayin opportunity based on the quality of the DM/Campaign you are running.
You also get the opportunity to create the dongeons, campaign, story etc. you want using the toolset used to create the campaign it comes with.

What you do not get with this game is a Hack-and-slash-sub-diablo-game.
You also don't get the nostalgia of Neverwinter because nostalgia is based on the experience you had and what you remember of it, not the actual game you played!

Pro :
Good 5th edition feeling (not the exct copy & paste of the rules, but a fluid in between to fit the actual pace of a video game)
good character creation system, skill use, roleplay possibilities for both the campauign and the DM mode
DM mode alowing creativity of a passive game play OR active DM interaction
Downloadable DM creations for extra replayability of the game you bought with a quality system to save you time between all the community's creations
etc.
pretty great easy/medium/hard system that feels like the adjective used!

Con :
some use & abuse of the system mechanic can make your character brokenly strong at higher level if you entend to do so... blame yourself for doing so, but also the fact that the creator didn't fallow the exact 5th edition system (ex : AC is supposed to be Armor+DEX+ best magic/buff source but instead the system adds bonus, stacking them instead of going for the best one )!
the camera angle is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as it always was (like it was in neverwinter btw)
the ever speaking character that needs to say something whenever you clic to move them (shut it : you're hidden!)

All in all : a good game, great DM mode, not for everyone, but not worth all the not-diablo-yet-too-much-diablo-like-to-be-the-R-in-Rpg" blame
"

reviewText:
This game is excellent. I believe that it is the closest that a computer game has come to replicating a real tabletop d&d experience. There are other tabletop simulators, but they all fail to have matchmaking, which this game has! So let's dive in to why I like this so much amidst a sea of haters.

I'd like to start by mentioning that I am a big D&D fan, used to play 2nd edition through 5th. I will also be honest and say that this game does not capture the true tabletop experience, but what computer game really could?
Pros: 1) DM Mode
2) Matchmaking for DMs and Players
3) Publish and Play your own campaign and the campaigns of others
4) Decent character cusomization
5) Even better NPC customization
6) Decent Quest Creation System, generally works correctly
7) A great fanbase of old school and new fans alike
8) Pause/Play options give the option for more strategic, old school D&D feel
9) Good Story Mode (also unlocks new DM items)
10) Lots of content on release and more on its way regularly
11) Built in push-to-talk communication and typing chat
12) Devs that truly care

Cons: 1) Need some more character customization options
2) Need more character/npc voice options
3) Would love to have the ability to make quest options/ branching quest lines (a tall order, I know)
4) Need open sea tiles! I know they will add them eventually, can't wait. Need ships, ocean, docks, etc.
5) Occasional bugs/glitches, many of which have been fixed already
6) When play testing a campaign module, changes that you make after the play test don't apply to those saves
7) Long wait times for matchmaking, especially as a DM looking for players

Overall, this is an excellent game and I am very glad to have purchased the collector's edition. I am looking forward to playing d&d with tons of friendly new people. Keep in mind that old school players tend to have a playstyle that they prefer, and new players do to (though they may not have found it yet). One must have patience when finding the right people to play d&d with. I am a philosophy major and prefer a more diplomacy-centric and story driven play-style. Fortunately, I am able to find others with similar interests. So keep that in mind, don't play one game and say Those guys were immature ♥♥♥♥♥" and quit. You need to find what playstyle suits you best
date: and find players/DMs that cater well to that style. I will continue updating my reviews as the game progresses
recommended: but I am genuinely thoroughly impressed thus far.\np.s. for people that are saying this game is too hard... there are many ways to fix that. First

reviewText: Alright, it has its ups and downs, but overall it is a pretty good game with alot of potential. I logged 20+ hours in the pre-release and while the content is currently underwhelming; they listen to their community and seem dedicated to building on their preexisting base. For D&D players, (like myself) the mechanics and classes implemented in the game are loose adaptations, not strict copies. Yet the lore is mostly spot on and they do a great job bringing the Swords Coast to life.\n\nThe development team behind the game is quite small, with strong ties to the community. My recomendation is to focus on creating a modding community around the game, so we can help add more unique content to the world. Buy it now, or buy it on sale, its a fun worthwhile experince and a great game to play with friends.

reviewText:
Ok here is what blows my mind.  Every single good dnd video game has 1 major thing in common.  They follow the rules of dnd.  Every failed dnd game also has something in common, they make up their own rules.   Why can they not learn from this.  While yeh the game is still fun, it is no where near what was expected.

Instead of feats and skiills and such you get a warcraft style talent tree.
You dont get all the classes in the book.
You dont get all the races.
You cant multiclass.
Spells are so limited its crazy.  There might be like 20 wizard spells.  No spell slots just all cooldowns.
Honestly the system is more like 4e then 5e.  All the classes have cooldown skills and such,

Whats more discouraging is that while yes they are saying they hear the community and that they are trying to make things better by adding content and drow, They are not doing anything to the real problem.   The core of the game is faulted.

If you are any kind of dnd fan this game is gonna leave you dissapointed.   If you are just looking for an rpg and dont really know much about dnd you may enjoy the game still.

reviewText:
Ive read a lot of the reviews for this game and I dont agree with much of the bad press this game is getting. Personally I like, I like it lots, and Im playing it.

Thats the short review.

Here is the longer review:

Many previous reviews are posted by DnD nerds (like myself) who I believe have unrealistic expectations about the how this product should be. I don't think these expectations marry up with the realities in the gaming market. In short some folk are a bit precious. Any old school gamer expecting an isometric DnD based rpg to have the same impact as early DnD products is never going to be satisfied.

A lot of reviews compare this game to Pillars of Eternity and Divinity Original Sin. I haven't played the latter but the former didn't move me that much. I prefer this game. Not really sure why. I abandoned the PoE campaign, got bored, maybe Ill go back to it one day.

A few re-occurring complaints that I would like to address:

Skill Trees:
+ Are good - they allow people not familiar with 5e to make informed early decisions about the possible roles for different classes and make early decisions about how make characters as effective as possible.
+ Provide the carrot for the next level.
+ DnD 5e uses skill trees for all classes. They just arent obvious and they are much more restrictive. Dont believe me? What is an archetype then?

Ability Cool Down vs Short Rest/Long Rest
+ For those not in the know... DnD 5e uses a mechanic to regain abilities by taking a short or long rest. Cool downs emulate this by having different cool down rates. 20s to 200s are most common. Cantrips normally have 2s cool downs.
+ Resting mechanic in a computer game causes the game to be all about the next rest spot. To stop players hitting the rest button after every combat so they dont just spam their best stuff a control needs to be put in place.
+ The much discussed PoE uses cool downs and they arent fast and limits resting by having allow characters to only carry 4 days of rest supplies. I dont know about anyone else but Ive been tramping/hiking I can carry more then 4 days food AND I dont have 18 strength and a limitless storage box that I can put all the stuff I dont want into (refer again PoE).

Its NOT DnD, its some weird hybrid:
+ I suspect the market for a pure DnD 5e computer game is small. Only real DnDers will buy. Not all DnDers play computer games.
+ 5e has a significant learning curve. You will lose players not familiar with the system. This system is quick to pick up.
+ If PoE branded itself as DnD (which it clearly is a copy of. I wonder if copy write infringement was considered) we would have the same complaints as we are seeing for this product.

Mobs have too many hit points. Spells dont do enough damage:
+ Spells dont do enough damage. I agree.
+ Mobs have too many hit points. I agree.
+ Pure 5e is unforgiving for new players. Surround a character with a low AC with hobgoblins and watch them fall over FAST.
+ High hit points and low damage out put is an industry standard.
+ Effective and scalable AI is too difficult a problem to be financial viable. It's easier to make mobs TUFF.
+ Game difficulty is often controlled by durability of mobs.
+ Almost all isometric rpg games use this mechanism. PoE certainly does. It frustated me, it still frustrates me.

Limited release of classes/races is a ploy to make money
+ Wizards of the Coast are here to make money.
+ You make money by selling stuff.
+ Computer games are expensive to make (dont believe me? Have you looked at the credits? Are you a professional? How much do you get paid?)

Review ends.

reviewText:
This short opinion piece is based on 206 hours of Head Start Access.

Sword Coast Legends does a lot of things right, let's get that in there straight away.

The story mode is excellent, and if you like Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, Divinity Original Sin and Pillars of Eternity you will find a lot to love here, especially the excellently fully voiced critical path through the main story.

Now one of the main selling points of the game has been the DM Editor. (Create your own adventure modules)
The editor started out as a way for groups of people to engage in a 4 & 1 campaign, with a live Dungeon Master, able to possess monsters, NPCs and throw enemies, and treasure at the party in equal measure.

The editor is great for a live DM, with some caveats, you cannot assign specific loot or XP to the party as a DM and monsters will scale to the average level of your group. If that doesn't tickle you, you might be disappointed.

The editor also allows for creators to make their own modules for the community to play, without a live DM, and its here you will find the games main weak point.
There's not a huge amount of available tilesets to choose from, and at the moment, the quest dialogue implementation leaves something to be desired, however these are things that the developers are aware of, and have said they will actively work on improving post-launch.

All in all, is Sword Coast Legends perfect? No, but especially the DM tool is a work in progress and will only get better as time goes by.

A common misconception is people expecting SCL to deliver the level of customizable module making that NWN did,
which it doesn't. It's simpler, much easier to use, but as a consequence, at the moment, its also more limited in scope.

Don't expect the game to be something its not.
With all that said, the 40 hour story mode is easily worth the price of admission.

8/10 for me

The game overall is good. I know some people are disappointed, but it has really good potential. For now I have mostly stuck to single player since a drawback of multiplayer is a mixed bag.  It works if you have a group of friends playing with same mindset  RP vs Hack and slash.  It does not work so well if people randomly put on together without some sort of filter indicating playstyle on the join queue.

one of the things I found lacking is storage or the lack of a stronghold.  There are several instances where a cleared location or house may become a base, but its a lost opportunity on the developer's side. Additionally storage is a major issue. I seem to be a packrat and it defaults on the leader's strength abilities rather than the party members individually (first playthru is a wizard).  Overall the NPCS work well enough and there are quite a few of my favorites.

At its current stage, the game seems more like a diamond in the rough, but as it further develops with the community and game designers, it will really come to shine.

reviewText:
First of all, I've spent about 92 hours on the Head Start Access before the game was released. And I've been playing since Head Start 2 (which was the first time it was released to all pre-orders) and obviously spent a lot of time with the game. Here is my take on the game.

I've spent the most time on the DM creator tool and have already released 2 modules. I have only spent a very minimum amount of time on the story campaign, but what little time I spent on it, was a rather nice experience. Granted, I only completed the start portion of the campaign, so I cannot say how well will it be later on but from most player's thoughts on it, the Story Campaign is a good one.

I'll be focusing more on the module creator and the multiplayer aspect of the game.

First thing's first, as many people have said and will say, the DM creator is incredibly limited. There are no branching dialogues, no item-based interactions (using a key to open a door), no option to edit your dungeons (adding or removing rooms), no manual triggers for certain events (changing a character's hostility after dialogues) and possibly some others. It's true that the DM is very limiting.

BUT!

As limiting as it is, it isn't that bad of an editor to work with. Sure you'll be limited  to bare simple interactions and some simple things may take several turns to do, but it's not impossible to create a narrative-driven module with the current system. It might take a lot more dialogues to get it done, but it's far from impossible. I've played several modules that are very well done and well designed. It's all dependent on how the creator play around with the limitations.

While talking about the limitations, I'll be talking about the DM mode for playing with other players. I've tried DM-ing a few runs with some friends and I can honestly say, some of the limitations of the module creator can be bypassed with the presence of a DM. Having a DM allows a lot of manual changes to be done to the module, from adding or removing monsters, providing extra challenge, changing the hostility of a character at will, adding quests on the fly and changing existing things on the fly. Just like the traditional PnP D&D experience, having a good DM solidifies the experience even more. And the DM mode of Sword Coast Legends was heavily marketed and I personally feel that they've done a pretty decent job doing it. It's fun having an active DM that plays around with group.

That being said, the multiplayer aspect of the game is bad to good, depending on who you play with. For one, Sword Coast Legends has a very bad loot system, where everything is shared. So some players may just run in and grab everything, leaving nothing for you, which is obviously bad. I do not know if they can fix this in the future, but I sure hope they do.

In the early Head Start days, the game was plagued by bad connections. It was almost impossible to play a multiplayer session nicely without some people disconnecting along the way. But over time, they seem to have fixed most of the connection issues, though certain bugs still persists from time to time. Things that can be ironed out with time, and the devs have said they will continue to support the game for quite some time. So give it time.

Again, I haven't really started playing the story campaign, but I'm looking forward to it.

As of now, I would give this game a score of 7/10. But if they add more contents and crush more of the bugs, this could get a good 8 from me. And if they eventually release a more powerful module creator, this may very well be a good 9/10. Because the DM portion of the game, is very good.

If you love classic RPG, this could be a good game for you at its price point. It's also a pretty good D&D themed game, and can only be expanded even more in the future.

reviewText:
I just wanted to tell you that I really like the SP campaign! I'm pleasantly surprised after having played the main story all weekend during the last headstart.

Disregarding some D&D 5th ed. rules liberties taken (This is a computer game, after all), I must say this game really captures that computer game D&D feel well. The atmosphere, the music (Inon Zur), the party bantering, the tone of the story, the narrative and the characters (generous sprinkling of humour, with some story arc golden oldies with a new twist or two), are pretty much spot on and very fun to experience. Sure, most quests are so-called fetch quests, but believe me, I have played all D&D computer games since the early 80's, and the great majority of quests have been that way. For the most part, despite some linearity, the entertainment value and general feel to the game easily outweigh any such basic qualms.

Is this the Forgotten Realms I love? It sure is!

Is this Dungeons & Dragons that I adore? Absolutely!

Do I get to build a character I can cherish and enjoy with a number of fun and interesting companions? Yup!

Also, so far, the bugs have been few and far between, and anything but game breaking.

All in all, this is a huge dollop of D&D CRPG of fun, and a worthy successor of BG and NWN1/2 as far as their single-player OCs go!

The worst negatives, so far, is the monster scaling and the loot abundance, and if you love wizards, you get no spell books, but skill trees like everybody else.

If the toolset, at least later on, allows us to deliver the same kind of fun, this game will hopefully be around for years to come and let the D&D CRPG creative juices flow copiously.

reviewText:
I'm really loving this game. The story is excellent. Very immerssive and it hearkens back to the days of Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale, and Neverwinter Nights I and II. But now, it is even better, because now you can experience it with your friends in co-op!

Highlights (no spoilers). I really like the character creation and the user-interface. Very easy to use and makes for good D&D adventuring. I enjoy the isomorphic view, as it is classic D&D PC gaming at its best. Good for party interaction and quickly switching between characters if playing solo.

Strengths: In addition to the above, I like the quick-play feature of making a dungeon and setting off on a quick dungeon crawl with friends or with strangers from the lobby. The time I did this it was fun and a good time was had by all. Didn't have to wait too long either for the group of four to set out on the adventure.

Obviously, the aforementioned. :)

Weaknesses: None that I really can see at this point! That's a good thing!

Summary: I hope that WotC and the Developers continue to pour out more stories and campaigns, not to mention what the community can put out! Ok, here's a wish of mine I'd love to see fulfilled...a full-scale Waterdeep, mapped out to the n-th degree from the boxed D&D Forgotten Realms pen and paper reference materials! Make that an official request for someone that might have the time to do it.

Regards!

reviewText: Been playing D&D games since 90s like Pools of Darkness and Eye of The Beholder. Best games so far was the Baldur's Gates and Neverwinter Nights's. Maybe they will manage to make this into a decent product, but I think it might take year or two if ever.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY, IT'S A SCHEME.

This game is a multiplayer action RPG under the guise of a CRPG:

- Character classes got nothing in common with original D&D classes except their name: You get a crappy talent system where you level up spells and every spell is cooldown or proc based.

- Combat has nothing in common with D&D: Creatures have way more HP than they're supposed and they hit for far too much unless CC'ed or you got a tank. Turns take about 1 second or less and every character except maybe a shield bearing one in full plate armor is way too squishy and will get eviscerated in 1 second or less. To compensate this, they give you the ability to click-to-res where any character can res another just by clicking on it in 1 second or less so your best combat tactic are RES TRAINS !!!
Also there's no rest and no spell memorization system. Since spells and talents are not D&D based, eventual product of combat including rolls and other stuff (running away in combat actaully works!) has nothing to do with D&D either therefore causing attributes to lose meaning, not that you had much say on those creating a character (can't put less than 8 in any attribute).

- Questing are like of a generic MMO, grocery list style. Except attribute-check dialog options, you literally have no other options except talking with the NPC that has a ! sign on its head and even then, dialogue options are limited and generally doesn't back your alignment specific actions.

- Co-op multiplayer is a mess: When played with 2 people, host controls 3 characters and guest controls 1 which is a total failure since one guy has to control 3x the amount of characters in a realtime game which causes one guy in a position to do a lot of stuff in a short duration while the other waits. You can't change control of companions. Also host decides every dialogue option related to main story while the guest is only watching. Guest can only interact with side-quests or vendors. Also pause system with short rounds is a total mess.

- Friendly AI is a mess with no way to set it up how you want it to play: Characters in your party will keep on casting random stuff if you don't micro-manage their every action and you have no control over it,

- DM Mode dungeon crawl is an original idea but seeing where the DM is really kills all the immersion.

TLDR; Do not buy, go purchase Divinity: Original Sin instead if you wanna have co-op campaign fun or play an actual mmo if you wanna do Dungeon Crawl.

reviewText: This game can be fun sometimes, but is a perfect example of soulless marketing to make a buck. It might not warrant such negativity if it didn't claim to be something it's not, and then perhaps people would have a case saying some are being overly critical, but this game has D&D in the title and nowhere in the game. Done to death skill trees, limited class options, module creating tools that aren't close to Neverwinter Nights, and limited character options place SCL solidly in role-playing light, action RPG genre, of which there are hordes to choose from.\nThe main story is entertaining and fairly well written, and of course playable with friends of your choosing, but true role-playing in the rest of the game is severly absent. From what I've heard of creating your own modules, player characters don't get to say anything beyond we accept" or "not right now
date: how the heck do you create a story doing that? Unless the game adds a lot of free conentto open up possible creativity with it, I can't give it a positive.

I was eyeing this game for a while, and when it had a free weekend I had to give it a try.

I'm glad I got to try it for free, because the hour I spent with the game was a complete waste.  I wanted to try the GM mode, so I set up a game and waited for players. Alright, I'll recruit some friends and we can play together!  No, I spent the last twenty minutes getting repeatedly disconnect from the servers.

So, based on my experience not getting to play the game, I'm not going to recommend it.  The community isn't there and the servers are unreliable, which is a real shame.

reviewText:
I never write reviews, but, to warn those who may purchase this game in the future, i'll make an exception. I was able to try this game (briefly) during a free weekend. The game was on sale 50% off, and I had considered buying recently when it was on sale 40%. I pretty much like every DND based game, so even though the reviews where not great, I was going to give it a chance. Luckily, I got busy and missed the sale, and then right after they had it on sale for 50% off with a free weekend to try it out!! Awesome, the game can't be that bad if they are letting you try it first!!

I must admit to some bias here. I do not like the new dnd rules with trees much like WoW. I liked second edition more, and even D&D Onlines change over to 3rd edition+ was annoying for me. That being said, it was not the character development and ruleset etc that turned me off as much as the tons of glitches, problems with the map, and game bugs. I had 2 game breaking bugs within minutes of startup, and barely got past the very start because the map decided to jump far away in the first area, and wouldn't let me click anywhere to get my character to leave etc.

I did.....finally...figure a way out (actually still not even sure what I did...but somehow it moved me to the next area) and was able to play. I'm also not a fan of controling groups of characters, although some games like dungeon siege II have done it very well. I did not feel like this game did it well, or that you had any real feeling of playing a dnd character (again it felt much like playing a bunch of difference classes from WoW at once, from a different perspective. I might mention I am not a fan of WoW or the clones and hate that it has spread into other genres at this point.

I will say that I only played for an hour or two at most, and just gave up. I didn't like the game at all, and was VERY happy I did not purchase it. Maybe it will improve in the future, but I strongly suggest not purchasing it unless you can try it first. If they have a demo, and they drastically improve the game, then maybe it will be worth picking up sometime. For now, even for die hard dnd fans (seriously I've played just about every DnD game and enjoyed almost all of them at least to some extent), I would pass on this game. There are better free to play dnd games out there (WAY BETTER). It's sad, but honestly I would rather go back and play my NWN games (or never winter online), then this game.

Even the few maps that were held back are not even randomizable...you will do the same city scene...over and over and over and over....I honestly was expecting a lot more from this product....No branching dialogue....No Necromancy "Skill tree" for players.   they need to change the wording of their Necromance with the heart of gold to "Big Fail incoming guys!"   The lies....the lies....it is staggering.   The only reason they held back the DM mode for HS5 was becasue they knew...they KNEW!   there is nothing of spoiler or substance....maybe ellysium?  Which looks straight out of a rip off of Diablo III????\n\nNothing like BG or Neverwinter.....Nothing like D&D for that matter.    There are talent trees instead of spell books.   there is scaling enemies that will always be just as strong as you are...meaning you gain a level

votesTotal: not my skill.   you can resurect a fallen ally at any time by any character.  there is no need for a raise dead spell....So I don't even know why they put it in there...There are no need for temples
votesFunny: no need for taverns since there are no spells in a spell book to memorize...Instead you talent into Magic Missle 1...then into Magic Missle 2...and so on.\n\nThere's no feeling of progression.  There is no custom Items for you to reward your players with....pretty much killing their reason to even go on adventures.  The maps are all pre fabricated....And worst butcher of all was the idea to cross platform this game with Console.  So now
commentsCount: all the old BG and Neverwinter fans that were looking for what SCL promised will get a gauntlet style play mixed with Diablo and Warcraft style mechanics.\n\nThe DM mode which should have been awesome has been restricted to meaningless nothing.   No one will really want to play online with random people anyway
column16:
and this is what is forced down our throats....Let people find and play with people they enjoy playing with.  Don't make all these rules for pug and pick up play and force it on everyone.  Almost no one will really want to DM for strangers.  Let them have full control of the DM tools...But this is meant for cross platform.  It feels like Mario maker meets medieval Contra.
There are no penalties for dying.  Just respawn at the back of the cave and zerg the place again and again....same with traps....why bother looking for them.  With your heals on Cool down and no real risk at all...just run them over and kill the same end boss over and over even if you are level 1....thats right.  scaling means you fight dragons at level 1 and win....yay...Immersion.    BG had a PC version (AWESOME)  and a Console version (Also awesome)   Why were they both awesome?  BECASUSE THEY WERE DESIGNED TO UTILIZE THE BEST OF THE PLATFORM THEY ARE ON!    Not to toss the best away and mix in a bunch of garbage to fit the other.

Again
column17:
butchering what could have been an indepth meaningful Dungeons and Dragons experience so they can attempt to force more random people to play together by cross platforming (Because clearly you can't make friends on your own)  you now get to interact with all those kids looking to impart their 16 years of wisdom of working the 7-11 or living in their mothers basement....Wisdom such as "YOU MAD BRO?"  or "You are totally a NOOB....My Cleric was LEET before ur mamma got PHAT!" Oh the joy...

I know I'll be doing a lot of QQing for all the lost potential this game had...Perhaps in the future they will make a D&D game...I don't know...D&D.  And leave the cross platform dumbed down Guantlet boring old hack n Slash at the door.

The story is pretty solid at least so far....Maybe a 1 weekend wonder then to the shelf as a place holder for real future D&D games.....If you enjoy being lied to
column18: if you enjoy getting left over scraps to play with from the Devs....If you really enjoyed the days of gauntlet and would love to relive that...over and over in SCL...then yes..This is the game for you."
