reviewText:
so, i'm returning it after i write this

it's advertised as being mechanically a real-time conversion of dnd 5e, and it just has absolutely nothing to do with the 5e rules at all. it seems like no one who worked on it even read the 5e rules. every design decision i've seen so far is like, actively going against the design ideas that 5e is centered around. for example, there's an ability you can get as a paladin at level 1 that gives your whole party +4 to attack and saves, essentally all the time. one of the most central parts of 5e is bounded accuracy, where even a +1 bonus to hit is supposed to be really significant and hard to come by.

the character creation ui is literally the worst ui design i've ever seen in like 15 years of playing video games and using software. it's unusable. it's so bad that they somehow made character creation, which is usually one of the most fun parts of dnd-related things, absolutely miserable, and impossible to even do without consulting the wiki. let's say you're deciding what race/background to play. there's absolutely no indication of the mechanical effects of each race/background on the screen you choose them on. you can go to the attrubute selection tab to check, and go back, and do this for each of the twenty or so backgrounds, and hope you remember them all. the non-attribute bonuses of races and classes (like movement speed bonuses for wood elves and stuff) apparently can't be found anywhere in the ui as far as i can tell? or they actually aren't in the game, and the wiki is wrong? character creation isn't the thing you have to do before you start the game". it's supposed to be fun!

all of the writing so far is like
date: aggressively mediocre. maybe i'm spoiled by undertale
recommended: but i'm just floored by how much i don't care about all the characters so far and how much i want to skip the dialogue (which
hoursPlayed: for the voice acted parts
voteText: you can't). so far i've been drowned by an overwhelming flood of side quests that no one will ever care about. like

reviewText:
I..  I didn't want to.  I had so much hope.  I honestly don't want to recommend the game.

I've read alot of the reviews and I haven't see anyone mention stat stacking.

Great concept and I can live with the bugs hell every game has bugs. It's the stat stacking.  When a lvl 20 rogue has 50 dex and wears light armor everyone else can stay at the entrance of the dungeon and cook dinner while the rogue takes everything out. Very unbalanced.

If they removed attribute points from items all together it may help correct this issue. Other stats seem relatively balanced but the attribute stacking makes rogues and dex fighters extremely over powered and clerics / wizards relatively useless.

Surely someone noticed this. Stacking the attributes such as Dex increases the to hit, damage, and AC for the character and the poor str fighter back here has a low AC because he's in plate and not light.

Hope I made some sense.

reviewText: I wanted so bad to like this game.   It had all the things that could be good in a D&D franchise game:   group play,  DM controlled environments, making your own dungeons,  Build your own characters, etc.    Unfortunately it does almost all of these somewhere between average and poorly.  The only thng that seems to run well is the group play but so far I haven't found a good group to play with.  Combat is frustrating as can be.  It's a weird mix of having to pause the game to give orders and then your hero running too fast doing that action then jumping into AI controlled mode very poorly so you are constantly having to micro manage everything they do.  Add to that underwhelming spells, abilities and even most monsters and it is more frustrating then entertaining.\n\nMaybe with a few major updates this could have potential but I feel I've wasted 40$ so far.  I played for about 3 hours and got bored and have never reloaded.   I hope they add some major upgrades to make this thing into something people would want to play.

reviewText:
I was eyeing this game for a while, and when it had a free weekend I had to give it a try.

I'm glad I got to try it for free, because the hour I spent with the game was a complete waste.  I wanted to try the GM mode, so I set up a game and waited for players.  After thirty minutes nobody had tried to join my game.  Alright, that's fine, I figured I'd go join a game that was GM'ed.  I got booted from every game I joined moments after joining them.

Alright, I'll recruit some friends and we can play together!  No, I spent the last twenty minutes getting repeatedly disconnect from the servers.

So, based on my experience not getting to play the game, I'm not going to recommend it.  The community isn't there and the servers are unreliable, which is a real shame.

reviewText:
I'm really loving this game. The story is excellent. Very immerssive and it hearkens back to the days of Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale, and Neverwinter Nights I and II. But now, it is even better, because now you can experience it with your friends in co-op!

Highlights (no spoilers). I really like the character creation and the user-interface. Very easy to use and makes for good D&D adventuring. I enjoy the isomorphic view, as it is classic D&D PC gaming at its best. Good for party interaction and quickly switching between characters if playing solo.

Strengths: In addition to the above, I like the quick-play feature of making a dungeon and setting off on a quick dungeon crawl with friends or with strangers from the lobby. The time I did this it was fun and a good time was had by all. Didn't have to wait too long either for the group of four to set out on the adventure.

Obviously, the aforementioned. :)

Weaknesses: None that I really can see at this point! That's a good thing!

Summary: I hope that WotC and the Developers continue to pour out more stories and campaigns, not to mention what the community can put out! Ok, here's a wish of mine I'd love to see fulfilled...a full-scale Waterdeep, mapped out to the n-th degree from the boxed D&D Forgotten Realms pen and paper reference materials! Make that an official request for someone that might have the time to do it.

Regards!
voteText: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sword Coast Legends is not Baulder's Gate, but that is BY NO MEANS A BAD THING!!! It takes it's own, different twist on the RPG style from previous D&D games and I like that about it. The combat is fast, punchy, satisfying and looks great. The loot is varied and worth searching for. The environments are beautifully crafted and look awesome. The quests aren't anything to write home about, basically your standard RPG affair, but at least they're engaging so you don't lose interest. Overall I think it's a great game, and if you're going into it hoping for Bauldur's gate, you're going to be dissappointed, but if you look at it as  completely seperate game with new and different features (which it is! is it called Baulder's gate 3? NO!) you're definitely going to get a lot of enjoyment out of it.

This isn't a perfect game though. My main complaint is that it seems to have trouble running on my computer, which isn't really the game's fault, but If I can run Alien Isolation on almost max settings, I don't know why this game's frame rate dropps to 2 fps if the graphics are anything higher than the lowest possible settings. The other minor complaint I have is that your chracter says some dumb remark LITERALLY every single time you click to move. It's sooo anoying. If you're like me, you don't click terribly far away when you're waliking, because you want to see everything and search for loot, so every two seconds my paladin's saying As you wish" or "I can do that". It gets really old really fast.

Those problems aside
date: I still love this game. It's a great RPG and I can't wait to sink even more hours of my free time into it."

reviewText:
Been playing the campaign with 3 other friends over a weekend and a few extra nights. I found the SCL experience relatively close to (at least my memory of) how we, in a similar setup, played Baldur's Gate as co-op.

I must say, I really enjoyed the game as a whole. I like the stories and the dialog with the NPCs. Only a single very annoying drawback: Every time you talk to an NPC, be it a merchant or a quest type NPC, the game pauses for everyone in the party and you are (almost all the time) teleported directly to the speaker. This mechanic surely needed some 'getting use to', but we accepted it in the end.

If you are 2+ friends looking for some adventure? Get it!
voteText: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game was disappointing. Asides from the dull graphics and the vetigo-inducing, unchanging perspective, which makes tactical combat and working out the occasional puzzles more difficult than needed, the gameplay is just boring. It plays like a sub-standard Diablo, yet lacked excitement. The gameplay of the solo game was so disappointing, it put me off trying the multiplayer version.
In the solo campaign, the game's writers seemed to use the Fantasy section of tvtropes.com as a guideline: heavy drinking dwarf CHECK, nicer-than-nice elf CHECK, good priests being evil CHECK (also a plot device from the original Neverwinter Nights).
For those who are expecting a new Dungeons and Dragons game will be disappointed. The gameplay is standard MMORPG, similar to Dungeons and Dragons Online, and the only connection to D&D's Forgotten Realms world is cosmetic.
Essentially, if you want a great fantasy MMORPG, there are many others to play. If you want a great D&D solo RPG, there's Neverwinter Nights and the enhanced Baldur's Gates. Don't bother with this one: it'll just encourage game companies to keep publishing substandard fare.

reviewText:
So I'm a huge D&D fan and downloaded this game to play for the free weekend, played for a while and then I forgot what this game was and why I had it installed. That tells you how forgettable this game is.

The character creation is excellent, I like the skill system and sadly that's about it. The story is really generic, the combat is the worst part, it's really boring and monotonous, everything is based on cooldowns. So combat is basically auto attacking and waiting to spam cooldowns, thats it. The other huge problem is the online component. Every online game is DM based so when you get online you have to pray that all the stars align to get a decent DM who builds a decent map/story. good luck with that.

tl;dr Not a terrible game, just really mediocre. I would reccomend it if you see it on sale for 15$ or less and you're a HUGE fan of D&D, but even then, there are much better games out there for cheaper, I recommend Divinity Original Sin or Baldurs Gate instead

date: who this character was that I could not switch out

Maybe with some support and patched this could turn into a good game but as it is this just feels like a 1st draft of a good game."

reviewText:
I really really wanted to like this game. I grew up with AD&D, and I'm a big RPG fan. I mostly play RPGs on consoles now, but complicated ones like Baulders Gate I loved on the PC.

I was willing to forgive some of the art because the overall look of the game is pretty poor. I kept telling myself, it's going to be ok if the gameplay was solid.

I gave Sword Coast a try, and I found I could not get into it. For starters, Character creation itself needs a bunch of work. Having to sign up was already really awkward. There should always be a text box up at one of the sides to explain everything rather than having to mousing over to read a popup every time. Things were already looking rough, and I used to find huge enjoyment in D&D character creation.

I found gameplay chaotic for a D&D style game. Playing the generated simple dungeon with just my character taught me so much more than the little bit of story I played. When you have 4 characters in the story doing random things, I could not follow what was going on, and I was just playing it like a poor man's Diablo. The characters were made to be a selling point, but I really hated all of the ones I met. The single player just threw a dozen random characters that I really didn't care for into the story with very little character building, and I found no connection with any of them.

The controls are not explained. I had to guess how to bring up inventory, save a game, move the map around as I was walking. I was expecting the screen to scroll with my mouse even.

I can't bring myself to play anymore. Sorry to everyone trying to defend the game, but It really failed all my expectations.    At least there was a free weekend before I spent any actual money on it. I am still hoping whoever is enjoying the game gets the right patches to help their experience.

reviewText:
I'm really digging the campaign.  I'm running solo, but it allows 4 co-op.

Drow darkness, duergar enlarge, umber hulks confuse, succubi seduce, demons summon, ooze immunities.  The ability to DM created modules for friends is awesome.  This is D&D without the table.

The build tools are a bit limited for creating a module that does not require a DM.  There are many work-arounds for said limitations and I find myself adapting my adventure to circumvent those limitations.

All in all, I'm having a blast with this title; running the campaign, creating my own adventure, and already cannot wait for more!

reviewText:
In theory, the game sounds great since I'm a big fan of the original neverwinter nights (not the MMO, the one that came out the the 2000s). However, in practice, things are a bit more lackluster. While I'm getting a definite NWN vibe, the controls for movement feel laggy and clunky. There's a decent bit of delay between clicking, the target circle showing up, and the characters actually moving. It jut doesn't feel as responsive as it could be.

The camera controls are also a bit annoying. Intuitively, one would think that moving the cursor to the edges of the screen would cause the camera to move when it's not actively following the characters. Nope. WASD. Very frustrating.

The story seems to be the usual fantasy fare, but it wasn't enough to really grab my attention. In NWN, you're essentially thrown into things. You're training at a guild that's safeguarding magical animals to help try and stop a plague that's ravaging the city of Neverwinter. Immediately, you know there's big stuff going down. SCL? So, I'm in a guild and I'm escorting a caravan and been having nightmares. Ok.

I will say that I liked the enviroments and the character customization. It was realtivly painfree to create my character, and I like that there was enough explaination that I knew what each option would do. Handy since I've never played a DnD tabletop game and only know the bare basics about it.

Overall, the game isn't bad, but it's not great. It's just kind of...Meh. Not really a game I'd recommend buying unless it heavily goes on sale.

reviewText: I don't recommend this game. I gave it a shot and it just falls on its face. The RPG elements are about as deep as a puddle and the quests are boring. The story elements are stolen from other games that were made far better than this. The DM tools are abhorrent. I did have some fun with dungeon crawling but it gets very repetitive. There simply are not enough options for the DM and as a player the skill/spell system lacks diversity. There are too many problems with this game to get into each one individually... I'm just glad I got to try out the game so I wouldn't have wasted my money on it...

reviewText: Not a strong entry into the D&D canon.  I bought the game because I loved the concept ... an isometric Baldur's Gate experience that you could mod like Neverwinter Nights.  This game failed to deliver on the first part of that formula with cartoonish graphics, only a loose adherence to the D&D ruleset and a single player campaign that lacked any serious depth.  I didn't get too much into the create your own dungeon" because of my disappointment with the core game.  To be honest
date: I don't know why WoC doesn't just hire Bioware to update Neverwinter Nights or get Black Isle to do a third installment in the Baldur's Gate series.  The re-releases of Baldur's Gate are doing well
recommended: Pillars of Eternity was a success and the modding communities for Neverwiner Nights are still clinging to the Aurora Engine because nothing better has come along.  D&D fans want to give their money to someone but they deserve better than this."

Story is mostly boring, although some small moments were entertaining.  I found that slogging through the linear levels was not rewarding enough to justify the time. All of these things are done better even in B grade budget titles.

And why should I be timed out of my own single player game for being afk?  Bizarre design decisions abound.

The game isn't TERRIBLE.  Just... not worth playing -- let alone buying.

reviewText: I've only played a little just because I wanted to see during the free to play weekend how the game handled and if it was any good, but from what I've experienced I dont want to try anymore.\nThe controls are extremely clunky, you control the map with asdw but your charachter is point and click, dragging the mouse across the screen doesnt move the map, the point and click movement doesnt feel natural and is sometimes hard to get your person exactly where you want them the first time, all the skills and attributes have perks and descriptions but to view them you have to hover over it making selecting your attributes a long arduous process.\nIf you want a D&D experience where you'll actually have freedom of actions and not feel like you're moving at a snails pace because you have to point and click where to walk, play D&D at home with friends. If you want a Diablo like game that's slower paced, has longish unskippable conversations once you start them with few limited options and very linear design once your on the path you've selected for your charachter, this game will be fine.

reviewText:
I started playing this game together with a friend and we went with the dungeon crawl option, mainly because that seemed the most fun to us.

The game, however, was lackluster and we quickly grew frustrated with the early game difficulty, seeing as you start at level 1 (Duh.) and have about 8 to 13 HP. Normally this is fine and all because in D&D you start out fighting small threats, which have about as much HP and damage potential as you do.

But we quickly found out that the starting bandits and the like have up to 50 HP and we did about 3 to 12 damage if we got a lucky hit in.

I would caution people interested in D&D and it's universe and already know some of it. This game is NOTHING like D&D, it is an Action-Dungeon Crawler, not a RPG.

The reasons for this are as follows:

The Combat feels floaty and not at all like D&D should feel. You have no feed back on your hits or misses, you don't know how high your roll was, you ust sometimes see damage come up.

The Leveling System feels odd, and not at all like D&D is supposed to go. You start with a few abilities and as you level you unlock the possibility of more skills, but you only have a limited point system to get your skills, unlike D&D where you get a certain skill each level and/or every few levels.

The loot system is awkward, there is no rhyme or reason readily available why something that is clearly worth 250 or so gold pieces is only worth about 50 gold pieces when you sell it to a vendor. Why even bother letting us know it's true value?

Obviously, the Dungeon Crawl mode has little room for Role Playing, but even outside of it, it is simple dialogue options and no visasble skill checks, like in D&D


TL:DR version.

Do not buy unless it is 5 euros or less.

It is nothing like D&D and is lacking in good interface or combat or RP gameplay.

reviewText:
Is a bit like mixing Diablo with NWN2.

I have played it until I finished Act I. The story has a tendency to be tedious and boring, but isn't the worst I ever saw. The system is rather limited, in that skills, feats, and spells are munched together into the same skill tree, with no class mixing. All skills are cooldown-based, with all classes playing out fairly similarly. Every class can be trained to bear any weapon or wear any armor, or take over the more common portion of a rogue's skillset. Then again searching for traps is not as necessary anymore, what with the abundance of healing spells that kick in the second you take damage from a trap; but there are quite a few secrets on the maps, so having e.g. a cleric in the team with some searching/lockpicking skills is useful.
Skills almost always come in multiple efficiency levels, which often can be bought with little or no level restriction. My cleric had his primary healing spell maxed out at lvl 2. Maxed out meaning there will not be a more efficient healing spell for him. Not at lvl3 and not at lvl 100, if it goes that far. I find this a bit weird, to say the least.

Looks better and runs a lot more stable than nwn2, though. You could buy this if it goes down to 10 bugs. Not recommended before then.

reviewText: I played this game during the free weeekend after letting it brew on my wishlist for awhile, and this is the conclusion I came to:\nI find it very hard not to recommend this game. It came down to the fact that if you want a D&D game that lets you choose tactics and really get immersed in your unit you should pick up Dragon Age:Origins instead. SCL has a lot going on, plenty of quests, lots of varied enemies, but ultimately the combat was the devisive point. There is no way to create battle formations or queue up your parties abilities so you can layer your attacks and heals, it's all on autopilot except for the unit you are currently commanding, so It just turns into a clickfest. It's a fun clickfest, but it's not as good as it could be. I'd say wait until this game drops below ten bucks and you won't feel ripped off.

reviewText: I wanted so bad to like this game.   It had all the things that could be good in a D&D franchise game:   group play,  DM controlled environments, making your own dungeons,  Build your own characters, etc.    Unfortunately it does almost all of these somewhere between average and poorly.  The only thng that seems to run well is the group play but so far I haven't found a good group to play with.  Combat is frustrating as can be.  It's a weird mix of having to pause the game to give orders and then your hero running too fast doing that action then jumping into AI controlled mode very poorly so you are constantly having to micro manage everything they do.  Add to that underwhelming spells, abilities and even most monsters and it is more frustrating then entertaining.\n\nMaybe with a few major updates this could have potential but I feel I've wasted 40$ so far.  I played for about 3 hours and got bored and have never reloaded.   I hope they add some major upgrades to make this thing into something people would want to play.

reviewText:
I'm really loving this game. The story is excellent. Very immerssive and it hearkens back to the days of Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale, and Neverwinter Nights I and II. But now, it is even better, because now you can experience it with your friends in co-op!

Highlights (no spoilers). I really like the character creation and the user-interface. Very easy to use and makes for good D&D adventuring. I enjoy the isomorphic view, as it is classic D&D PC gaming at its best. Good for party interaction and quickly switching between characters if playing solo.

Strengths: In addition to the above, I like the quick-play feature of making a dungeon and setting off on a quick dungeon crawl with friends or with strangers from the lobby. The time I did this it was fun and a good time was had by all. Didn't have to wait too long either for the group of four to set out on the adventure.

Obviously, the aforementioned. :)

Weaknesses: None that I really can see at this point! That's a good thing!

Summary: I hope that WotC and the Developers continue to pour out more stories and campaigns, not to mention what the community can put out! Ok, here's a wish of mine I'd love to see fulfilled...a full-scale Waterdeep, mapped out to the n-th degree from the boxed D&D Forgotten Realms pen and paper reference materials! Make that an official request for someone that might have the time to do it.

Regards!

reviewText:
Sword Coast Legends is not Baulder's Gate, but that is BY NO MEANS A BAD THING!!! It takes it's own, different twist on the RPG style from previous D&D games and I like that about it. The combat is fast, punchy, satisfying and looks great. The loot is varied and worth searching for. The environments are beautifully crafted and look awesome. The quests aren't anything to write home about, basically your standard RPG affair, but at least they're engaging so you don't lose interest. Overall I think it's a great game, and if you're going into it hoping for Bauldur's gate, you're going to be dissappointed, but if you look at it as  completely seperate game with new and different features (which it is! is it called Baulder's gate 3? NO!) you're definitely going to get a lot of enjoyment out of it.

This isn't a perfect game though. My main complaint is that it seems to have trouble running on my computer, which isn't really the game's fault, but If I can run Alien Isolation on almost max settings, I don't know why this game's frame rate dropps to 2 fps if the graphics are anything higher than the lowest possible settings. The other minor complaint I have is that your chracter says some dumb remark LITERALLY every single time you click to move. It's sooo anoying. If you're like me, you don't click terribly far away when you're waliking, because you want to see everything and search for loot, so every two seconds my paladin's saying As you wish" or "I can do that". It gets really old really fast.

Those problems aside
date: I still love this game. It's a great RPG and I can't wait to sink even more hours of my free time into it."

reviewText:
I played for the free weekend and only the campaign.

Pros:
+The cooldown system for spells and abilities is nice.
+No significant bugs found.
+Battle as a whole feels smooth.
+Stash chest is shared between all your characters, allowing you to have fun as soon as you make a new character.

Cons:
-The main storyline is kind of a cliche. Prophetic, apocalyptic dreams. Is that the best they can come up with?
-Character races and classes are severely limited. No half-orcs. No bards. No half-orc bards. No dual/multi classing.
-Crowd control is severely overpowered. I could stun some bosses.
-Companions don't have enough banter and situation specific banter. One character is a racist (Understandably explained) and I made a new character of that specific race and received no reaction.
-Weapons types have no distinction. The only real question is if it's a one hand or two hand weapon and if it's a finesse or regular weapon.
-Character building system is simplistic. You see a skill, you take a skill. Not much room for creative building or unique synergy.

The game is a simplistic and plain. Lacking nuance and spice to make it really really nice. If it relies on it's dungeon master mechanic to make really nice campaigns, I would consider such a thing a sloppy choice by the creators. I cannot recommend this at $40. I would only consider it at $10 or less.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, but it fell feels very basic and unfinished to me. It should be noted that I only played the singleplayer campaign for some hours however.  All things considered, it was a decently interesting storyline, I actually want to finish the game, but I wouldn't pay anywhere near the price they ask. Which is a shame really. I do like the setting and was hoping for something more similar to previous games set in it.


Some negative aspects of the game as I found it:

- Wonky and tedious camera controls which i simply could not get used to which ruined some level of immersion for me.
- Unclear quest objectives which needed googling (sometimes you can clear an area, get a quest and need to backtrack to a place you already cleared where now a new mob has spawned, or an item has become interactive).
- Dull bestiary with the same art for all mobs in a cateogy. And no entries at all for many things.
- Lack of fluff in the world. I just found one thing while exploring, a boars head which had a funny text when clicked.
- Lack of customisation of characters and classes.
- Oversimplified combatsystem where everything has a cooldowntimer, ending up not feeling right.
- It's not a perticularly good looking game, ingame models are thick and basic without much in ways of detail.
- Some sloppy mapping. A hand full of areas were easely recognizable as carbon copies of one another.
- A bit nonsensical scaling of mobs. Rats were harder to kill than vampires.

reviewText:
I played this game during a free weekend.
I know I didn't play long but that was because I couldn't take the game any longer.

I wish I could like this game. I really do. This was such a massive disapointment.
There are little things everywhere that annoy me, like not being able to adjust mouse sensitivity or change the mouse buttons, or not being able to zoom in and see the characters up close... sometimes I got the feeling that the reason why we can't zoom in is so that we can't see how bad the models and animations are.
I could be wrong but this is the impression that the game left on me.

And then there is the rules system. I'm sorry but this doesn't look like D&D at all.

I think the developers of this game should take a look at Divinity: Original Sin.
Despite not being a D&D game I find it far more enjoyable.
That includes all aspects of the game. Graphics, interface, controls, combat system...

I'm sorry but saddly I'm gona have to give this game a thumbs down :(

reviewText:
My negative recommendation for this game is not related to gameplay mechanics. I mostly enjoyed the section of the game I suffered though. My problems lie elsewhere:

Substantial technical problems.

I have a rig far above the recommended specs, but I'm still running into major issues with frame rate, and even more annoying issues with absurd loading times (90 seconds to 2 minutes to load a save from in game? 2-3 mins from main menu? Da hell???).  Not sure why Mass Effect 3 and Witcher 3 run smooth as silk (and load too quick to read load screens) and this completely average looking game drops down to 15-20 fps in any outdoor environment, regardless of what I set the video options to. (And yes, I also tried playing with/disabling audio sections, eliminating sound as a possible memory drain)

This is frustrating, as the game overall seemed like a pretty decent romp through the sword coast. Sure, as an old-school D&D nerd it was a shock and a slight disappointment at how simplified the gameplay and tactical aspects were. However, I had read reviews of the game beforehand, and knew to expect massive changes. As some have said/implied, a general dumbing down" of some rather important D&D mechanics. And the difficulty is a JOKE

Again

reviewText:
so, i'm returning it after i write this

it's advertised as being mechanically a real-time conversion of dnd 5e, and it just has absolutely nothing to do with the 5e rules at all. it seems like no one who worked on it even read the 5e rules. every design decision i've seen so far is like, actively going against the design ideas that 5e is centered around. for example, there's an ability you can get as a paladin at level 1 that gives your whole party +4 to attack and saves, essentally all the time. one of the most central parts of 5e is bounded accuracy, where even a +1 bonus to hit is supposed to be really significant and hard to come by.

the character creation ui is literally the worst ui design i've ever seen in like 15 years of playing video games and using software. it's unusable. it's so bad that they somehow made character creation, which is usually one of the most fun parts of dnd-related things, absolutely miserable, and impossible to even do without consulting the wiki. let's say you're deciding what race/background to play. there's absolutely no indication of the mechanical effects of each race/background on the screen you choose them on. you can go to the attrubute selection tab to check, and go back, and do this for each of the twenty or so backgrounds, and hope you remember them all. the non-attribute bonuses of races and classes (like movement speed bonuses for wood elves and stuff) apparently can't be found anywhere in the ui as far as i can tell? or they actually aren't in the game, and the wiki is wrong? character creation isn't the thing you have to do before you start the game". it's supposed to be fun!

all of the writing so far is like

reviewText:
I..  I didn't want to.  I had so much hope.  I honestly don't want to recommend the game.

I've read alot of the reviews and I haven't see anyone mention stat stacking.

Great concept and I can live with the bugs hell every game has bugs. It's the stat stacking.  When a lvl 20 rogue has 50 dex and wears light armor everyone else can stay at the entrance of the dungeon and cook dinner while the rogue takes everything out. Very unbalanced.

If they removed attribute points from items all together it may help correct this issue. Other stats seem relatively balanced but the attribute stacking makes rogues and dex fighters extremely over powered and clerics / wizards relatively useless.

Surely someone noticed this. Stacking the attributes such as Dex increases the to hit, damage, and AC for the character and the poor str fighter back here has a low AC because he's in plate and not light.

Hope I made some sense.

reviewText: I wanted so bad to like this game.   It had all the things that could be good in a D&D franchise game:   group play,  DM controlled environments, making your own dungeons,  Build your own characters, etc.    Unfortunately it does almost all of these somewhere between average and poorly.  The only thng that seems to run well is the group play but so far I haven't found a good group to play with.  Combat is frustrating as can be.  It's a weird mix of having to pause the game to give orders and then your hero running too fast doing that action then jumping into AI controlled mode very poorly so you are constantly having to micro manage everything they do.  Add to that underwhelming spells, abilities and even most monsters and it is more frustrating then entertaining.\n\nMaybe with a few major updates this could have potential but I feel I've wasted 40$ so far.  I played for about 3 hours and got bored and have never reloaded.   I hope they add some major upgrades to make this thing into something people would want to play.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, but it fell feels very basic and unfinished to me. It should be noted that I only played the singleplayer campaign for some hours however.  All things considered, it was a decently interesting storyline, I actually want to finish the game, but I wouldn't pay anywhere near the price they ask. Which is a shame really. I do like the setting and was hoping for something more similar to previous games set in it.


Some negative aspects of the game as I found it:

- Wonky and tedious camera controls which i simply could not get used to which ruined some level of immersion for me.
- Unclear quest objectives which needed googling (sometimes you can clear an area, get a quest and need to backtrack to a place you already cleared where now a new mob has spawned, or an item has become interactive).
- Dull bestiary with the same art for all mobs in a cateogy. And no entries at all for many things.
- Lack of fluff in the world. I just found one thing while exploring, a boars head which had a funny text when clicked.
- Lack of customisation of characters and classes.
- Oversimplified combatsystem where everything has a cooldowntimer, ending up not feeling right.
- It's not a perticularly good looking game, ingame models are thick and basic without much in ways of detail.
- Some sloppy mapping. A hand full of areas were easely recognizable as carbon copies of one another.
- A bit nonsensical scaling of mobs. Rats were harder to kill than vampires.

reviewText:
I played this game during a free weekend.
I know I didn't play long but that was because I couldn't take the game any longer.

I wish I could like this game. I really do. This was such a massive disapointment.
There are little things everywhere that annoy me, like not being able to adjust mouse sensitivity or change the mouse buttons, or not being able to zoom in and see the characters up close... sometimes I got the feeling that the reason why we can't zoom in is so that we can't see how bad the models and animations are.
I could be wrong but this is the impression that the game left on me.

And then there is the rules system. I'm sorry but this doesn't look like D&D at all.

I think the developers of this game should take a look at Divinity: Original Sin.
Despite not being a D&D game I find it far more enjoyable.
That includes all aspects of the game. Graphics, interface, controls, combat system...

I'm sorry but saddly I'm gona have to give this game a thumbs down :(

reviewText:
In theory, the game sounds great since I'm a big fan of the original neverwinter nights (not the MMO, the one that came out the the 2000s). However, in practice, things are a bit more lackluster. While I'm getting a definite NWN vibe, the controls for movement feel laggy and clunky. There's a decent bit of delay between clicking, the target circle showing up, and the characters actually moving. It jut doesn't feel as responsive as it could be.

The camera controls are also a bit annoying. Intuitively, one would think that moving the cursor to the edges of the screen would cause the camera to move when it's not actively following the characters. Nope. WASD. Very frustrating.

The story seems to be the usual fantasy fare, but it wasn't enough to really grab my attention. In NWN, you're essentially thrown into things. You're training at a guild that's safeguarding magical animals to help try and stop a plague that's ravaging the city of Neverwinter. Immediately, you know there's big stuff going down. SCL? So, I'm in a guild and I'm escorting a caravan and been having nightmares. Ok.

I will say that I liked the enviroments and the character customization. It was realtivly painfree to create my character, and I like that there was enough explaination that I knew what each option would do. Handy since I've never played a DnD tabletop game and only know the bare basics about it.

Overall, the game isn't bad, but it's not great. It's just kind of...Meh. Not really a game I'd recommend buying unless it heavily goes on sale.

reviewText:
A classic example of game development controlled by someone with no PC market research and blowing most of the budget on promotion hype. It also smacks of future console compatibility, this is probably why the game has been so dumbed down for kids and casual players, that just want a quick button mashing, Diablo 3 hack fest.

MAIN FAILS
Most of the D&D computer game fan base who buy this product will compare it to Neverwinter Nights 1&2 and the merits that made those dated titles so popular to this day. This fan base will be hoping for just a gfx upgrade of said examples. Wrong!
The devs have completely ignored those merits of technical depth, customisation, and of course, the excellent world building tools for dedicated servers.
Yes the game is pretty, however there is still more tech depth/variation in the development of one character class from NWN 1 or 2 than the entire game of Sword coast.

Combat tactics? Very little. The very linear nature of the game and the lack of character action complexity provides little in the tactics department.

The Module creation mechanic is so basic it's a joke. Its pre generated terrain maps that you populate with the few objects/NPC’s available ingame.

Price. The game lacks content to warrant the high end bracket.

POSITIVES
Better gfx than NWN2, good music, good voice-overs, good classic HUD menu and controls, was stable with no obvious bugs.

THE BOTTOM LINE
If you want this pace of game just play Path of Exile, which is more complex than Diablo 3, and has an amazing character progression tree.

If you want a good D&D style game Pillars of Eternity" still has no opposition.

THOUGHTS WHILE PLAYING
I felt like I was play testing yet another early access game
date:
but without the bugs.
With the Story to one side the lack of variation in standard game play had the "Rinse & repeat " effect on me. I almost went back in time to Gauntlet 1 from the 80's..."Valkyrie your life force is running out!"

Very disappointed after waiting two years for this product. I am a massive D&D fan that hates to see this franchise damaged through short term cash-cow mentality.
This is not how the PC gameing market works for this genre. Games with depth make money if they look good for the long haul with good promise of further development
recommended: looking beyond two WEEKS of entertainment."

reviewText:
Sword Coast Legends is not Baulder's Gate, but that is BY NO MEANS A BAD THING!!! It takes it's own, different twist on the RPG style from previous D&D games and I like that about it. The combat is fast, punchy, satisfying and looks great. The loot is varied and worth searching for. The environments are beautifully crafted and look awesome. The quests aren't anything to write home about, basically your standard RPG affair, but at least they're engaging so you don't lose interest. Overall I think it's a great game, and if you're going into it hoping for Bauldur's gate, you're going to be dissappointed, but if you look at it as  completely seperate game with new and different features (which it is! is it called Baulder's gate 3? NO!) you're definitely going to get a lot of enjoyment out of it.

This isn't a perfect game though. My main complaint is that it seems to have trouble running on my computer, which isn't really the game's fault, but If I can run Alien Isolation on almost max settings, I don't know why this game's frame rate dropps to 2 fps if the graphics are anything higher than the lowest possible settings. The other minor complaint I have is that your chracter says some dumb remark LITERALLY every single time you click to move. It's sooo anoying. If you're like me, you don't click terribly far away when you're waliking, because you want to see everything and search for loot, so every two seconds my paladin's saying As you wish" or "I can do that". It gets really old really fast.

Those problems aside
date: I still love this game. It's a great RPG and I can't wait to sink even more hours of my free time into it."

reviewText:
First thing first, it is need to be cleared that although Sword Coast Legends (later SCL) is advertised as a D&D game, it is not exactly that.
SCL is a mixture of Dragon Age: Origins, D&D 5E ruleset and a little Aarklash Legacy (less known combat based „RPG” ).  Sounds good, isn’t it?
Don’t let yourself deceived! SCL lacks content, consistency and quality.

Long review ahead. Prepare yourself before venturing forth.

Character creation:
Your stats and your class is coming from D&D. You can only select from 5 races (elf, half-elf, human, dwarf, halfing -> no half ork, tiefling, gnome etc.) and 6 classes (fighter, cleric, ranger, paladin, wizard, rogue -> no druid, warlock barbarian etc ; no prestige class either).
The „ability tree” where the real problem begins. Firstly it looks like like dragon age but if you go deeper, you see that there are not so much type of ability you can have. but full of upgrades to make your abilities slightly better (fireball 2 do little more damage than fireball 1). Abilities are not balanced, few of them has prerequisite of character level, most of them not.

Campaign:
Completing SCL “epic” campaign main storyline and 98% side quests takes max 30 hours. The story is boring and inconsequent (though ACT 3 is „ok”). Very few side quest is interesting, others are boring dungeon crawl.
Your alignment means nothing in this game. Daylight on open street your lawful good paladin can murder innocent people to get his peg leg.
Your companions are quite good and the voice acting also convenient.

Combat:
The combat is real time, where you can use pause to make decisions, but you don’t need to do that. SCL campaign offers no challenge at all (at normal difficulty). I didn’t have to load game because of a lost fight.
Your characters will use all of their cooldown abilities (except heal) at start, then only basic attack for a long time because mostly you need to wait a lot to use your abilities once more. Later in the game you only need to use basic attack, passive skills (like one more attack per turn) and heal.
The most ridiculous is the instant revival. During the fight any type of character can revive a beaten teammate in 3 seconds.

Inventory/Loot:
Your party has a common inventory (I like it), where your carrying capacity depends on strength, but not counting the armors and weapons are actually equipped (*facepalm).
Loot system is so disappointing. Everywhere (not joking) you can obtain magic loot. Rogue can help you search much more if it not enough. Some equipments are overpowered, so it will play much more role to make your character stronger than your abilities.

Module creation:
Forget the days of freedom. Prepare yourself for a module creator where you can’t do loot customizations, scripts and many other that could make your module original.
Nothing more than an easy to use dungeon crawling generator.

Other problems (just listing):
-no crafting
-bugs (stuck at door-> load game; sometimes capes covers chest not your back etc)
-mini loading before interaction with other persons and quest objects
-graphic is so mediocre

The only one who did a great job at this game: Inon Zur The soundtack is best part of the game.

reviewText: Been playing D&D games since 90s like Pools of Darkness and Eye of The Beholder. Best games so far was the Baldur's Gates and Neverwinter Nights's. So I was expecting pretty much of this game when I heard it's going to be released. First impression of the game was that it's not good, starting from the stupid game mechanics and lack of classes. The skills are now in skilltrees like in every other new RPG and theres not even all the basic D&D classes available like the bard or the druid. Even multiclassing is not possible. Well i was going to look past this and try the single player campaign which might be OK if you try to forget that this was supposed to be D&D. Then I looked to the editor and was hoping much that maybe this saves the game. I was hoping too much, the editor lacks many of the basic features that you would expect from an editor. I am so disappointed that I am a bit angry now, since Neverwinter Nights the whole D&D brand has lost so much of it's former glory and now they are releasing stuff like this under it's name. Maybe they will manage to make this into a decent product, but I think it might take year or two if ever.

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY, IT'S A SCHEME.

This game is a multiplayer action RPG under the guise of a CRPG:

- Character classes got nothing in common with original D&D classes except their name: You get a crappy talent system where you level up spells and every spell is cooldown or proc based.

- Combat has nothing in common with D&D: Creatures have way more HP than they're supposed and they hit for far too much unless CC'ed or you got a tank. Turns take about 1 second or less and every character except maybe a shield bearing one in full plate armor is way too squishy and will get eviscerated in 1 second or less. To compensate this, they give you the ability to click-to-res where any character can res another just by clicking on it in 1 second or less so your best combat tactic are RES TRAINS !!!
Also there's no rest and no spell memorization system. Since spells and talents are not D&D based, eventual product of combat including rolls and other stuff (running away in combat actaully works!) has nothing to do with D&D either therefore causing attributes to lose meaning, not that you had much say on those creating a character (can't put less than 8 in any attribute).

- Questing are like of a generic MMO, grocery list style. Except attribute-check dialog options, you literally have no other options except talking with the NPC that has a ! sign on its head and even then, dialogue options are limited and generally doesn't back your alignment specific actions.

- Co-op multiplayer is a mess: When played with 2 people, host controls 3 characters and guest controls 1 which is a total failure since one guy has to control 3x the amount of characters in a realtime game which causes one guy in a position to do a lot of stuff in a short duration while the other waits. You can't change control of companions. Also host decides every dialogue option related to main story while the guest is only watching. Guest can only interact with side-quests or vendors. Also pause system with short rounds is a total mess.

- Friendly AI is a mess with no way to set it up how you want it to play: Characters in your party will keep on casting random stuff if you don't micro-manage their every action and you have no control over it,

- DM Mode dungeon crawl is an original idea but seeing where the DM is really kills all the immersion.

TLDR; Do not buy, go purchase Divinity: Original Sin instead if you wanna have co-op campaign fun or play an actual mmo if you wanna do Dungeon Crawl.

reviewText: This game can be fun sometimes, but is a perfect example of soulless marketing to make a buck. It might not warrant such negativity if it didn't claim to be something it's not, and then perhaps people would have a case saying some are being overly critical, but this game has D&D in the title and nowhere in the game. Done to death skill trees, limited class options, module creating tools that aren't close to Neverwinter Nights, and limited character options place SCL solidly in role-playing light, action RPG genre, of which there are hordes to choose from.\nThe main story is entertaining and fairly well written, and of course playable with friends of your choosing, but true role-playing in the rest of the game is severly absent. From what I've heard of creating your own modules, player characters don't get to say anything beyond we accept" or "not right now
date: how the heck do you create a story doing that? Unless the game adds a lot of free conentto open up possible creativity with it, I can't give it a positive.

reviewText: This game isn't even bad, it's just painfully average. With VERY limited character creation options, (Only six classes and five races) bare bones CRPG mechanics that feel more like the developers haven't played anything in the genre before, and a slow crawl at the beginning made me ponder wether or not this was worth continuing on with and missing out on the possiblity of getting a refund. It isn't bad by any means, and I for one like how they didn't go with a direct translation of 5e and instead used it as a back bone for it's own skill system. However after thinking about it I honestly could not see myself playing onward until they added more races and classes. Not to mention the price for admission of 35 bucks at the time of purchase made me sort of realize getting a refund would be best.\n\nSo yeah, wait for a price drop/sale of like 50% or something and for them to add more races and classes to the game. Otherwise, don't bother with this one.

reviewText: Sword Coast Legends is a confused game, that much is true, but there is something rather endearing about it.  No, it never reaches the storytelling heights of previous D&D based games such as Planescape: Torment or Baldur's Gate II.  Nor does it have the flexible module creation of the Neverwinter Nights games, instead opting for an easier to use, but rather limited dungeon and campiagn creator.  But that is okay.\n\nAt it's core SCL is a dungeon crawling game similar to Diablo or Torchlight with some D&D inspired elements added to it and a small bit of roleplaying akin to the infinty engine games.  When it was first annouced, many people saw it as a throwback to the inifinity engine games and were seeing it as a response to Pillars of Eternity and Torment: Tides of Numenera (both excelent games), a sort of official successor"

reviewText:
Well this is tough. This game is clearly not as good and polished/in-depth as most RPGs on the market (Pillars of Eternity, Divinity : Original Sin and Dragon Age being the latest to date), yet that doesn't make it a bad game.

I enjoyed the story, which took me around 30h to finish. I played it entirely solo, like I would any of the aforementioned RPGs. And for a 20€ pricetag, I think I got my money's worth of gameplay.

Yes it crashes sometimes, and the UI isn't exactly practical, but I thought the writing was good, the voice acting too, the game looked decent enough and I didn't find the gameplay to be as bad as some reviews describe it. I found the game to be quite challenging at times too.

Overall I think the game is worth a buy, especially if you're a fan of the Forgotten Realms, and I consider the player-created modules and multiplayer/co-op aspect a nice bonus.

reviewText:
I enjoyed the single player game.  It loosely fits in the D&D realm.  I have zero interest in MP.

Pros: Enjoyable characters/story, fun sense of humour
Runs well (for me)
Acceptable game length

The Meh:
- old, toony graphics when their target audience wants dark realism akin to D&D
- no customizable batle AI
- inventory item icons are often just coloured blocks
- weak engine

Cons:
-Overly simplified (had a watered down console feel), the skill/proficiency trees took a page from ARPG's instead of CRPG's
-Only 4 characters in your party, should be 6.
-Amateur Inventory System (Can't equip your party in camp) you have to grab 3 party members and leave and come back, grab three others leave and come back etc...
-Clunky leveling system.  Only your active party memebers gain experience which is practical in theory but encourages the player to pick 4 from the start and simply stick with them all the way through for maximum leveling.
-the save system is dreadful, one save, not just one quick save, one save for the whole campaign.  This is a major flaw which I saw a dev say was a Steam cloud restriction which it isn't.  There should obviously be limitless local saves like every other RPG.

It comes across as amateurish and suffers from not being wholely D&D or wholely something else.  Hybrids always suffer.  That's me being picky, overall I had fun with it.  I recommend the campaign for $30 and under.

reviewText:
(disclaimer, I have not tried DM mode yet)

A decent D&D game similar to games like Baldur's Gate.  I only have a few complaints.  One has to do with the in-game map.  When you open the map, you can't move it around the screen.  This seems more like a rough edge that just hasn't been addressed yet.  Another has to do with monsters auto leveling to your character level.  I know this is due to the system of generating dungeons for players and DM's to use, however I've never been a fan of this mechanic.  Then there is the matter of not being able to have multiple saves during the single player campaign.  They really should change this... it just seems lazy.  And finally, the game only has a handful of abilities for each class to learn (feats, skills, spells, etc- all rolled together), but the choices are fairly limited.  This is most noticeable with Wizards.

Overall very much worth the price if you enjoy this style of overhead, pause-tactical, party based RPG.  However, not a must have for people that aren't already fans of this sort of thing.  I look forward to future content, and hope to see a modding community take off.

**SPOILER EDIT**



Before the final battle, you are warned that there is no going back.  Normally this would not be a big deal, but since you only have a single save game you are stuck.  So be warned, finish all your side quests since you are _forced_ to start over after the final battle.

reviewText:
Amidst all the hatred for this game, I have to admit that while it does have its flaws, I found it to be highly addictive and very enjoyable. From a somewhat nostalgic viewpoint, it brings back that great, genuinely fun feel that was seen in D&D games like Icewind Dale. As far as play-value goes, this game actually does pretty well. There's a relatively long story with very enjoyable companions who each have their own eccentricities and humorous quirks, providing good banter at times. If you finish the story, don't fret: Besides DM mode (which, as of this point, I'm actually yet to try out), there are still Dungeon Crawl and Module modes. Dungeon Crawl lets you create a party, either online co-op or with any of the characters you have actually made, and puts them in a randomly generated dungeon that fits specs for enemies, environment, and bosses that you choose. If that's not enough, there are still Modules which are being added and are played as miniature campaigns.
From a single player perspective, this game is genuinely good. The pause-input decisions-unpause mechanic works well and allows you, with enough effort and foresight, to come up with effective kill team procedures. The character development is enjoyable, too, as there is a plethora of powers and abilities from which to choose. The only downside here, though, is the distinct lack of Multi-Classing that is often seen as the stamp of D&D games.
Another good thing is that, for a player like me who has a very low-end PC, the game is still very playable. The only lag on my low-end PC occurs in open areas, whereas dungeons - where most of the game occurs - are smooth. Moreover, lag is actually irrelevant in a combat style where one can pause and input commands.
Personally, I struggled adapting to the D&D 5.0 system at first, having only played much older versions, but I picked it up quickly enough to avoid any real issues.
The biggest negative to this game is a vast array of glitches relating to loading screens. The forums are riddled with issues about non-loading loading screens and issues thereafter; however, there is an easy fix for those of you concerned: before loading, drop your graphics settings or window the game heavily, then as soon as you're in-game, put them back up to where you want them. This works pretty much every single time, so there's no actual negative there.

Overally, I'd give this game an easy 80%. While it may seem a push to buy it full price, if there is ever any discount on it, it is definitely worth its weight.

reviewText:
Sword Coast Legends
This review was last edited when I had completed the single player campaign in easy mode. I have also played out the first section in coop mode. I have not played with the DM tools.

Short Review
A party based roleplaying game that despite a host of minor issues is none the less an enjoyable romp. The highlights for me were the humour within the character dialogue and the boss fights. The low point is definitely the user interface which was very cumbersome to use.

Long Review
It's probably worth mentioing that the last time I played AD&D was with the first ruleset so I have no knowledge of the current ruleset this game claims to follow. I have played Baldur's Gate and was not imparticularly impressed with that game. My initial reaction to this game is that it is an updated version of Baldur's Gate with similar game mechanics and humour but with much updated graphics. However, having said that I have to say that I prefer Sword Coast Legends to Baldur's Gate.

You play this game in third person with the ability to zoom in and out and adjust the camera angle. To be hnest I played most of the game scrolled out to the furthest level and could have done with the ability to scroll out futher.

Interaction with the important NPCs takes you into a still graphic with audio to listen to and text based options to make a decision on how to respond to the NPC. I found the quality of the audio to be pretty good.

The first time you come across using a control there are tutorial hints displayed. I found these useful and TBH within 10-15 minutes had the basics matered. However, there is a lot of depth to the interface that did require some trial and error to figure out.

I found the audio and graphics to play fine on my low end gaming machine and had no issues related to hardware performance that I can recall.

There is certainly some replay value in the game, particularly to play it as co-op and try out the DM tools. I doubt whether I'd replay the solo campaign again.

ProsThe humour is very much my cup of tea
I like the ability to scroll well ahead of the party
I found the storyline engaging and enjoyable
The boss fights were excellent
The AI was good enough to mean the charcters do not need to be micro managed but be aware occasionally they get snagged moving from place to placeConsI find the camera angle a little restrictive
There is a significant delay inbetween moving from one map to another
The map view is not scrollable
Unlimited ammo. I liked having to manage how many arrows I carried in Baldur's Gate
The party members do not move on the map view
The messages disappear too quickly off screen and clicking on them does does not take me to the relevant entry/item
When the journal is updated there is no indication as to which entries have been updated since you last opened it
The journal is pretty cumbersome to use to the point I pretty much ignored it in the end
When interacting with merchants the default view is to list items by the lowest cost. This means that all the rubbish" stuff is listed first
Allocating abilitiies on levelling up is instantaneous. It would have been much better to offer a confirm option once you'd selected which abilities you wanted to include
Whenever the game pauses all the characters movement if forgotten. So we you un pause you have to re-reploy the party members again. A real nuisance.
I'm not sure if I was just unlucky but I found the number of companions to choose from rather limitingSo whilst I believe SCL to be a good game it has way too many annoying "minor" flaws that prevent me from wholeheartedly recommending this as a great game..

Marks Out Of 5
5) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this
4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase
3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted
1) Not worth getting even if given away free

Where I got the game from
I pre-ordered the game from  Green Man Gaming [www.greenmangaming.com] and had the key delivered a few days before the first preview weekend so was able to download it ready for the launch.

Platform Played On
Intel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition

reviewText:
Long story short: after so many months from the release, this game has got some high priority and frustrating bugs, such as getting stuck in a room, and this looks to me simply UNACCEPTABLE even though I would otherwise recommend this game because it should deserve it. In my opinion, beauty and gameplay are second to functionality. For now, and sadly, my thumb is down. Let's see if something good happens in the future, however.

I played and finished a lot of D&D based games like this (Baldur's Gate 1 EE and 2, IceWind Dale 2, Neverwinter Nights 1 and 2 etc.) and non D&D (Dragon Age 1 & 2, Divinity: OS, etc., Pillars of Eternity) and as a whole this is probably the one of the best of its kind (but not as good as PoE, for example).

PROS:
Fine plot, classical CRPG with some advanced graphical effects, there is pretty anything you could expect from the best party based, turn based tactical rpgs around.

CONS:
Critical level bugs are still there (example: full screen mode switch only working with a keybord shortcut you discover from the forums - alt+enter for pc's if i'm not wrong);
Little to no graphics optimization (example: the whole graphics and text get blurry if you do not choose the best screen resolution for your device, so you are forced).
Only one 'save slot'. This could be interesting, but currently is a mad choice given the in-game bugs, especially in single player campaign.
Lack of standard journal or log, which is, according to me, another mandatory feature.

reviewText: I stayed away from this game for months because of all the bad reviews I read about it. Well I got bored and decided to give it a shot I mean if i did not like it I could just get a refund. However from the moment I started I can not put it down. Granted it is not completely a DnD game. All of the races and abilites are exactly from DnD but the gameplay is much easier then what you would be use to. However the storyline and quests are exteremly fun, and the characters are some of the best I have experienced in an rpg in a very long time. There are items galor for customzing your characters. The only way you will hate this game is if you go in expecting a True DnD experiance. The fact is this is an RPG inspired by DnD with many elements taken from it. Moral of this story? Don't always trust those negative reviews because you may very well miss out on a great experience.

reviewText:
I had fun with this, the story is well written and enjoyable.

Pro's:
Story - Great story to pull you along into the game.  I thought it was well written and interesting.

Maps and Areas - The maps and areas were well done, interesting, lots of variety.

Combat - I liked the combat auto mode, or if I needed to take over for an action I could do so at any point in time very conveniently.

Party - Party Members were well designed, all had good stories and where interesting/fun.

Sound & Voice - Voice acting was all good, spell effects where cool.





Con's:
Encumbrance - I found that all of your items having a weight limit was kind of bothersome.  It's D&D, Bag of holding anyone?

Itemization - There just seemed to be so many different items, keeping track of them all was sometimes tedious, the fact that they had weight was also tedios.  I was getting tons of late game items that were significantly worse then early game items.  I get that not everything is going to be a huge upgrade, but having to manage them, and their weight was kind of annoying.

I'd give it a 9/10, I had fun and completed all the quests except for one.


For the Developers:
I'd recommend a more convenient way of comparing weapons and armor in the inventory to that already equiped.
Basically something that shows what the new DPS would be vs the old weapon, or stat increases, etc etc.

reviewText:
Playing on a Laptop without a mouse.

Overall, I love this game! I expected quite a different experience, however, I was surprised with what I ended up with! That being said, first I'll say what I expected, then I'll list pro's and con's.

I expected a solid RPG experience with an immersive world, and a game maker element with tons of customizations! Instead, I got a challenging, immersive, unforgettable, long lasting journey, with a mild level editor.

Pro's:
Massive World
Extensive Character Customization
Strong RPG Elements
Meaningful Co-operative Play
Hours of Gameplay
Unforgettable Story
Familiar Lore
Beautiful World
Ton's of Enemies and NPC's
Excellent, Intuitive, and Smooth controls (recommeded to use a mouse)

Con's:
DM Mode is not as free as an RPG Maker
Lack of Tools for DM Mode
Sometimes the difficulty has a steep learning curve (this could be a pro)
Difficult playing on a track pad (Again, not intended for track pad use, but could be a tad smoother)

Overall:
I went in expecting a wonderful RPG, it delivered, I expected wonderful multiplayer aspects, it delivered again. I expected an immersive and extensive DM tool, more specifically, a better campaign creator, it wasn't what I wanted, this far from makes or breaks the game. The DM tool is fun, and the campaign creator is fun as well, however, it's not intended to build a whole game..it's more suited to smaller, shorter campaigns, and pick them up with expansions or add on campaigns. This game can offer a truly wonderful role playing experience, especially with 4 other friends, and using voice chat.

I DEFINITELY recommend trying this game, if for nothing else, the story campaign and the Rage of Demons campaign is wonderful!

reviewText:
Sword Coast Legends is a game more interesting for what it isn't than what it is, which is unfortunate.

Much of the emphasis of the game is on the DM-mode, which allows four people to play through custom-created campaigns or the main story quest cooperatively... which (should) certainly sound very interesting--until you realize that the single-player campaign is not all that compelling, dynamic or interesting, and the content-creation tools are far too shallow to allow for even the potential of interesting adventures. Despite the D&D name, the core gameplay also fails to impress, as it ditches the tried-and-true adaptations of past D&D games in favor of generic, cooldown-based ARPG fare that feels more at home in a Dragon Age or Diablo game than D&D. The combat is moderately engaging while playing solo, but when you're playing multiplayer (and thus only controlling a single party member) it quickly becomes apparent that the game is designed like an ARPG, with fast cooldowns on powers, rapid normal attacks, respawning, and wave-based encounters that completely annihilate any semblance of the tactical gameplay inspired by TotSC's top-down party-based premise.

As for the meat of the game--the single player campaign--good Gods, is it dull. Just about every possible D&D campaign cliche is dumped at you within seconds of loading up a new game, and once you start playing... you're bombarded with fetch-quests and imminently forgettable dialog. I haven't played the game to the end yet (I will amend this review upon doing so), but what I've seen so far is much more at the level of say, Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance than Baldur's Gate proper.

Beyond that, there are a host of other problems: the UI is incredibly poorly designed, with some of the most tedious-to-navigate menus I've seen this side of a Paradox Grand Strategy. There's also a noticeable delay between clicking on a button, and that input registering--which is always annoying. Speaking of which: did you know that every time you enter or leave dialog with an NPC, the screen will fade-out to black and then fade back in as the camera adjusts to slightly different angles? Yeah: that's a thing.

Sword Coast Legends offers none of the grand narrative or character of the Baldur's Gates, none of the engrossing user-creation tools of Neverwinter Nights, and doesn't even try to emulate the systemic fidelity of the Icewind Dales. In short, for most hardened CRPG gamers, SCL is an immensely disappointing game that completely fails to live up to even a single aspect of its potential.

So: why the recommendation?

Because, ultimately, I think the only thing that really matters is whether or not a game is good on its own merit. Is Sword Coast Legends the game it could have been, or perhaps should have been? No. Absolutely not.

But does not being good make a thing bad? You are welcome to think so; I do not. Sword Coast Legends offers a fairly generic experience, true, and has a number of minor problems that hamper enjoyment... it's clear that the developers don't really have much (if any) experience making CRPGs. But nothing really sticks out as being awful, either. There are plenty of bad games out there--I should know, I've played many of them (how many of us can boast to having beaten Daikatana?)--and, while disappointing, SCL isn't bad. Sometimes, I don't want to get too involved in a game. Sometimes, I just want to play around in an archetypal high fantasy setting that doesn't demand I become too involved with the characters or story. And, sometimes, I want to do that with friends.

And, as you can likely guess, Sword Coast Legends provides exactly that. There are few CRPGs that offer cooperative multiplayer, and of those fewer still are worth playing. So, yeah: if you've tired of the great classic CRPGs of yore, or find yourself in-between the big CRPGs of today (the Divinities and Eternities and Torments), or simply want to relax and have some low-intensity fun with a friend or two (or three)... Sword Coast Legends is for you.

reviewText:
Enjoyable adventure reminiscent of Baldurs Gate and Neverwinter Nights. If you like swords and magic, killing undead and goblins then I'd recommend you give this a try.

It may not satisfy hardcore D&D fanatics due to it's loose interpretaion of the 5th edition rules but for a casual gamer with a passing interest in fantasy this is good fun and a well written story.

It can be played as a party or by yourself and custom campaign can be created and hosted by a live DM, although the tools available will not allow for creation of anything more than a straight up dungeon crawl IMO.

There is much negativity and disappointment directed at this title but in this case people have been victims of their own expectaions as much as anything they think the developers did or didn't do.

reviewText:
- Character customization is wanting, both in style and appeal.

- Selected hero gives verbal feedback for every single click, and the only way to disable it is to mute ALL character voices.

- There are no hotkeys to select individual party members.

- There is no implementation of a rest mechanic.

- The loot system is uninspiring and redundant.

- The story isn't interesting.

- Party A.I. is generations behind.

- The map system is inexcusable.

- There is no implementation of a fast-travel mechanic. You crawl, everywhere, all the time.

- When I alt-tab out to do something, the entire machine is bogged down to a stand-still. I have to save and exit the game in order to perform any miniscule windows task, then reload the game.


It's like they read a text-book of what is expected in a game like this, set up superficial placeholders for HALF of the requisites, and then just released.

I got a refund and feel like I just dodged a bullet.

reviewText:
I do not recommend the purchase of Sword Coast Legends in it's current state.

There are a myriad of things that I just didn't enjoy but I will try and keep this short.

1.) I realized after a few hours into the game that what I was really enjoying the most is the setting. And not much else. Nothing about this game made me go awesome" or "wow that's really cool". The only thing I ended up being excited about was the fact that the game starts by heading to Luskan and my group is currently in Luskan. Literally that was all.

2.) This game is causing my GPU to fail. My 3 month old 980 in my dual-980 build with three monitors. I have had 3 failures in three hours of gameplay. I tried playing some other much more graphically intense games to see if I really was having a true hardware issue. Nothing. Everything else runs completely fine. I am still in the process of researching this
date:
but after some quick Googling it appears I am not the only one with issues that happen to occur when trying to play Sword Coast Legends.

Thumbs Down.

Edit: Just thought I would come back and update this as it has been a bit. DO NOT buy this game if you have an expensive GPU. This game will cause your GPU to run at 98-100% load for no reason and I can confirm without a doubt it blew up my 980.

You can think I'm an idiot

reviewText:
Sadly I have to say that I instantly dislike this game from the get go, dispite the appealing promise of the game. As other reviews have stated already the D&D brand is tantamount to a sham.

Character creation feels stale. Things are not explaned in any detail nor are they intuitive in any way. An atheist cleric or paladin just seems odd - deities seems tagged on and doesn't really provide anything. The possibilities for customizations are very low - a mere 5 classes are presented to the user and you have little influence on how these are configured. Moreover the characters look cartoonish in appearance, which annoys me for some reason.

I have only had about an hour of actual gameplay and there is a reason for that. The controls are confusing and annoying. Maybe it is a Linux bug, but you cannot scroll by moving the mouse to the egde as usual. It feels like a tedium to play the game and it shouldn't.

This game is NOT BG or NWN in any way or form. If you expect that kind for game then pass on it. I was fortunately able to get my money refunded. I may try to pick this up in a summer sales and give it a go in a different light.
