reviewText:
This review is based on the single player campaign. I have not played and do not have any real interest in playing the multiplayer campaign.

Probably the biggest plus to this game is the story. The plot drew me in from the very beginning, and I can already sense that the stakes are very high a couple of minutes into it. The pacing is faster than most fantasy RPGs that I’ve played, and there is a sense of urgency through every progression of the main quest. The characters in general are quite well fleshed out, especially your companions. You will encounter some unexpected twists with one or two of them. The banters are quite clever and I feel they have just the right touch of humor.

The combat will be hit and miss, depending on what you’re expecting. While the overall feel of the game is similar to the traditional isometric infinity engine, the combat mechanics remind me of Dragon Age Origins. Casting spells and using special abilities have cooldown periods. There is no need to rest and similar to DAO, you are provided a camping ground where you can converse with your companions and further their own individual quests. Personally, I feel it is easier to navigate through battles with the current system and I am honestly having a lot of fun with it. Also, most of the time, the battles are fairly easy which to me is actually a welcome relief as I’ve been playing some really tough RPG games lately. I forgot how good it felt to just relax and breeze through enemy encounters. There are complaints that the combat is nowhere near close to table top D&D as is promised. Well, if you’re that serious about those pen-and-paper rules than pay no heed to my opinion on combat since my enjoyment of the game does not hinge on the ruleset at all.

Outside of combat, other game mechanics such as navigation can be irritating at times. It takes a long while for me to get used to the process of scrolling through an area. Even rotating the view can be a chore. The area map screen is almost useless since it does not give you the usual option of clicking on a spot and moving your party to that spot. Also if you’re in a pretty huge area, your map does not zoom out which makes it absolutely impractical for you to use, since often, specific locations that you need to go to is not visible on the map. I’m sure the devs will come around and improve on this sooner or later.

Now for my biggest complaint; the save system. It is not as bad as having no manual save but it’s still pretty bad. Why? You’re only given one save slot. It is especially made worse with the fact that this game has just been released and there will inevitably be bugs in it. Once you encounter one that is serious, there are no options for you to go back a couple of steps and avoid the bug. You are basically stuck and will have to start over. I have so far encountered no serious bug yet but I’m a bit nervous at this point. The devs probably made this decision because of multiplayer, which, for gamers like me who is only in it for the SP experience is definitely not on. I really hope they make some serious changes on this matter.

In conclusion, the story and lore alone already won me over. I just hope no progress killing bug will change that opinion anytime soon ^_^

8/10.

reviewText:
Even though it advertised as a D&D CRPG game, IT IS NOT D&D.

Therefore, one who bought this game expecting Baldur's Gate, PoE, etc may not like it.

However, as a newcomer in CRPG genre, I quite enjoyed SCLs.



The combat system is very casual. Cantrips are based on cooltime system, not per rest.

Some dislikes casuality, but I loved it.

Cuz messing up with per rast cantrips in PoE was a bit annoying for me.



Plus, there's a very charming game mode named 'Dungeon Crawl'.

In most CRPGs, encounters happen in entirely preset location and time.

So as you keep playing the game, world map becomes more empty and dead.

Cuz there are no random encounters and mob respawn.

It is also a tragedy for players who enjoy the combat itself of CRPGs.

Here comes 'Dungeon Crawl'. You can explore randomly generated dungeons as much as you want.

You can fight. You can kill. You can loot.

And all the data is shared with your character in story mode, of course.



DM system was criticized severely at first. But it's being improved as time goes by.



Ah, also thumbs up for developers actively reflecting what players complain about in forums.

Community Pack 1, 2 patches were fabulous.




Definitely an Excellet Game for CRPG Newbie & Battle Maniacs.

reviewText:
TLDR: Game is good, don't trust the bad reviews.

-DM Mode is interesting, play against your friends!
-Campaign is really fun since you can play drop in drop out co-op
-Dungeon Crawl mode is for quick fun, you can use your character/companion from Campaign mode to play a dungeon of your settings.

Is it better than PoE or Divinity:original sin?
-Graphics are better than PoE and battle-pausing between is similar but AI's are smarter in Sword Coast Legends
-Divinity is turn based combat; very different since Sword Coast is much faster

reviewText:
The graphics are great. I haven't finished the single player campaign yet and I'm not terribly far in but what I've seen of it so far is pretty good.

I haven't done any group play as far as playing with other players yet but when playing the dungeon crawl aspect with the NPCs companions it's been pretty fun so far.

I think the DM tools are fairly good as well and are pretty easy to understand/use. You can either let the random mob placement put in the NPCs or manually put them in or a combination depending on how much effort you want to put in.

Overall I think the game is worth picking up just for the ~40 hour single player campaign, plus however much of the multiplayer you enjoy.

Now for some 'cons' to the game. Some of these SCL has stated that they are going to add/fix going forward, based on player feedback/request, they just didn't have time to do so before launch. Considering the amount of content they've added during Headstarts and in the community updates to date from player feedback they've shown, at least to me, that they seem sincere in their desires to do so.

-While the variety of dungeon sets to use is pretty decent the lack of being able to fully customize a dungeon by creating one tile by tile was a bit of a surprise.
-Two of the monster sets aren't able to be set for a dungeon you create, the troll and ogre sets.
-On the overland maps you can't zoom out properly, which is a bit of a problem on the larger ones because you can't see where the mob placements are and it's hard to properly build the maps.
-For me the complete lack of any crafting in the game is a bit of a draw back, being able to create magic items and such is a pretty interesting aspect of D&D.
-The lack of spell options for wizards is a bit of a let down for me, the immense versatility of the class is it's main draw for me. I'm unsure how 5e handles wizard spells since I play 3.5 and I understand that the limitations of creating and balancing an online game make such things difficult .
-Not all the D&D classes, or even the base classes, are in at launch. They plan to add them in the future but weren't able to for launch. (barbarian, monk, bard are missing, and I think Warlock is considered a base class now also?)
-The game is missing some iconic creatures, like dragons. Not a deal breaker and they are planning on adding more in the future but still bit of a downer not to have dragons in a D&D game.
-They don't allow you to make/hand out custom items as a DM/Dungeon designer. There are pros and cons to this. They went this route for balance reasons so DMs couldn't just give +10 Vorpal, Keen, etc etc weapons and the like. I respect their decision and the reasons behind it, but feal like decisions like these should be up to individual DMs and not be blanket dissallowed.
-the absence of branching dialogue is a pretty sore point for many campaign creators. SCL has stated numerous times that they want to put it in, they just weren't able to get it in for launch. (this and Tile by Tile dungeon creation were the two top requests by the headstart community)

Summary:
Going into this game I new that the idea was to make a space where Dms could make a dungeon and players could join it and the DMs could run a campaign through it. They'd also made it clear from the begining that it was based off 5e Faerune and not D&D itself. I think a lot of people got really excited about the game and thought it was straight up digitized D&D 5e in a virtual space and that's why there are so many who dislike the game.

The game is perfectly able to pull off what the designers said it would be able to do and they have been very open about their desires to add those things the community has asked for and responding to feedback. There has been quite a few things added already as a direct result of player requests for instance. They've already added well over 200 assets and 4 new areas to the game just in the couple weeks since launch for instance.

With these things in mind and the presence of a pretty nice ~40 hour single player campaign I feel the game is well worth the money and that the SCL team has earn the benefit of the doubt that they'll continue to deliver what they've said they would and what the community requests as far as new features/updated features. Your mileage may vary depending on whether you're looking for a D&D-esque game or a pen and paper 5e replacement.

reviewText: Almost 10 hours into the main campaign and I'm really enjoying it.  It has a really nice classic D&D type story and the questing is satisfying.  Its a good combo of quests that tell you exactly what to do and quests that give you an idea of what you need to do and let you figure it out.  I'm finding the combat very satisfying so far.  It has a good amount of challenge in the beginning leading to many fights where I need to control all the members in my party.  It has a more action packed feel than stuff like Baldur's Gate.  Its kind of like a combo between Diablo type games (lots of hotbar moves with cool downs) and Baldur's Gate type games (pause with space bar, queue actions for specific party members), which I am finding pretty cool so far.  So far the only negatives I am noticing are small optimization issues/oversites that don't detract from the game in my opinion (single save file, every time I start the game I have to put the resoultion back to 1440p, weird stuff like that).  I'd say pick it up if you like D&D style adventure stories but don't mind a game that strays from D&D convention to make it a bit more action packed.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of FR but I was a bit sad around the area I typically feel emotions when I saw the mixed reviews so I went with Mordheim instead (which is brilliant btw). I had a bit of disposable income this week to throw at a new game, so I took a closer look at some of the reviews and noticed that a lot of them were complaints about deviations from the core rule set which didn't bother me much. I do not regret this purchase at all. I'm only a little ways in, but I can tell you the voice acting is awesome, dungeons look great with lots of detail, secrets and traps, while graphics look just a little dated, open areas still manage to look beautiful and they're interesting too in unexpected ways,

Developers communicate with their audience and patch where required with community content packs which is what I think gamers expect these days after years of feeding the AAA machine money and getting silence in return,

Have not had a look at the multiplayer or DM aspect of the game, living in Australia can make getting people in a party hard, but hopefully that should change once the game gets a little more polish.

If you enjoyed BG and all the rest, don't buy into this expecting copy paste experience. Attribute points are still there, but perks have been replaced with skill trees and no multiclassing (but access to multiple skill trees per a class), AI companions can be controlled by player or the AI and they have their own voice acting and direct role in the story. Oh, and abilities and spells are cooldown now so no resting after every few encounters (which I kind of like), there's a few classes missing but I'm sure (I hope) they will be added down the line.

If you're on the fence, give it a little more time. Certainly could use a little more optimization and polish, but I think it's a little gem that will see a lot of improvement over time. It's good to be back in The Forgotten Realms.

reviewText:
I can't believe the poor reviews this is getting.

This game is incredibly fun, and I've only played the single player campaign up through about halfway of chapter 2. I absolutley LOVE D&D 5th edition, and I believe they have translated it incredibly well into a video game.

I loved Baldur's Gate 1 & 2, Neverwinter Nights and Dragon Age: Origins. This game falls somewhere between those and it is awesome.

People don't realize that you can't fully translate a tabletop D&D experience to a video game, because the core element of D&D is roleplaying. The combat mechanics and skill checks are fun as heck, sure, and this game does that in spades.

The NPCs that you meet are well done and make you care for them.

Again, I'm only halfway through, but I would give this game a solid 87/100.

I now have no real reason to level any more, and thus no real reason to play.  What's the goal here, a 20/20/20/20/20/20 toon?  If so, what is the point?  Now I'm sorry I spent the money.  A rogue with a DEX of 20 and no more.  Fail.


Graphics: Divinity Original Sin style
Ruleset: 5.0
Plot of main campaign: Meh.  Not terrible, but nothing new under the sun or compelling.
Setting: Start out with a caravan travelling between Neverwinter and Luskan.
Character building: Most closely resembles character customization in Dragon Age I.
Recommendation:  Sure, maybe, if you're really bored.  Price is still too high though, for solo play anyway.

I am a 3.5 fiend.  Still play DDO and am replaying NWN2 because they hit my minimum graphics requirements and I just love building characters.  I can build a character, save it, and stop playing altogether.  It's central and it keeps the game fresh.  I think DDOs staying power rests with the fact that you can rebuild a character endlessly through the 3.5 ruleset and get a different game each and every time.  You can't get that with other games.

That said, I cannot play Neverwinter online.  I hate 4.0.  No choice, no variation, no newness" to each character.  Which equals crap replayability.  Moving on.

Sword Coast Legends uses 5.0.  It's not terrible
recommended: no cross-classing.  My rogue uses DEX for trap skills instead of INT.  Previously finesse-able weapons are just straight out  DEX based.  No feats that I've seen.  STAT pts with level ups which you choose to place.   What my rogue gets is access to 8 ability trees

reviewText:
So, I'm reviewing this after the mounds of updates they have piled on to it as of Dec 4th 2015.  It's good.  It's not quite as good as earlier D&D games, but it's pretty good.  I've mostly played campaign mode with two other people, and multiplayer is the only way to play this to me, a completely customized party of you and your friends.  The story is actually pretty decent as well.  Though if you're a D&D fan you'll be thinking that you didn't really visit 'all that much' of the Sword Coast, and you're right.  The gameplay is very modern, buttons/cooldowns/etc so the hardcore D&D fans seem to dislike that when compared to older games, but I didn't mind, it makes for easier to learn/get into gameplay IMO.  Some of the 'boss' fights are intriguing.  Some can even be challenging (if you're not paying attention and just clicking attack).  My biggest complaint is actually that only the game host gets to make most of the big choices in the game, and not the other party members.  Perhaps a voting system should be in place for choices.

Is it the Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale of yesteryear? Nope.  They have attempted to modernize it, and they succeed at a lot of things, and failed in others, but really, as much as I love those old games, they had issues too.  I think this attempt, and thus the game, is a good effort.  Though I hope they release some mroe updates, and  MORE CAMPAIGNS for it.  Hopefully free campaigns for those of us that paid a fairly mainsteam price for this game at launch.

So that's my two cents.  After all the updates the game is much more playable, and enjoyable than it was at launch.  I recommend playing with a group that loves the D&D lore and lands to increase the joy (Because the NPC allies are a little dumb).  Does it play a bit more like WoW, and a bit less like Icewind Dale? Yeah, but that's how it goes these days.

Overall I'd say a 7 out of 10.

reviewText:
This is for the game after 'community pack two' went live.

I was excited about the title, but dismayed by the reviews.  Fortunately, a free weekend is going on at the time of this writing, accompanied by a half off sale.

I am five hours in, and am enjoying the game.  It's not the constant slugfest of Diablo 3 (which has its place) nor is it the dialog heavy game like Pillars of Eternity (which has its place) but it kind of snuggles up somewhere right in the middle.

Combat can often be done with little attention, but if you let your guard down at the wrong time it can bite you.  It doesn't have a 5E flavor to me, though; it seems more like 4E, with rapid cool downs and plentiful heals after each encounter, like a cinematic style.   This isn't a bad thing, though, in a video game, as it keeps the flow going.  It often bothers me in other games to have to pitch camp for no other reason than to gain spells back.

The graphics aren't mind blowing, but are certainly adequate.  If you have tried Neverwinter (the MMO) you will have an idea.

I haven't dug too deeply into the user generated content yet, but I have checked it out.  The options sure do seem plentiful.  Don't know yet whether or not much of it can be done solo or if you need to group up, and I don't know how popular grouping up is.  I hope to tap into that, but it's a busy time and I haven't yet.  The fact that the option exists is very attractive to me.

Anyhoo . . . I think the game suffers from early launchitis, and the early reviews reflect that, but the reviews that come after should be given more credence, as apparantly much has been addressed in the community packs.  I am midway into the free weekend, but I will be purchasing, just don't know if I will get the deluxe version or not.

Now I must go have harsh words with my wife.  Her influence is my only excuse I have for using the word 'snuggle' in a review.

Edited after 20 hours:

A couple addendums to my review.

After creating several characters to get a feel for the different classes, I made a rogue that is a ball to play but has had a couple issues loading.  After about an hour in to the campaign, it would not load, and I started over.  It had the same issue later on, but I exited the game and came back and let it sit and it ended up loading.  This is the only character that has had this issue.

One thing I really like, and has a real D&D feel, is that leveling is slow.  It took hours of play to reach fourth level.  That does not mean that I felt weak the whole time, quite the contrary: Each level up was significant and memorable.

I also didn't feel invulnerable or super-powered.  There are some battles that I had to avoid and times when I was glad I was able to talk or buy my way out.  My wife called me a wuss more than once.

The more I play, the more of a D&D vibe I sense from it.  Concessions have been made for the sake of the medium, but that can't be avoided.

Anyhoo, I'm glad I grabbed it, and I haven't even done multi-player yet.  Looking forward to that experience.

reviewText:
Wow, I am really liking this game. It may not be Neverwinter Nights or Baulders Gate, but it seems as though it might be their offspring and may just need some time to grow? It's really great and I really don't understand the negativity. I've played D&D pen and paper and computer games going back to the DOS Goldbox series, and this is a very respectable addition to the D&D CRPG library. In some ways it seems similar to Neverwinter Nights 2 in style and playability, although I always felt that NWN2 was a bit of a mess when it came to any form of stable online play.

Also, I feel as though this game is made for the 'old school' D&D folks like myself. And bravo n-Space for delivering on a non-massive online game that the 'old school' have been starved for over the past decade. So, thanks very much for that! I should also add that NWN is probably my most favourite game of all time, and this is a pretty good homage to that era.

Anyhow, just wanted to add that I'm loving this game and I haven't loved a new CRPG for a very long time.

reviewText: At first, yes, Sword Coast Legends seemed underwhelming when I placed it next to titanic titles such as Shadows of Amn, Icewind Dale, and the incredible success of Neverwinter Nights. Still, I dove into Sword Coast Legends hoping for a gem in the rough and I soon found the rich and immersive, and often humorous storyline. I never take jabs at a company who put out a game with only a small development team, and I will not do so with the SCL team. The developers respond quickly to issues and have set a path to make SCL a force to be reckoned with. After the CP1 release, I found that most all major bugs were hashed out and the level up trees became a bit more immersive, if you don't mind doing a little leg work. The true gem here lies in the DM mode and the ability to create custom adventures, and then run them for adventurers as a RL DM would. There is also a dungeon crawl aspect, allowing a group of adventurers to delve through tireless dungeons (which can also be DM'd). I suspect this will receive much attention from the devs as I found it truly amazing myself, and for anyone who does not care to craft DM based dungeons.\nIn close, I think the community was too harsh in their initial opinion of SCL, especially after only a few hours of gameplay after release day. There is so much potential with this game, and the dev team has already hinted at some of the truly amazing content they will release by Christmas. Buy this game; it is nothing like Diablo (thank God). It plays and feels closer to Shadows of Amn mixed with aspects of Neverwinter Nights.

reviewText:
Don't believe the haters.

This game deserves a much higher rating than the 57% its got right now!
Most of the negative votes come from people that are disappointed that this game is not exactly what they expected it to be. As much as I can relate to that disappointment, because sadly this game doesnt follow the real AD&D ruleset for the most part, one still should be able to enjoy a game for what it actually is and not for the thing one desperately wants it to be.

I'm a HUGE AD&D-games fanboy myself (on computer ofc, theres not much Pen'n'Paper where i live ^^), BG2 still being one of my favourite games of all time and i loved all the old Infinity-Engine games! And I'm enjoying my time with this game very much.

There is a lot of love for detail and world creation apparent here and theres a ton of content present: Many locations, quests, items, funny situations. The score is very nice and i personally loved all the voice acting (esp. Larethar).
Its not on par with the big ones up there (BG1/2, PT e.g.) but that doesnt mean this isnt a lot of fun!

If you are a cRPG fan, do yourself a favour and give this one a try....don't believe the haters.

reviewText:
This lovely game D&D derived game is well worth buying at the current 33% discounted price if only for the fun of playing through the  solo campaign.  The Campaign/Module development tools have seen regular updates in recent weeks and by now there are a lot of player made adventures to be had once you've finished the core campaign.  I've not played on a multiplayer basis with a live DM so far but forum feedback suggests that it's a load of fun playing with a group of friends and less fun playing with random people.

There has been a lot of negative press for this game since launch but to me this was mainly due to the developer's trying to please too many different rpg gaming audiences at the same time which then had too many compromises.  By now the game is  seeing a lot of development from some clever guys writing mods which are giving the game a much more 'D&D' feel and at the same time the developers are making continuous improvements based on player comment.  In some ways SCL is a work in progress, but this is part of the charm and for me it adds to the fun since the community chat becomes part of the overall experience.

Having played many CRPG's over many decades this game has held my attention for far longer than many others both past & present.   The game is lots of fun in it's current form and definetely has a huge potential with the current development path.   If you enjoy the spontenaiety & imagination which 'pen & paper' rpg's require then this game is being developed with you in mind but if you're the type of person who demands a perfect gaming experience straight from the box then SCL is probably not for you ...... yet.

reviewText:

Being a dungeon master is all about making the game fun challenging with maybe some twists like spawn an ogre make it friendly turn it into a shop take control of it and bash some enemy's with it then when it looks good enough make it hostile turn it into an elite and watch the struggle.

As a DM you get penalised for killing adventurers so spend your points wisely maybe block of obvious routes force them to take detours remember you are the DM make them work for their gold/items

reviewText:
A Very 5th Edition D&D Experience.
If you are unfamiliar with 5E D&D on the tabletop, you may be very disappointed with this game.

The mixed reviews we're seeing are because of two major reasons-

1) This game is very true to its 5th Edition heritage, which is something that WotC have deliberately made into an easy-to-grasp-but-bland-and-flavorless experience. The lack of character to the game and story are inherent in the material. The limited class list, reduced ability trees, all of this is 5th Edition perfectly translated.
The combat is dull and repetative. As is 5E table top combat. I think the game is judged harshly here but the problem is the core experience is flawed in and of itself, but that comes from the pen and paper side, not the computer side.

2) This game was rushed out the door, even with a delayed release date. Simply put- for a game that's supposed to have a built in DM engine as well as a single player experience, there is a significant lack of customization and variation in the tools and assets included. You cannot make too many kinds of encounters, and the tools are limited to say the least.
The game feels like it was shipped missing 100 to 200 hours of more art and voice assets still to be included. That's not explicitly said, but promises of the pre-release articles were for a much more robust experience than was delivered. The voices and character customization options are not only slim and but widely vary. Female characters come in only 4 flavors - Smart, dumb, mean, and smart-alec. Nothing in-between, just polar opposites.
The conspiracy theorists might say this is for DLC, but I don't think the devs actually had the time to get done what they originally promised in the pitches.

D&D veterans will findthings to enjoy here, but this isn't Baldur's Gate or Neverwinter Nights in the least.

I have only played the story mode so far, so I can't rate the multiplayer mode.
The story mode is absolutely brilliant though. Funny dialogues. Not too much to read.
Fast gameplay (camera, fights, etc.) Excellent  implementation of the DnD 5 rules - in my opinion.

I had a great time playing the game and will try another hard-mode walkthrough soon...

Easy to play .. good fun .. made me laugh out loud on several occasions!

reviewText:
Disappointed with this game. After playing Pillars of Eternity, Sword Coast Legends is a real let-down :(

Pros:
- Skill trees are moderately interesting
- D&D-like

Cons:
- Poor UI especially inventory, skill bar customisation, character selection
- Combat is boring and too fast to appreciate the details
- Dialogue is non-skippable and poorly written
- Lacks sense of immersion

I'll play this because I paid money for it but if I had a demo I wouldn't have bothered buying it.

Recommend do not buy this game.

reviewText: I would love to give a very in-depth review of all the things I found disappointing about Sword Coast Legends, but I feel that the action is genuinely fruitless.  The Devs don't care, even with their (at the time of writing) Mixed review score of 58% (EDIT: 52% one month later) positive looming over their heads.  The general public doesn't care, as it has either moved on and stopped following the game in bitter disappointment, or is a small dedicated fanbase who like the generic cookie cutter hack n' slash gameplay and can't stop touting how awesomely generic the gameplay is.  And people who are considering SCL as a purchase option are just going to give a look at the Mixed reviews and walk away without actually reading my review anyways.\n\nI gave SCL time to update, but as near as I can tell, the so-called Community Content Packs" contain none of the features that I saw most requested by the community
date: and did nothing to alleviate my own complaints about the game.  The devs are sticking to their guns on this poorly designed game (and really
recommended: it is without a doubt the designers and producers on this one that should be sacked)
hoursPlayed: and letting their deceptive marketing team flavor all of the sales pitches with buzzwords to make it sound like they care what the people think.  Thanks for barfing on my plate and telling me it is a delicacy.\n\nEDIT:  For the record
voteText: none of the people on my friends list who own this game are even willing to play it anymore.  It started as a four-pack purchase
helpfulPercent: and now the mere mention of it makes people angry.  Makes me wonder how eager the community will be to gobble up N-Space's next project
votesHelpful: whatever it may be.  Their crack marketing team should be able to scrape up at least a few sorry investors with a low Wisdom score for one more digital travesty.\n\nSECOND EDIT:  Rock Paper Shotgun released an article (March 30
votesTotal: 2016) stating that Sword Coast Legends Developer N-Space has closed and laid off all employees.  It remains to be seen what will happen to the game
